The New York Times

 

PUB-DATE: September 3, 2000

SECTION: Section 6; Page 46; Column 1; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 3615 words

HEADLINE: Monday Night Football's Hail Mary

BYLINE: By Julian Rubinstein; Julian Rubinstein is a freelance writer whose last article for the magazine was about John McEnroe.

 BODY:
Last spring, newspapers across the country were publishing articles almost daily about ABC's search for a new "Monday Night Football" announcer to join the veteran Al Michaels in the broadcast booth. With the N.B.A. playoffs in full swing and kickoff still four months away, this kind of publicity would have ordinarily been a testament to the strength and power of the N.F.L. and its top-rated weekly telecast. But, as the N.F.L. commissioner, Paul Tagliabue, knew too well, exactly the opposite was true.
Tagliabue had been feeling the heat from the networks that televise the league's games. In the last go-round, ABC, CBS, Fox and ESPN anted up a record $17.6 billion over eight years, which, they quickly discovered, made it impossible for them to make money. During those negotiations two years ago, Dick Ebersol, president of NBC Sports, had angrily ended his network's 33-year relationship with the league, saying that he "refused to put the livelihood of its employees at risk" by entering into such an imprudent deal. The continued ratings slump last year only hammered home his point. In March, following the worst season ever for "Monday Night Football," ratings-wise, ABC convinced the programming guru Don Ohlmeyer to come out of retirement and retool the show he produced in its heyday. 
 Now, if the newspapers were to be believed, the conservative radio host Rush Limbaugh was up for the announcer's job. Tagliabue knew Ohlmeyer as the man who had taken NBC's entertainment division from dead last to the top of the TV universe, and he hoped that the Limbaugh reports were either a joke or a marketing ploy. But ABC was refusing to confirm or deny the reports. He picked up the phone and called Ohlmeyer at his home in Beverly Hills to set up a meeting.
The two men sat down to breakfast a few days later at the Four Seasons in Los Angeles, where Tagliabue suggested Ohlmeyer consider the veteran ESPN reporters Tom Jackson and Robin Roberts for the job. But Ohlmeyer wasn't there to talk about announcers. Instead, he steered the conversation toward what he felt was the bigger issue and the reason he had decided to go back to producing football games at age 55. "This is a critical year for sports and television," Ohlmeyer remembers telling him. So-called reality shows like "Survivor" were about to transform viewers' expectations for entertainment on television. And a new pro football league, dreamed up by the wrestling impresario Vince McMahon and brought to NBC by Ebersol, would begin play in 2001, promising to bring fans closer to the game than they had ever been before. If the N.F.L. wanted to stay ahead in this environment, Ohlmeyer said, it would have to change its ways.
By the end of the two-hour meeting, Tagliabue had only one question: Would Ohlmeyer come to the N.F.L. owners' meeting in two weeks and tell them what he had just told him?
When the new "Monday Night Football" makes it regular-season debut tomorrow night, Ohlmeyer's innovations won't exactly leap out of the TV set. With great effort, he helped persuade the league to mount miniature cameras on the referees' caps and to allow more reporters to roam the sidelines and interview players coming on and off the field at halftime. The greatest change, however, will be the comedian in the broadcast booth, Dennis Miller, the first nonsports announcer ever to join a major sports telecast.
The criticism that greeted Miller's appointment shows what Ohlmeyer is up against. "I thought the game was the entertainment," sneered John Madden of Fox. The purists have a point: sports remains a staple of network TV, and the N.F.L. is the single biggest draw. But there is so much product on the air (by one calculation, 235 hours a day of sports programming pours into the typical American home) that it's impossible for even the mighty N.F.L. to maintain its dominance. More than that, sports is losing the golden demographic it once owned: young men. Forty-seven percent more of them tuned in to the Monday night telecast of McMahon's "Raw Is War" last year than to "Monday Night Football."
Sports had always been considered the ultimate formula -- the original "reality TV" that unlike every other type of show on television never needed reinventing. But the way that Don Ohlmeyer and Dick Ebersol are attacking the problem this year, even that notion is being challenged. As former proteges of Roone Arledge at ABC -- and old friends themselves -- they have made their reputations as entertainment producers. And in their view, relative to what else is on television, sports has lost its spark. Viewers love the highlight reels, but persuading them to sit through an entire game is getting harder all the time.
How far will they be able to go? Ebersol has a completely unproved entity in the XFL, but his costs are low and he can get away with practically anything. Ohlmeyer's advantage is that he has the N.F.L., notoriously conservative and fiercely protective of its game but also far and away the pre-eminent brand in sports, and as tough and ruthless a competitor as Microsoft.
Don Ohlmeyer glides his black mercedes sedan through the crowded streets of Los Angeles toward Dodger Stadium. He's running late for the night game between the Dodgers and the Angels, but he is in no rush. The most important lesson Roone Arledge taught him, he says, is never to be at the mercy of the game.
Ohlmeyer is tall and bearlike, with a mouth that curls playfully at the corners as if to suggest that he always knows more than he's saying. He calls everyone, including his male friends, Honey, making a point of always seeming at ease. He made it through seven years as the West Coast president of NBC wearing black cotton Nike sweatsuits (perfectly pressed) and black loafers, the same outfit he's wearing to the game.
As he settles into his regular third-row seat near first base, he admits that it was frustration with the limitations of sports broadcasting that drove him into the entertainment side of the business 17 years ago. "There was a sameness about it," he says. "People have seen thousands of games. How do you get them to watch my telecast?"
When Ohlmeyer joined Arledge at "Monday Night Football" in 1971, the show's second year, it was the only sports program in prime time. Initially, the network had been reluctant even to fork out the $8.5 million rights fee to put it on the air. But Arledge, then president of ABC Sports, promised to make the show like nothing anybody had ever seen. He deployed three times as many cameras as other networks and provided coverage not just of the plays but also of the players themselves and of the crowd's reactions. The shots of stadium lights gleaming off the players' helmets, backed by the staccato voice of Howard Cosell, made even humdrum matchups seem like once-in-a-lifetime epics. John Lennon, Burt Reynolds, Gov. Ronald Reagan and Vice President Spiro Agnew made guest appearances. While other networks lambasted Arledge's "show biz" approach to football, the show became a juggernaut.
"Monday Night Football" not only defined how sports was packaged on television; it also changed forever the economics of the industry. The major sports leagues, suddenly aware of their value as prime-time fare, escalated their demands for fees. Though total ratings for many sports began to slip in the 1980's, with the advent of cable, the leagues ratcheted up their rates at every contract renegotiation.
Ohlmeyer began to feel the financial pressure as far back as 1977, when he left ABC for the top job at NBC Sports. While there, he hired some of the top broadcasters in the business, including Bob Costas and Bryant Gumbel. But always seeking larger audiences, he put on a Jets-Dolphins game in 1980 with no announcers at all. It rated well, thanks to the hype Ohlmeyer engineered, but he knew it was a one-time gimmick.
By that point in his career, he had bought a house in Los Angeles and was commuting to New York every weekend in the fall to oversee the network's N.F.L. programming. His patience with sports was wearing thin. Soon he not only stopped flying in; he stopped watching the telecasts altogether. On Sundays, he would get up in the morning, hit the golf course around 10 and by 11:30 -- 2:30 in New York, the halftime show -- he would be making the turn at the Bel Air Country Club. "I'd call the studio and say, 'Tell Charlie Jones to stop talking so much and tell so-and-so to talk about why things happen, not what happens,"' he says. "They all thought I was watching."
So when Howard Katz, president of ABC Sports, called him in December to ask if he would consider returning to "Monday Night Football," Ohlmeyer, happily retired and golfing every day, had to laugh. But the more he thought about the offer, the more enticing it became. "This was the show that had launched my career," he says. "Now I had the chance to go back and bring everything I'd learned in the interim to bear." In March, Ohlmeyer decided he would take the job on the condition that he be given complete freedom. Only after he got assurances from Katz and Robert Iger, president of ABC, did he accept.
On his orders, the entire staff, except for his old golfing buddy Michaels, was dismissed. During the news conference announcing the moves, Ohlmeyer talked about wanting to bring "a sense of danger" and "unpredictability" back to the program, the same elements that would soon make reality TV the new craze.
He began working obsessively from home, often waking up in the middle of the night to jot down ideas. To the extent that he can script a game, he will, and he hired a friend, the television writer and producer David Israel, to help him develop compelling story lines based around the players and matchups each week. "Great storytelling is the key element in any medium," he says.
Finding the right person for the booth took time, but the longer it dragged on, he realized, the more publicity the show got. "There would be days when we'd be playing golf and we'd go through 30 different possibilities, everything from President Clinton -- hey, he needs a job -- to guys who are in jail," Al Michaels says. Ohlmeyer had Billy Crystal, Chris Rock and Dennis Miller on his list, but he initially thought of the entertainers as hosts of a souped-up halftime show. In mid-May, Ohlmeyer received a call from Miller's agent telling him that Miller wanted to be in the booth. At that time, Rush Limbaugh was in fact the front-runner for the job; Ohlmeyer saw his divisiveness as a selling point. "People used to pay for the pleasure of throwing a brick through the TV at Howard," Ohlmeyer says. But executives at ABC, including Arledge, made it clear to Ohlmeyer that picking Limbaugh would be a mistake. Then there was Tagliabue. Ohlmeyer knew he had played it perfectly when they met for breakfast. But he still needed the league's favor when it came to getting the gametime access and scheduling preference he felt were necessary
Ohlmeyer figured Miller was "worth a meeting," and after a promising audition, he emerged as the favorite. The other top contender was more in the strident Cosell mold: Tony Kornheiser, a kvetching 52-year-old columnist for The Washington Post who had gained a surprisingly strong following for his show on ESPN Radio. But Ohlmeyer believed Miller's iconoclastic image would better appeal to the key young male demographic. As a courtesy, he called Tagliabue the week before he made the hire and got his blessing. The flirtation with Limbaugh had been shrewd. By comparison, even a comedian was taken seriously by the N.F.L.
Michaels, too, enthusiastically endorsed the choice. "If he's as good as I think he can be," Michaels says, "this will be trendsetting."
Miller, whose weekly HBO show runs from January through August, the opposite of the N.F.L. season, is feeling the pressure. "I have shadow memories of 'Saturday Night Live,' the whole revival of a franchise," he says. "I don't know if I'm the guy to do this, but I'm a decent roll of the dice."
Dick Ebersol is a studious, almost grandfatherly man of 53, an appearance that belies his reputation as the most dangerous man in the business. His ability to land huge deals before anyone else has even imagined them made NBC the leader among network sports divisions over the last decade. In 1995, he stunned the industry when, after secretly flying to the world track-and-field championships in GRated PG-13teborg, Sweden, he sneaked through the hotel's service elevators to meet with I.O.C. members, locking up the rights to telecast every summer and winter Olympics through 2008. No one else had even begun to bid for 2000.
But Ebersol never moved quicker than he did last February, when his assistant popped her head into his office and suggested he flip on the TV. There was Vince McMahon presiding over a news conference at his W.W.F. Restaurant in Times Square, announcing the formation of the XFL, a new eight-team circuit that would begin play the following winter after the N.F.L. season was finished.
After bidding good riddance to the N.F.L., Ebersol had spent the last 18 months trying to create his own pro football league with Turner Sports. But he couldn't figure out what would draw viewers to a league owned by a TV network. The XFL was a little different from what he had envisioned; it was a "brand of smash-mouth football," McMahon said, "not for pantywaists and sissies." It wouldn't be scripted like his wrestling programs, McMahon insisted, but there was no doubt it would be a made-for-television extravaganza like no other in sports. Cameras and microphones would be everywhere, including in the locker rooms and in the huddles; the cheerleaders would not only be the prettiest in football -- they would also be "encouraged" to date the players.
Ebersol was well acquainted with McMahon. In 1985, they went into business together. Then an independent producer, Ebersol sold "Saturday Night's Main Event" to NBC, where it ran for six years, making both men a fortune and putting wrestling on the map. When Ebersol rejoined NBC in 1989, he had to sell his stake back to McMahon, but he had watched as the popularity of the W.W.F. mushroomed. "Raw Is War" was the most popular show on cable television last year.
As Ebersol listened to McMahon that afternoon, he realized that if he was going to put his reputation on the line and buy a football league, there was no surer bet. Producing each game would most likely cost less than NBC paid for a typical three hours of prime-time programming, and linking up with McMahon would all but guarantee a core audience of young viewers. By the time McMahon was in his limo heading back to his Stamford, Conn., headquarters, his cell phone was ringing. It was Ebersol. "Don't do anything else yet," he told McMahon. Two months later, they announced the historic deal: NBC was investing $30 million in the W.W.F. and would be a 50-50 owner of the XFL, marking the first time a major sports league would share ownership with a network. The games will be shown weekly on NBC, one of them as a prime-time lead-in to "Saturday Night Live," the show Ebersol created in 1975.
Ebersol is not new to controversy. Critics have tarred him for moves like his decision to show the summer Olympics in Sydney entirely on tape, so he can package the events as shiny human-interest dramas for prime-time audiences. But the opprobrium brought on by the XFL deal was harsher than ever. It's one thing, after all, to deal with McMahon on wrestling, but endorsing his brand of football? The New York Post headlined its story, "NBC Makes Deal With Devil." The former CBS executive Rick Gentile calls the XFL "a fiasco." Even his mentor thought Ebersol had gone too far. "At some point you have to decide how classy you want to be," Arledge says.
But if Ebersol has been a visionary about anything, it is deal making. By becoming a partner in the XFL itself, Ebersol has declared sports leagues unnecessary middlemen. The game will belong to TV in every conceivable way. "Intimacy is coming, coming, coming," he says. "But it's been slowed down by the infrastructure of sports. With the XFL, intimacy is something the league is based on; it's part of the deal."
At the house of blues in West Hollywood, Vince Mcmahon's entrance is preceded by a booming, lights-out, videotaped introduction, in which Dick Ebersol calls him "the best promoter in America." It is supposed to be a news conference announcing the XFL's new Los Angeles franchise, but he is greeted with thundering applause and cheers. Dressed fashionably in a fitted black suit with a white shirt and no tie, McMahon gets right to the point. "The arrogance and the lack of common sense of the suits at the N.F.L. is not to be believed," he says, mimicking the clipped rhythms of a preacher. "Put one hand on the quarterback -- and the whistle blows! You're not protecting the quarterback in the name of safety. You're protecting him in the name of investments. That's. Not. Football. Pause, sigh. The suits at the N.F.L. Head shake, pause. Penalize end zone celebrations? What the hell is that? Why that's downright un-American."
Tagliabue will not respond to McMahon's taunts or even acknowledge the XFL's existence (on the advice of his lawyers, concerned about potential antitrust charges). But he says the N.F.L. would never consider gimmicks like microphones in the huddle. "Obviously the reason is competitive," the commissioner says. "You can't put strategy on the air for other teams to watch. This is a game of surprise. We've done focus groups, and what they tell us is what sells football is the competition on the field. That's what gives us the No. 1 audience in sports. It doesn't depend on where the microphones are or who we interview at halftime. It depends on the national passion for the game."
Just in case that's not enough anymore, Ohlmeyer is returning to the same tactics he used to make NBC "Must-See TV." He persuaded ABC, for the first time, to hire an outside ad agency to make "Monday Night Football" hip again. The catchy slogan, "Monday Night Football,' It's Powerful Stuff," will be plastered everywhere, on television and billboards and even the floors of supermarket aisles. And he plans to go head to head against McMahon for young male viewers by attempting to buy ad time on W.W.F. programs in the local markets. "It's going to be a battle," says a senior marketing staff member at ABC Sports.
There may also be battles with the league; if ratings don't improve, Ohlmeyer will surely turn up the pressure to be granted more liberties. Even if he can't have microphones in the huddle, he has plenty more ideas where "referee cam" came from. Tagliabue says that he "feels like we're in good hands with Don," but it's clear that unlike McMahon and Ebersol, he and Ohlmeyer aren't in the same business.
"My only concern is the viewer," Ohlmeyer says, leaning back in his seat at the Dodgers game. "That is why Nascar has been so successful. They've changed the rules in the middle of the season to change the air-intake valves, put restrictor plates on. What they're basically saying is, 'We want a race where a bunch of cars will have a chance to win on the last lap.' That's what the fan wants."
By the seventh inning, the highest-paid pitcher in baseball, the Dodgers' Kevin Brown, is giving out hits like Halloween candy, and Ohlmeyer's team is down by four runs. "We're outta here," he says, standing up to leave. "They're not coming back from this."
On a humid night in Canton, Ohio, on the last day of July, the new "Monday Night Football" team took to the air for the first time, a preseason game between the San Francisco 49ers and the New England Patriots. The telecast opened with a beautifully shot prepackaged story about rookies trying to make an N.F.L. team; Al Michaels described training camp as "the ultimate game of 'Survivor."'
When they came back live, Michaels introduced Dennis Miller by saying that he had "come to expect the unexpected, but this is off the charts." It may have been the most anticipated moment in the history of sportscasting. Miller said: "If there's anyone in this stadium more pumped up than me, they wouldn't pass the league's standardized drug test."
The telecast featured noticeably improved sound quality of the grunts and groans of players in the trenches, and the view from the referee cam was revealing. Ohlmeyer's secret plan for halftime would have to wait as the network broadcast an update on the Republican convention. "Republicans and Democrats," Miller said, when Michaels mentioned the halftime fare, "there's a couple of 4-12 teams."
In the end, though, it all felt very much like a football game -- and a bad one at that. The Patriots won, 20-0. Of the seven pages of material Ohlmeyer and Israel had prepared for the announcers, they only used about 5 percent. Miller managed to make use of one of his own well-scripted lines; with a minute left in the game, he said, "Don Meredith used to have his saying. I figured I'll give mine a shot, and I'm going to say, 'Start blow-drying Teddy Koppel's hair, because this one is done."'
It was amusing stuff, but by referencing the past, it pointed out the biggest challenge Ohlmeyer -- and by extension, all of professional sports -- face: how do you make an old, familiar product seem fresh and new? "Monday Night Football" has always treated the game itself as sacred, and it will this season, too, even with a comedian in the booth. Commissioner Tagliabue has to be happy about that. But he won't be if it doesn't boost the ratings.

HEADLINE: THEATER;
The Bard of American Politics, Still Campaigning

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY; Adam Nagourney is a political correspondent for the Metropolitan desk of The New York Times.

 BODY:
GORE VIDAL wrote "The Best Man" in 1959, a time when Joseph McCarthy's legacy endured, when Adlai Stevenson and Richard Nixon were among the nation's leading politicians, and when Mr. Vidal counted as his friend a young senator from Massachusetts named John F. Kennedy. The play, first produced on Broadway in March 1960, eight months before Kennedy was elected president, drew on these influences to become a tale of politics that may seem improbable today: a stark struggle of two men of obvious complexity, set during a national political convention where decisions of consequence were actually made.
"The Best Man" is returning to Broadway 10 presidential campaigns since it first arrived to favorable reviews. Previews begin on Tuesday at the Virginia Theater, where it opens on Sept. 17 with a cast that includes Charles Durning, Spalding Gray, Chris Noth, Elizabeth Ashley, Christine Ebersole and Michael Learned, under the direction of Ethan McSweeny. 
 The play is dated, yet it is not, and in that, it is very much like the 74-year-old Mr. Vidal himself. Politics have changed mightily since 1959, and the play and its author are a reminder that much of what once so invigorated the nation's presidential selection process -- the suspense, the unvarnished characters, the sense that something meaningful was at stake -- has seeped away.
Mr. Vidal attended his first convention at the age of 14, yet he did not even consider stopping by when the Democrats met in Los Angeles to nominate Al Gore last month, even though he was 25 minutes away by car, settled in at a rooftop suite with a private garden at the Regent Beverly Wilshire Hotel. "It's too dismal," Mr. Vidal said, the morning after President Clinton gave his valedictory speech to the assembled Democrats. "I'm not interested in any of the candidates."
Still, Mr. Vidal has not, it seems, lost enthusiasm for what was probably his best-received play, nor has he made any changes in the original script to account for the intervening 40 years. Now formally retitled "Gore Vidal's The Best Man," to avoid confusion with an unrelated movie called "The Best Man" that was released last fall, the drama abounds with themes and lines that are at times strikingly contemporary, notwithstanding the fact that they were written before many of the current crop of politicians were old enough to vote.
"We've had some very good presidents who have slept around a lot more than Bill Russell ever did, and in the White House, too," proclaims the frumpy national committeewoman Mrs. Gamadge (played by Ms. Ashley), as she comes to the defense of a candidate with an exemplary public life and a marriage more complicated than that of the couple now living in the White House. As Russell (Mr. Gray) finds himself drawn into the back alleys of political combat, he laments that he entered public life to put an end to "the business of gossip instead of issues, personalities instead of policies."
Besides the two candidates, who are out to destroy each other, there is a departing president (Mr. Durning), who makes a case for the honorability of lying to the electorate, be it about his terminal medical diagnosis or the fact that he does not believe in God. Most fundamentally, though, Mr. Vidal presents a struggle between two types of politicians who are as common today as they were then: the ruthless, relentless yet effective Senator Joe Cantwell (Mr. Noth), and the honorable, morally grounded yet maddeningly deliberate Bill Russell.
This was Nixon versus Stevenson in its time, the inspiration for the competing politicians in the play, but there is no shortage of present-day analogies. "There are only so many types who are drawn to politics," Mr. Vidal observed. And the questions he raises in setting up the combat between his politicians are the same ones that Bill Bradley's dispirited supporters were asking themselves in New Hampshire as Al Gore cheerfully pummeled their candidate into defeat: Who would make the better candidate for office? And who would make the better president?
"I don't have an answer and I never will," Mr. Vidal said last month in Los Angeles, poking at a slab of seared salmon and drinking iced coffee in the dining room of the Beverly Wilshire, which was teeming with Democratic delegates who, to his constant distraction, had taken to chanting "Gore!" as they marched through the hotel corridors.
"I'm dealing with game players," Mr. Vidal continued. "These are chess games. And I'm not going to analyze the chess player. I'm going to analyze the game." (That said, Mr. Vidal has never attempted to hide his empathy for Stevenson. So it is not surprising that Russell comes across as more noble by the play's end.)
The game, as Mr. Vidal would have it, involves the struggle between Russell and Cantwell to win their party's presidential nomination, played out in two hotel suites in Philadelphia in July 1960, as the convention unfolds around them. Each man has dug up information that could likely doom the other's candidacy. Russell is mortified at his own behavior when, exhorted by his lieutenants and the president, he confronts Cantwell with what he has discovered. "I never thought I could bring up something like this against any man," Russell says. "It revolts me." It falls to Cantwell to buck up Russell. "Oh, come on -- don't give it a second thought," he says. "Look, I don't blame you. I'd certainly use it against you if it was there."
To be sure, the story line would be unimaginable today for obvious reasons. " 'The Best Man' is based on the idea that candidates have secrets," said Jeffrey Richards, one of the play's producers and its press representative. "Today, who has secrets on the eve of the convention?"
In its way, then, the play is a time capsule, a means to measure how much the system has changed. Even the undercurrent of homosexuality, which Mr. Vidal noted was "scandalous" in its time (though certainly not a surprising theme for one of the nation's first openly gay writers), seems almost quaint in these days of Richard Hatch and television's "Survivor."
Even though Mr. Vidal did not alter the script, he would not approach the subject the same way now. "If I were to do a political play today about who governs the United States, it would not be set at a political convention," Mr. Vidal said. "It would be within a board room, as they argue about politicians, and audition politicians, and figure out which one they're going to make president."
Speaking of his drama in light of the present period, he said: "I don't see how you can begin to do a play that's constructed like that -- which is really a dramatic contest between two front-runners. And it can go either way. That doesn't happen anymore. Primaries meant something then, but nobody knew in March who the candidate was going to be -- which we knew in both parties this year. It's predicted by how much money is spent in the primary season and it's quickly wrapped up. So there's nothing to do at a convention but pick a vice president. Generally undramatic, if that."
It is no coincidence that "The Best Man" is being revived this season. Mr. Richards said he had had it in mind for a play-reading project that did not pan out, but still thought "it would be great to do in a year in which there was a presidential campaign."
When he subsequently contacted Mr. Vidal in Italy, Mr. Richards recalled, "His initial questions were: 'Are you really serious about this?' And, 'Do you want me to update it?' "
Mr. Richards said he put "The Best Man" in the category of "classic popular entertainment"; "I wouldn't update 'The Front Page' or 'The Little Foxes.' " At the same time, though, there have been few attempts by any writers over the last 40 years to make politics the subject of a Broadway play (Mr. Vidal tried once or twice after "The Best Man" without much success), and it will be intriguing to see if there is more interest in theatrical treatments of politics than in the game itself. (The 1964 movie version of "The Best Man," for which Mr. Vidal wrote the screenplay, starred Henry Fonda.)
Mr. Vidal is not just another playwright, or historical novelist, or essayist, or commentator, or whichever of the many resume entries he might use to define himself. He has practiced what he is writing about: he ran for Congress from New York in 1960, and for senator from California in 1982, each time as a Democrat; he lost both elections. And while in Los Angeles last month, he was a keynote speaker at a forum sponsored by The Nation, an ideological retreat for Democrats frustrated by the proceedings downtown.
THE speech he gave warned that the drive to increase the country's military might was a threat to the economic viability of the Republic at a time when the nation is anxious for peace and suspicious of interventionism (much as Mr. Gore's grandfather was when he served as a senator from Oklahoma).
"It was quite something," Mr. Gore said. "Not only a standing ovation, but they began to chant, 'Go, Gore! Go, Gore! Go, Gore!' They were running me for president!"
Mr. Vidal is also unusual in that over the years he has kept some notable company. He and Jacqueline Bouvier shared the same stepfather, Hugh D. Auchincloss, at different times, and his conversation is scattered with first-name references to former presidents and first ladies, complete with anecdotes about, and caricatures of, the people he has known.
"It doesn't remind me of Mr. Truman at all," Mr. Vidal declared in a husky falsetto, as he recounted what Eleanor Roosevelt told him when she was asked her opinion of the president in "The Best Man."
As the playwright sat in on a rehearsal the other day in Manhattan, wearing sunglasses and drinking a Diet Coke while the actors competed over the thump of construction machinery outside, he leaned over to offer a real-time footnote to his play. "The next line is one Jack Kennedy gave me," he said. He turned to the makeshift "stage," an assortment of couches, tables and empty Absolut bottles, where one of Russell's supporters proceeded to promise him that he was behind his candidacy "100 percent." That means, then and now, that "you're finished," Mr. Vidal said tartly.
President Kennedy attended a performance of "The Best Man" on Broadway, with Charles Spalding, a longtime friend, at his side. Mr. Vidal stood behind a curtain in the wings, observing the president as the president observed his play. "I had never actually watched anybody who was watching a play," Mr. Vidal said. "I could see their eyes, so I could see who they were looking at. He was following it very attentively. And there was a little giggle between him and Spalding on the line about how to get girls in the White House."
"And then he did his famous" -- Mr. Vidal brought his fingers to his mouth and tapped his teeth, evoking a dozen pictures of Mr. Kennedy -- "which meant he was thinking, he was really following it."
As it turned out, another man who would be president, Ronald Reagan, came close to playing Russell on Broadway. Mr. Vidal rejected that casting suggestion from the producers, and the part went to Melvyn Douglas. "I'm responsible for Ronald Reagan," Mr. Vidal whispered, as the rehearsal continued. "I turned him down for the part. They came to me and said, 'What about Ronald Reagan?' I said, 'He is good, but I don't think he'd be credible as a presidential candidate.' I have always thought that if I had cast him, Melvyn Douglas would have become president. It's been on my conscience ever since."
Mr. Vidal said his days of palling around with presidents ended with the Kennedys: "I learned my lesson from the Kennedys, which is if you want to be effective as a commentator on political matters you've got to stay away from presidents. I was continually attacked as a Kennedy apologist."
He said he had met Mr. Clinton only briefly and found him charming, "and I'm not easily charmed by presidents."
Al Gore is another matter. The two are distant cousins through Mr. Vidal's mother, though Mr. Vidal, in the polite way one talks about strayed relatives, leaves little doubt at his disappointment -- or perhaps disinterest -- in this particular member of the famous family.
Would he vote for his cousin? Mr. Vidal, at this point speaking from his villa in Italy by telephone, laughed heartily at the question. "As they say in the House of Representatives, at the end of the day, Gore is thicker than Nader," he said, presumably meaning that his blood-tie to Mr. Gore counted more than his ideological attraction to Ralph Nader.
In any event, Mr. Vidal said he had never met Mr. Gore, and does not think it possible to learn much about him, or George W. Bush, from the way presidential campaigns are conducted. "We'll never know whether they're interesting or not," he said.
Speaking of himself, Mr. Vidal said that at his age, he had reached the "springtime of my senility." As sharp and acerbic as ever, he is also white-haired, magisterial in bearing and a bit slow in his gait. "I don't do e-mail," he declared. He did not seem fazed at the rehearsal when, during a break, Michael Learned asked if he would autograph a copy of his 1967 historical novel, "Washington, D.C." He is about to publish "The Golden Age," the concluding volume in his series on American history.
Mr. Vidal follows developments in American politics by way of CNN and The International Herald Tribune from his home in Ravello, though he is indignant at the suggestion that he is something of a recluse, a subject he had raised himself as the lunch in Beverly Hills had come to a quiet end, without dessert. "The illusion that the press has carefully developed, because my views are not popular with management, is that I must be depicted as an exile -- an embittered expatriate. I am no such thing, and they know it. I've been involved in every election, in one way or another, as a commentator, sometimes as a candidate, for most of my life. And this, after all, is my subject as a writer."

HEADLINE: Alaska

 BODY:

To the Editor: With more than 570,300 square miles of land mass, Alaska is about one-fifth the size of the continental United States. These facts add perspective to Timothy Egan's story, "A Land So Wild, It's Getting Crowded" (Aug. 20).
While there are powerful outside interests that would like to see our state turned into a national park, Alaska is far from becoming "Disneyfied." These organized groups fail to recognize the economic needs of the state's 615,000 residents, many of whom are dependent on tourism to sustain their families. 
 Accessible only by air and sea, Juneau, Alaska's capital city, is proud of its long-standing tradition of welcoming visitors. Historic downtown Juneau is a port -- not a park -- that has served as the heart of commerce for more than a century. America's last frontier has something for everyone and ample room to grow.
 
JOHN MAZOR
President and C.E.O.
Convention and Visitors Bureau
Juneau, Alaska

HEADLINE: Where the Pilgrims Lived, Megaprojects Now Loom

BYLINE: By SUSAN DIESENHOUSE

DATELINE: PLYMOUTH, Mass.

 BODY:
FOR 340 years after the Pilgrims settled here, Plymouth and its neighbors in southeast Massachusetts grew very slowly. Then in 30 years, from 1960 to 1990, the population of this 103-square-mile town, the state's largest municipality and still a sizable slice of cranberry growing country, tripled.
Better transportation, good schools, lots of land, reasonable prices and proximity to the jobs in Boston and its beltways attracted families seeking single-family houses in traditional subdivisions. 
 While eager for growth, this town of 50,000 residents and its neighbors in the still rural region began feeling overwhelmed and took various planning measures to deal with the rapid expansion. But that boom seems modest compared to what is coming: megaprojects.
In Plymouth, construction is under way on a 3,000-acre mixed-use project with almost 3,000 luxury houses that will be the town's biggest development so far. That project, called Pinehills, will in turn be dwarfed by another being planned by the A. D. Makepeace Company, a major cranberry grower. The company has filed preliminary plans for tract subdivisions that could contain 3,000 to 7,000 houses on 9,600 acres spanning Plymouth, Carver and Wareham.
The megaprojects have brought worries for these communities.
"The towns are scared to death of losing their open space and having a demand for services -- schools, water, sewer and fire protection -- they can't provide," said John Lenox, the town planner here. "So they've enacted building caps, moratoriums; increased minimum lot sizes; or overencouraged commercial development, all of which consumes twice as much open space."
While Plymouth has a full-time government and a professional town planner able to promulgate sophisticated zoning, its small neighbors have only part-time officials, explained Steven Smith, executive director of the Southeastern Regional Planning and Economic Development District, a federally financed agency working with all of the towns and developers.
"The region isn't prepared for the growth that's coming," he said. "Most of the zoning doesn't give the towns or developers much choice other than large-lot, single-family subdivisions that spread all over the hills."
Basically, Mr. Smith and others worry that the 51 towns from Duxbury (about 30 miles south of Boston) to Westport (just shy of the Rhode Island border) will not have the tax base to deliver resident services or the regulations to prevent the still sparsely settled hills, bogs and beaches from being plowed under or polluted.
Part of the growing attraction of this area is that it is one of few regions in eastern Massachusetts with moderately priced single-family houses. The average selling price in Plymouth this summer was $204,682. In Boston it was $823,000 for a house of fewer than 2,400 square feet; for a larger house, it was $1.4 million, said Debra Taylor, owner of Link, a real estate information service in Boston.
BUYERS like Michael Bash found both more house and a country way of life in Plymouth that is not available closer to his Boston-based cleaning company. Last fall Mr. Bash; his wife, Ellen; and their two daughters moved into a 2,800-square-foot four-bedroom house in Harrison Woods. This 32-lot subdivision, deftly tucked into a wooded 125-acre site, has a private 22-acre pond good for swimming, fishing and kayaking. House prices range from about $300,000 to $400,000, said Vivian Mulligan, who with her husband, Patrick, is the developer.
"Plymouth has breathing room," said Mr. Bash, who moved here from Hull, a tightly packed beach resort just south of Boston, where he had lived for 40 years. "You have your privacy and nice neighbors, excellent schools, more house for your money. And the extra commute isn't much."
Mulligan Homes bought the site, a former Boy Scout camp, in 1997 and started construction the next year. The first buyers moved in last year. Now 20 homes are occupied, six more are being built and the Mulligans are holding the last six lots as an investment. They expect to complete construction of the 26 homes and the surrounding roads by mid-2001.
For decades, Harrison Woods and similar subdivisions have fed the growth here. Now a new era of larger-scale development is dawning as construction on the $1 billion Pinehills proceeds.
Three years of planning will result in 2,854 attached and detached houses priced from about $300,000 to more than $1 million. The houses will be in clusters, and the 3,037-acre forested site will include about 2,000 acres of open space offering residents -- mostly empty nesters and retirees -- panoramic views of Cape Cod Bay, woods and four golf courses.
The developer, Pinehills L.L.C., has construction financing from the Fleet National Bank division of the FleetBoston Financial Corporation.
So far, it has built one mile of roads with underground utilities, a private well, a 7,400-square-foot office building called the Summerhouse and seven model homes set for completion in October, when marketing will begin. Of four golf courses planned, two are in construction along with a village center, which will have 1.3 million square feet of commercial space: a hotel, conference center, retail and offices. The land planner is Sasaki Associates of Watertown, Mass.
Seeing the megaprojects approach, in the mid-1990's Plymouth enacted new zoning bylaws. They allow cluster designs for projects that leave three acres per house somewhere on the site and special permits for more dense developments like Pinehills. On parcels of 3,000 acres or more, the new zoning allows overlay districts, where mixed-use projects can be built in areas zoned residential or agricultural. Because an annual building cap of 185 houses took effect last year, about 200 new houses are going up now, compared with 287 in 1999 and 336 in 1998.
Some local and regional planners point to the cluster-zoning approach taken by Pinehills, which is conserving 70 percent of the site as open space and building private infrastructure, when they contemplate what might happen to the vastly larger property being developed by the Makepeace Company.
According to Mr. Lenox, the town planner, "Pinehills is a positive alternative to the threat of Makepeace."
Makepeace owns 13,000 acres in the area. It is considering building houses on 9,600 acres, which it could also cultivate, but it is now growing cranberries on only 1,750. Recently, as cranberry prices fell and home prices rose, the company began focusing on real estate development.
What worries Mr. Lenox is that the company "might take 9,600 acres out of agricultural use to build thousands of houses in sprawling subdivisions that we can't serve."
This summer Makepeace started working with regional and town planners to develop an alternative to traditional subdivisions that would enable it to continue its agricultural activity and leave open space as well.
To accomplish this, the company hopes the towns will change their zoning to allow New England village style clusters of luxury houses, a conference center, hotel and golf courses, said John O. Drew, chairman of Makepeace's real estate arm, Sassomon Holdings.
"We don't want to do sprawling subdivisions, but we will if that's the only way to protect shareholder value," said Mr. Drew, a member of the Makepeace clan, which owns 80 percent of the company.
Mr. Smith, the regional planner, said, "The challenge is to rewrite the zoning so this project is an asset rather than a blight."
In its attempt to cope, the 35-square-mile town of Carver introduced a 30-house building cap townwide this summer and a special permit for cluster zoning, which could mean lengthy negotiations with developers.
"The idea isn't to be difficult, but for the town to have some control as we work with each developer," said Sarah Hewins, a planning board member.
Effective planning and good design will indeed determine the impact of future growth on all of these towns, said Mr. Bash of Harrison Woods. But he is certain of one thing: buyers will keep coming.
"People need someplace to live," he said. "And this is such a beautiful commute, a few times I drove right past my exit."

LENGTH: 1480 words

HEADLINE: Growing Frustration in the Computer Aisle

BYLINE: By ALLAN RICHTER

 BODY:
MARIA ORTIZ-TABONE has walked out of a half-dozen computer stores empty-handed, qualifying her as either a very cautious shopper or a very frustrated one. Ms. Ortiz-Tabone, a 50-year-old real estate broker, insists she is the latter.
After strolling through an OfficeMax store in Westbury the other day, she walked away without buying a notebook computer she was eyeing because the manufacturer renting space in the store had not yet staffed its kiosk. 
 She did no better when she moved to a display of hand-held wireless computers, stumping a salesman with questions about Internet service. After the salesman moved on, she threw her hands in the air. "You just can't get help," she said. "They read from the display card."
Ms. Ortiz-Tabone has turned to technical magazines to make up for the deficiency. And she has enrolled in a computer class after a day of comparison-shopping left her no better informed than when she started.
She may find more classmates to commiserate with: finding a technically savvy computer sales associate is about to become even more difficult.
This month's arrival of the consumer electronics chain Best Buy on the Island is likely to benefit consumers by stimulating price competition. But the dozen or so stores that Best Buy, which is based in Eden Prairie, Minn., is planning here over the next several years could stretch an already thin retail labor force, never mind one with technical skills.
"Most computer salespeople don't know the difference between a microprocessor and a meat processor," said Jonathan Jacala, 22, a salesman at a CompUSA store in Garden City. Mr. Jacala was clearly segregating himself from the ill-equipped in his profession as he darted along the aisles seeking customers and lucrative commissions.
CompUSA, which was acquired in March by the Mexican retailer Grupo Sanborns S.A., is the biggest computer specialty chain in the United States, with a long list of corporate and government customers. Best Buy, which is scheduled to open in Westbury, Bay Shore, Levittown and Setauket this fall, focuses more closely on individual sales. Jeff Morgan, an analyst at Levin Consulting in Beachwood, Ohio, which tracks the industry, said that in 1998, Best Buy sold about $400 million more in computers for home use than CompUSA did, out of Best Buy's total computer sales of $3.9 billion that year.
The two chains won't battle it out alone, however. OfficeMax is next door to Best Buy's Westbury site, for instance, and within a short drive are the Wiz, RadioShack, Circuit City, P. C. Richard & Son, Office Depot, Staples and independent retailers.
The sweeping competition is propelling sales growth in consumer electronics past that of retailing in general, which in turn has outpaced the Island's overall economic growth, said Gary Huth, the state's labor market analyst for Long Island.
"The buyers are here, the market is here, but there's a lot of competition, and that's why almost all of these national chains are late in arriving to Long Island," he said. "But they all get here eventually. The market will get tighter for hiring."
Some computer retailers have left the market, but not for lack of demand. Ahron Schachter, the general manager and a vice president of DataVision Computer and Video, an independent retailer, blamed the operators of the Source Mall in Westbury for DataVision's departure last year. He said they failed to promote the mall adequately and expected tenants to pay for advertising to promote other stores.
"Our exit was not because the business isn't there," Mr. Schachter said. "The business is there. We just need a better location, a stand-alone store or a mall that understands what its tenants really need to do the business."
Bob Gedarovich, the manager of the mall, said it was a standard practice for tenant retailers to contribute money to market their landlords' malls. He said DataVision's lease required it to participate.
"Sometimes when somebody's business doesn't turn out to be what they had hoped, they look for all sorts of reasons to assign blame," Mr. Gedarovich said, "but the consumer is king and drives the business."
Another store, Tandy's giant Incredible Universe in Westbury, folded because shoppers did not accept the chain's concept of a Disney-style "entertainment destination" in a somewhat remote location, Mr. Morgan, the analyst, said.
The loss of those retailers will be more than offset by Best Buy's arrival. And Circuit City's departure from the appliance business, which is expected to be completed in November, signals its bid for the mantle of digital retail king.
But the sales staff remains an imponderable, and the demographics of suburbia make the challenge of finding skilled workers even more acute.
Mr. Schachter noted that shoppers at DataVision's Long Island store needed more attention than the company's Manhattan customers.
"You get the mothers with strollers looking at computers, and you need the patience to deal with that," he said. "It's not like a customer who walks into the New York City store and says: 'I know the specs already. Tell me your best deal.' "
Retailers have wrestled for years with trying to figure out how many resources to devote to training specialized staff, said Ursula Moran, who follows specialty retailing for Sanford C. Bernstein, an investment research company. Profit margins in computer retail are low.
Still, selling computers is becoming easier as consumers become more sophisticated. About 60 percent of American households own a personal computer, according to Gartner Dataquest, a research company, and about two-thirds are on their second or third machine.
The role of sales personnel in computer stores has waned as online and other direct sales have spread. But Philip Lu, a Gartner Dataquest analyst, warned of a sizable "group of novice users, grandpa- and grandma-type people, who want to get online. They still prefer some touch-and-feel way of buying. They're not that comfortable with the technology, and have questions."
As one path toward improving customer relations, more retailers are combining the lean direct-sales concept with their brick-and-mortar stores. Circuit City, which operates seven stores on Long Island, plans to provide in-store Web access for customers, said Bill Cimino, a store spokesman. Gateway, a leader in mail-order sales, also has stores here, but they carry no inventory and only take orders. OfficeMax rents out space in its stores to Gateway.
Best Buy is a rarity because its sales force is salaried; most electronics retailers pay their sales associates by commission. But salaried sales personnel may be less aggressive, perhaps to a fault, leaving customers to their own devices when help may be preferred.
But Ms. Moran, the analyst, said that Best Buy overcame problems brought on by rapid growth by investing more heavily in training. "If you go into a Best Buy store these days," she said, "you will find some qualified people."
But can Best Buy and other retailers count on finding skilled employees in the midst of one of the most severe labor shortages the Island has seen?
Best Buy cast a wide net and began its recruiting drive in July 1999, and the company said it was meeting its goals of hiring up to 250 people for each of its planned stores on the Island.
Adam Levin, the president of Levin Consulting, said Best Buy's employment ranks are buoyed by the salary structure and its mix of computer and music products. These draw a younger sales force, he said, compared with the career salesman more likely to be found at Circuit City or P. C. Richard.
The trick is in the training. "We've got people from our competition, from grocery stores, people in the car industry," said Dave Schandle, the general manager of Best Buy's Westbury store. "I've got a stock-market analyst working for me as a part-time salesperson."
Another Best Buy strategy that has worked in other markets has been to import workers from out of state, putting them on a fast track to management in exchange for making the move, said Peter Caruso, a first vice president of Merrill Lynch in Manhattan.
But the resume of David Ring, the retailer's district manager -- he was a regional district manager for the Wiz and brought 15 employees to Best Buy with him -- points to the most likely source for many sales employees: competitors.
The Island's high turnover rate among retail employees is borne out by statistics from Mr. Huth, the state analyst: he estimated that about 12,500 job openings a year in the sector are caused by employees' departures, while only about 2,000 openings are the result of new positions.
For Mr. Jacala, the CompUSA sales associate, job security could not be stronger. "I'm pretty sure CompUSA is the best place to work," he said, "but if anything happens, there's always Best Buy."

HEADLINE: Teaching the Fourth 'R': A Sense of Reality

BYLINE: By JOAN SWIRSKY

 BODY:
THEY'RE teaching ancient Greek in Riverhead and Chinese in Great Neck. Jericho High School students enroll in an emergency medical technician class. In Syosset, middle-school students are learning how to get rich; in Eastport, elementary-school students are learning how to be virtuous.
Reading, writing, and arithmetic, the bedrock of school curricula for generations, are no longer enough, many Long Island educators say, to prepare their students for the challenges of the new century. 
 "The world is much more complex than it used to be," said Jean L. Clark, principal of the South Woods Middle School in Syosset, explaining why the school now offers eighth graders an elective Wall Street-Madison Avenue course in which students develop business plans, create their own mock enterprises, sell the concept to their peers and issue fake stock for fake investment capital.
In addition, they tour the New York Stock Exchange and Federal Reserve in Manhattan, are lectured by parents and account executives from firms like Smith Barney, and participate in a statewide competition in which they create their own portfolios and spend a fictitious $100,000 to research, buy and sell stocks.
"The money is theoretical," said Arthur Goldstein, chairman of the business education and family and consumer science departments in the Syosset school system. "But the course and the competition teach kids that these things are real and involve risk, and how hard it is to be successful making money. They learn a lot when they're not successful -- that investments are more than buying and selling paper. They create capital that fuels the economy of our country."
The Madison Avenue component of the course, he said, "teaches kids who are exposed to so much TV and the Internet how advertising influences their lives as well as businesses and consumers, and that the world of business and advertising is not male-dominated."
The course is a springboard to high-school courses in investment decision-making, sports marketing, business research and ownership, and restaurant management, among others. They can earn college credits through Long Island University, and "about 80 percent of colleges accept these credits," Mr. Goldstein added.
Jenna Rosenfeld, who took the Wall Street course at Syosset's H. B. Thompson Middle School last year, said, "My mother belongs to an investment club and my father invests in the market, so the course gave me a better understanding of a subject that's a big part of everyone's life."
Also on the Syosset middle school menu is "Latin at Lunch," in which students meet in the cafeteria to learn about the roots of English words, study Roman culture and architecture, and hold toga parties.
At Great Neck South High School, Phyllis Trautman Chen has taught Mandarin Chinese for the past four years. "Today, with so many American companies doing business with China," Mrs. Chen explained, "increasing numbers of students are interested in the country and its language. It's the same kind of interest American students used to have in Russian, but now they seem to be bitten by the China bug."
Tim Gurba, 18, took the Chinese course for four years before graduating last June.
"At first, I took the course because my dad pretty much mandated it. He thought it would be good for my future. But the course more than fulfilled my expectations," he said. "Even in a daily sense, I found the language to be just as useful as Spanish, and as far as the future, there is no telling what sort of global economic impact China is going to have, so knowing the language gives you the extra competitive edge in the business world."
At Eastport Elementary School, character development is taught from kindergarten through sixth grade.
"The course is important," said Priscilla Tuttle, who heads the character education committee at the school, "because it demonstrates to children that they can become better people by accentuating their positive qualities. It gives them a reason to believe in themselves and develops traits they'll need in later life when their employers want a responsible, respectful person working for them."
Mrs. Tuttle, who teaches chemistry at Suffolk County Community College, and is the mother of three children under the age of 12, said the course content was based on a survey of parents who rated 15 character traits in order of importance. Nine were chosen, one for each month of the school year.
In conveying the values of responsibility, cooperation, kindness, acceptance, honesty, heroism, fairness, perseverance, and building self-esteem, the teachers employ a variety of methods. If, for instance, a child catches a classmate being kind, the name of the virtuous child is written on a paper leaf that is hung on the school's Kindness Tree.
The children tote garbage bags through the streets of Eastport to assist the town's spring cleanup, donate toys and games to the Salvation Army to distribute to needy families and invite the school's auxiliary staff of secretaries and custodians, whose photographs and names are featured on a bulletin board, to speak to them about their jobs.
Zachary Skarka, 7, said that when honesty was the character trait of the month, he learned that "honesty is important because you and someone else can get hurt. You can lose friends.
"Always tell the truth," he added, "or people won't like you. Lies can get bigger and bigger."
Thomas Lickona is a professor of education at SUNY-Cortland and author of "Educating for Character: How Our Schools Can Teach Respect and Responsibility."
"Education," he said, "has two great goals: to become smart and to become good. Character education used to be an integral part of school learning, but it got less popular with the rise of positivism in the 1940's -- facts are empirical; values are subjective; the personalism of the '60's, that shed new light on personal dignity but also neglected personal responsibility; the pluralism of the '70's that made people ask, 'Whose values should you teach?' and the secularization of the public arena in the '80's and '90's that banned prayer in schools."
Dr. Lickona said that courses like the one taught in Eastport "are a return to a much older form of character education, where honesty, compassion, fairness, self-control, respect and responsibility are recognized as objectively good qualities that transcend time and culture and help the individual and society stem the slide down the ethical tubes."
Such courses may soon be appearing all over the state. The Safe Schools Against Violence in Education Act, which became law in July, mandates that by next July, all public schools in New York must establish "safer and more effective learning environments" through a variety of measures, including comprehensive violence-prevention education programs, granting teachers and principals increased authority to discipline students, and "instruction in civility, citizenship, tolerance, and character education."
"When students are taught the principles of honesty, tolerance, personal responsibility and respect for others, and when they learn courtesy and how to obey rules and laws, all our schools -- students and teachers alike -- will be safer," said Kenneth P. LaValle, a state senator from Port Jefferson and a cosponsor of the measure.
The trend to have schools teach character is not universally embraced. Lainie Marin of East Rockaway said that her daughter Lindsay, 11, a seventh-grader at the Lynbrook Middle School, "can learn the laws of society in school, but when it comes to morals and ethics and knowing right from wrong, that's where the nurture part of parenting comes in. Those are the prerogatives of parents."
"Besides," she added, "people have different definitions of character, so how can a parent be sure that a teacher shares the same values as her student's family?"
Dr. Lickona said that it's not only students who benefit from unconventional programs and courses, but educators as well.
"Teachers want to make a difference in the lives of their students," he said, "not just teach fractions."

HEADLINE: Battle Lines Harden Over Syosset Mall

BYLINE: By LINDA SASLOW

DATELINE: SYOSSET

 BODY:
THE six-year battle over an upscale shopping mall in Syosset will draw a little closer to a resolution on Thursday when the Oyster Bay Town Board holds a public hearing on the proposal. The developer, the Taubman Company of Bloomfield Hills, Mich., is asking for a special-use permit to build the 860,000-square-foot project, to be called the Mall at Oyster Bay, on the 39-acre site formerly owned by the Cerro Wire and Cable Company.
Since 1994, when the development was first proposed, the project has been a source of controversy in the Town of Oyster Bay. 
 "This has become an emotionally charged issue," Supervisor John Venditto said. "Everybody has an opinion and everybody wants the last word. We're dealing with an application that could have a significant impact on the personality of the Town of Oyster Bay and that could change the direction of its future."
Mr. Venditto said he expects the town board to vote on the project next month.
If approved, the Mall at Oyster Bay will be a fashion-oriented shopping center, with a Neiman Marcus and two other anchor stores. One of them may be Saks Fifth Avenue, which was thwarted last year when it tried to move its Garden City store to Roosevelt Field. There will be 125 to 150 smaller shops and a three-level parking garage.
Harry Murphy, the senior vice president for development at Taubman, said: "We're not interested in building another Roosevelt Field. We've discovered in our research that many fashion-oriented stores, like Neiman Marcus, have been looking to get into Nassau County for a long time because it's a ripe market. We have a list of tenants who have no presence on Long Island who we think might be interested in coming out here."
The mall's supporters contend that it will generate jobs and tax revenues, but its critics argue that Nassau County does not need another mall, that it will adversely affect stores already established in other shopping centers and that it will drive out smaller local merchants. They contend that traffic will be a problem, with an estimated 24,000 cars going to and from the mall each day, causing bottlenecks on major arteries. Further, they fear that drivers will cut through residential streets to get to the mall, endangering children in the neighborhood and at two elementary schools nearby.
"I don't know of anyone in the community who approves of this project," said Susan Sariego, who lives in the East Birchwood section of Syosset, near the site. "We are all concerned about how this will affect our quality of life. They keep talking about upscale, but upscale is unimportant when it still generates traffic and pollution to our community. Cars are still cars. I can't imagine how our children will be able to cross the street."
Traffic congestion and safety are the most pressing concerns for local residents, said Todd Fabricant, the chairman of the Cerro Wire Coalition, a group of some two dozen civic associations united to block the mall.
"Jericho Turnpike is already a disaster at 5 o'clock," he said. "The mall's primary entrance will be very close to the Long Island Rail Road crossing, which will result in dangerous conditions. When you put 3,000 cars an hour in front of a railroad crossing on an ongoing basis, there is no way that people will be able to move. There is also no public transportation for workers to get to the mall. Just wait until Christmastime and when the mall runs sales."
Residents are concerned that the proposed mall will destroy existing businesses, said Len Gutterman, a board member of the West Birchwood Civic Association, which represents a neighborhood near the site.
"We've seen Home Depot, BJ's and Costco come to the Island and knock out many small stores," he said. "We wonder, if another mall comes in, what will happen to the small merchants along Jericho Turnpike and Northern Boulevard? And what will happen to the Broadway Mall and Walt Whitman Mall that are not far away?"
Last month, the Nassau County Chambers of Commerce, representing 6,000 businesses, came out against the mall.
"The county is malled out," said Gary Hudes, the organization's president. "From a business standpoint, another mall would result in cutting the retail pie into smaller and smaller pieces. People only have so much money to spend, and unless you bring in new shoppers from outside Nassau County, which is unlikely, the existing money will just be spread around even more."
Mr. Murphy, the executive at Taubman, which was responsible for the Mall at Short Hills, in New Jersey, said that community resistance to a proposed mall was a common initial reaction, one that usually disappears once the mall opens.
"We developed a similar project in an affluent neighborhood in Short Hiills, and there were many concerns, but now they love us there," he said. "We intend to do the same things to make this work in Nassau County."
The Taubman Company is a 50-year-old publicly owned manager of retail malls at 28 locations throughout the United States. Working with the Tribune Company, the Chicago newspaper publisher that now owns the Cerro property, Taubman took control in 1990, four years after Cerro closed its plant and sold the site.
The Cerro Wire and Cable Company built its plant in the early 1950's, and with a work force of 600 it manufactured electrical conduits and copper rods there. The state Department of Environmental Conservation declared it an inactive hazardous waste site in 1983, but after a cleanup, it was removed from the list in 1994.
Proponents of the mall say it will create 4,500 construction jobs and 1,900 permanent jobs and bring in $7 million in property taxes and $22.5 million in sales taxes each year.
"This is a responsible project that will provide $100 million in wages" in three years, during the site preparation and the mall's construction, said Morton Weber, the Melville lawyer who represents Taubman. "Local residents are complaining that they don't want it here, yet these will be the same people who will be among the first to shop there."
The Nassau-Suffolk Building Trades Council, which represents about 60,000 construction workers on Long Island, recently endorsed the project.
"We need work opportunities for our people," said its president, Jack Kennedy. "We're talking about a lot of employment over a long period of time. The property has been an economic black hole that contributes next to nothing in way of tax revenue to the county or town. It's time to build and get rid of this eyesore."
Gary Lewi, Taubman's community affairs representative, said: "The mall is the only thing on the boards that stands between us and tax increases that could be so onerous as to erode our property values. This is something that critics will have to wrestle with, because it's an economic fact of life."
But critics think otherwise. "This is a zoning and planning issue that should not consider the fact that Nassau County is having fiscal troubles," said Howard Avrutine, a Syosset lawyer who represents the Birchwood Civic Association. "It's about how the land should be used appropriately in a way that is harmonious with the surrounding area. Why should residents nearby this property bear a disproportionate burden because Nassau County has financial problems? This shouldn't be a bailout on anybody."
In anticipation of the hearing, Mr. Venditto, the supervisor, said: "There are two very strong positions. It seems that regardless of the final decision by the board, the matter will be the subject of litigation in the Supreme Court and probably beyond. We are determined to make sure that our decision is adequately supported in law by the evidence presented on Thursday."
