HEADLINE: E-Business Alters ABC's of Real Estate

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
AS telecommunications companies lease and modify space for their special needs and for the elaborate specialized pieces of equipment that are the backbone and nerves of electronic commerce, landlords and brokers are adapting some of their ways of doing business to adjust to the new conditions.
Because of their need to have an extraordinarily high level of reliability, the telecommunications companies are installing their own backup systems, including batteries, generators and air conditioning equipment that are independent of the systems already working in buildings. And they are changing established landlord-tenant relationships, including which party makes decisions and who controls parts of a property. 
 Telecommunications sites are becoming a significant factor in the commercial real estate industry. According to a survey conducted by Cushman & Wakefield, the real estate services company, 4.9 million square feet of space has been leased or purchased by these companies in the metropolitan New York region in the last two and a half years.
Because the telecommunications industry is the basis for the new Internet economy, the penalties for an operating failure are severe. As a result, technical experts are being given greater control of lease negotiations than in the past, observed Jeffrey Bernstein, a managing director of Insignia/ESG, the real estate services company.
"About two years ago I began to notice that the deals were driven by the technical guys, not the financial guys, " said Mr. Bernstein, who has specialized in telecommunications leases.
"These companies absolutely do not want to go dark, and so they rely on cautious engineers," he said. "You find yourself in a conference room with three technical guys across the table negotiating a lease." Knowing they will be blamed if the system crashes makes the engineers all the more careful, he said.
The emphasis on reliability has also led tenants to insist on more control of their own spaces. In the past, tenants shared the electrical and mechanical systems installed by a landlord in a building. Today, telecommunications companies want their own generators, cooling systems, fuel tanks and pumping systems independent of other tenants and the landlord.
Indeed, one of the marketing points for a new telecommunications building on 57th Street between 11th and 12th Avenues proposed by the Durst Organization is that it will have multiple risers -- vertical shafts that rise through the building -- and that tenants will have independent access to the risers without having to go through another tenant's space. And telecommunications companies want to do the work themselves, not being willing to allow a landlord to do anything that might compromise their reliability and independence. "In the early telecom deals, the landlords did the work and not everybody was happy," Mr. Bernstein said. "Now the tenants do the work, which is a big change. In the old days, the landlords would never let a tenant anywhere near a riser or anything vertical."
The new building proposed by the Dursts is an indication of how the needs of high-tech tenants are changing the way buildings are being designed. Instead of uniform floors, the structure is to be replete with special zones. There is a mechanical equipment zone on each floor and a roof equipment zone at the top of the six-story building. Inside there are multiple riser shafts to distribute electrical power, telecommunications cable, fuel oil and coolant from the basement to the upper floors.
The zones are being designed into the building to support the tenants the Dursts are hoping to attract, which are primarily machines and only incidentally people. Named the NYCyberCenter, the building is intended to house the powerful computers and switching equipment that are essential to the growth of commerce on the World Wide Web.
"This is a new type of building, like 4 Times Square," said Douglas Durst, the president of the Durst Organization, referring to the Conde Nast building on Broadway between 42nd and 43rd Streets. While the office building was designed to be environmentally correct and includes two fuel cells to provide independent electrical power, the Cybercenter is being designed for e-commerce.
"Web hosting is a high margin business," said Robert Stella, a senior vice president of CB Richard Ellis, the real estate services firm representing the Dursts on the 57th Street project, "and it is linked to the growth of business-to-business and that is what this building is intended for."
"These companies expect to be billing $1 million a minute when they are operating," or more than $500 billion a year, said Richard A. Romm, a senior principal in SCR Design Organization, citing a commonly used estimate of the industry's potential revenues. . "That is a lot of money."
When older buildings are modified to host telecommunications and Web hosting companies, the requirements are usually similar: multiple sources of electrical and communications cables to lower the chance of an interruption in service. And, even though Consolidated Edison is one of the most reliable utilities in the country because its cables are buried underground rather than hanging overhead, most installations include batteries and generators as additional backups.
"These guys want a belt and suspender, and then they add more belts," one real estate executive commented.
The electrical demands of the densely packed ranks of telecommunications equipment means that landlords are being forced to provide power in amounts scarcely contemplated just a few years ago. Durst has said its new building will be equipped to deliver 100 watts of power per square foot, compared with 5 or 7 seven watts per square foot in a typical new office building.
More power means more heat, which means these buildings will have to be cooled even on the coldest day in winter. Last weekend, at another "telecom hotel," cooling towers were lifted for installation on the roof and setbacks of the old AT&T building at 32 Avenue of the Americas, just south of Canal Street. One floor of the building, the 15th, has been reinforced and modified to house diesel-powered generators that will be used to keep the telecommunications companies that are moving into the space given up by AT&T in operation if something happens to public utilities.
"These are 24/7 businesses, 365 days a year," said John J. Gilbert, chief operating officer for Rudin Management, which owns and manages the building, using the current term for around-the-clock operations. Indeed, this invasion of technology is prompting the use of terms not previously common in real estate circles. He said the telecommunications companies are seeking "five nines" reliability, which means that they are trying to find ways to be in operation 99.999 percent of the time.
ANOTHER term being used is "N plus one systems." This means if a tenant needs three generators to sustain operations in the event of a power failure, it should install four, the amount needed plus one. "The idea is that you can keep running even if there is a failure in your own system, in addition to electrical grid," said Richard T. Kennedy, a senior director of Cushman & Wakefield, a real estate services company.
"If you need three generators, install four, if you need three cooling towers, install four," he said. "That way if the power goes out, and you have to take one of your own units off line for maintenance, you can still keep operating."
Some companies have gone beyond "N plus one" to what is called a "2 N system" where the backup system is itself completely backed up. "Some installations have put in two complete systems, each capable of handling the load," said Julius Bogad, a partner at Jaros, Baum & Bolles, a consulting engineering firm.
Mr. Kennedy is representing Bush Terminal, a five million square foot collection of 12 multifloor warehouses on the Brooklyn waterfront. The owner, Industry City Associates, is seeking to transform two of the buildings into a telecommunications center. Plans call for the installation of backup generators on the space behind the buildings where railroad lines once brought cargo from the docks to the city.
Putting the generators outside on platforms, instead of on a special floor in a building or on the roof, takes advantage of something that is more available in Brooklyn than Manhattan: open space. "There is no land area in Manhattan," said Bruce B. Federman, a partner in Industry City Associates. "We have the land, so we can be more flexible." Using outside space avoids the expense of preparing a floor inside for the heavy, vibrating machines, and there is also no need to replace windows with louvers to secure an air supply for the diesel engines that run the machines and piping to vent the exhaust outside.
Other telecommunications projects in New York include a building at 85 10th Avenue at 15th Street, which is being adapted for Level 3 Communications, and 636 11th Avenue at 46th Street, which is to be occupied by Global Crossing Ltd. Another is a former tire parts factory at 470 Vanderbilt Avenue in Brooklyn, which is being developed for multiple tenants by the Carlyle Group of Washington, D.C.
Another center is the old Western Union Building at 60 Hudson Street, between Worth and Thomas Streets in TriBeCa. This was one of the first buildings in Manhattan to be converted to house modern communications equipment, and brokers say some of the decisions made there offer a guide for subsequent conversions.
"Not everybody has space to install generators, but the need to be in the building to interconnect with other companies is so great that some tenants are willing to sacrifice reliability," said John Peters, a former broker with Cushman & Wakefield, who now operates Technology Real Estate. He said landlords now establish master plans for buildings to ensure that all tenants have equal access to space for installation of generators, coolers, antennas and fuel tanks.
Telecommunications companies are choosing old industrial buildings today because of their ability to carry heavy loads and other practical considerations, rather than the prestige of the address. Mr. Stella of CB Richard Ellis said this reflects the maturity of the industry. "Eight or nine years ago these companies wanted to be in Class A or B buildings to give the impression they were established," he said. "But today it does not make any sense to pay $80 or $90 a square foot to house equipment."
Brokers say space in Manhattan for telecommunications installations ranges from the mid to high $40's per square foot annually, with space in other boroughs and suburbs renting for about half that amount.
One of the early tenants at Bush Terminal is Winstar Wireless, a long distance carrier. Algis Butkus, the company's senior manager for construction, said the systems being installed now at telecommunications centers are an extension of the backups that kept voice systems working during power failures.
"With the voice system we had batteries as a backup, and we never lost telephone service," he said. "Now we are taking it farther with the additional cooling and generators. You don't want all your eggs in one basket."
Implicit in the emphasis on redundant power supplies and backup systems is a skepticism that the deregulated electrical industry will be able to supply all the power the companies will need on a reliable basis. But at the same time, the companies are pushing the utilities to install equipment to supply power well in excess of their present needs. This is particularly true in New York, where the companies fear Con Ed will not be able to handle the full load, particularly during a hot summer.
Although Con Ed has sold many of its generating plants under the terms of deregulation, it is still responsible for delivering power and there are physical limits on how much power it can buy outside the region and transmit into the city.
"Obtaining electrical capacity is difficult, particularly in New York City," Mr. Bogad said. "So the companies overstate their requirements, so they will have it if they ever need it." He said the companies say new generations of equipment are physically smaller than earlier gear, so more can be crammed into the same space. This increases the need for power to operate the equipment and more power for cooling to keep temperatures low enough that the equipment will not be damaged.
Mr. Bogad said he had not seen an installation that required more than 30 watts per square foot. But the Dursts want 100 watts per square foot and say Con Ed has agreed to supply it.
THAT poses a problem for any utility. The utility makes the capital expenditure to install the distribution equipment and recovers its investment as the user buys electricity. But if it installs gear to supply 100 watts per square foot and the user demands only 20 or 25 watts per foot, it is not receiving payment on all of its invested capital.
Mr. Bogad said utilities would sometimes agree to install capacity well in excess of a user's likely need if the user is willing to make payments above the cost of purchased electricity. And, he said, many of the telecommunications companies are willing to pay. "Time is important to these companies, and when they need the capacity, they want it there in a hurry," he said. "With the revenues they are anticipating, they are willing to pay for reserve capacity."
A Con Ed spokesman said the utility is willing to provide the extra electrical capacity, as long as customers are prepared to pay for the cost of the extra equipment and maintenance.
Telecommunications companies can be difficult neighbors in a crowded city. Residents of TriBeCa have complained that the noises from the equipment operating at 60 Hudson have disturbed the neighborhood.
Durst executives say their neighbors on the far west side of Manhattan are less likely to be disturbed, because most are business or industrial, rather then residential.Current plans call for placing all the louvers on the 58th Street side of the building, where there is a block square Con Ed plant. The sites at both ends of the block are to be developed in later phases, perhaps as office buildings, since that is the Durst specialty.
The zones in the telecommunications building are designed to accommodate auxiliary equipment like generators, coolers and batteries. The mechanical equipment zone will have a load bearing capacity of 250 pounds per square foot, compared with 150 pounds a square foot for the rest of the structure and less than 100 pounds per square foot for a standard office building.
In recognition that telecommunications companies often hang cables from the ceiling for ready access, the floors will also be capable of sustaining a hanging load of 100 pounds per square foot. The roof equipment zone will be reinforced to carry 250 pounds per square foot for tenants' communications, electrical and mechanical equipment.
The lower level will be available for tanks to store fuel and coolant. It will also have parking for 100 vehicles, most likely to service tenants' wiring networks.
Robert Fox, a senior principal of Fox & Fowle, the architects of the NYCyberCenter, said designing a new building is easier than adapting an existing one to the needs of telecommunications companies. "These companies are talking about millions of dollars a minute; they cannot afford to go down," he said. "They need something better than the best."

HEADLINE: POLITICS;
Bills. Thrills. Spills.

BYLINE: By STEVE STRUNSKY

 BODY:
Governor Whitman has never surfed 40-foot waves or parachuted thousands of feet off a radio tower. At least, if she did, she never issued a press release on it.
But in this era of all things extreme, the 53-year-old mother of two is about as fit -- and fitting -- a chief executive as there is when it comes to getting out on the ski slopes or mountain bike trails or basketball courts or on horseback. And getting banged up in the process. 
 While her well-publicized injuries have undoubtedly been painful -- like the chipped finger bone and torn lip she got in a biking accident in California last weekend -- they have not hurt her politically.
"Certainly, it makes her seem more real," said Matt Stark, 27, of Jersey City, the manager of the New Jersey Rock Gym in Fairfield, where working stiffs can loosen up and release tension by climbing a man-made boulder. "She's going out having a good time. She's not sitting in her office stressed out, worrying about what bills are floating around in front of her nose. It's nice to know that she can kick back and relax."
The governor was trying to get in some last-minute fun while on vacation in California's Napa Valley last Sunday before flying back to New Jersey, when she was riding a rented mountain bike down a steep paved road. As she told a group of reporters on Monday at the State House, who could not help but notice the cast on her right middle finger and the six stitches in her upper lip, she was trying to stay ahead of a driver who was bearing down on her on the single-lane road when she went off the road's edge.
With that, Mrs. Whitman did what Generation X refers to as a face plant on the hard ground. The blood-and-guts governor said she got right back up and pedaled to the rental shop to return the bike, got stitched up and caught her flight.
"I wanted to get that last ride in before getting on the plane," Mrs. Whitman told reporters. "If you don't bring back some real blood, it's not a real vacation."
Apparently so.
While in Davos, Switzerland, with the likes of Bill Gates and Bill Clinton in 1999 for the annual World Economic Forum, Mrs. Whitman broke her leg when she took some time to hit the ski slopes. But the governor was back at work soon afterward with metal pins in her leg.
There was also her rotator cuff surgery in 1996. After a year of physical therapy, the governor was still missing the plate with her curveball, and her fastball had lost a lot of its movement and velocity. Or maybe it was simply that her right shoulder was in pain. In any event, she ultimately resorted to surgery to repair the rotator cuff in her right shoulder, an operation much more common among people who sign their name on baseballs than on legislation.
Eager to get back in the game, the governor left the hospital an hour after the procedure.
And perhaps like so many backroom deals in the name of open space or income tax cuts, there may be countless scrapes and bruises that have never come under public scrutiny.
Laura Otterbourg, a spokeswoman for Mrs. Whitman, said the governor had been active all her life, whether riding horses while growing up in Somerset County or playing basketball with her State Police bodyguards. Ms. Otterbourg said the governor did not believe she was taking unreasonable risks with her health, safety or the stewardship of the state.
To try to glean any insight into the governor's political behavior through the lens of her athletic pursuits -- could her bold 1993 campaign pledge to cut income taxes 30 percent and her high-speed Napa Valley descent be rooted in the same compulsion to take risks? -- is to indulge in so much psychobabble, Ms. Otterbourg insisted.
"I believe she is a good role model for residents of all ages from New Jersey, and none of her injuries have ever kept her from doing her job," she said. "She's always been physically active, whether it's horseback riding, bike riding, hiking, working on the farm. She wouldn't say she's a risk taker, she's physically active. She makes well thought-out decisions and being physically active has nothing to do with this process."
Whatever it may relate to, her physical activity is far from unique among elected officials. Athleticism and physical fitness has long been a valued part of a politician's image, and officials from John F. Kennedy to Franklin D. Roosevelt have gone to great lengths to conceal their frailties.
Among current governors with a sporting image, 47-year-old Gary Johnson of New Mexico was the first chief executive to compete in Hawaii's Ironman Triathlon, according to the National Governors Association. Gov. Pedro Rossello of Puerto Rico, 56, is an avid tennis player who has won five men's singles championships on the island. Gov. Mike Leavitt of Utah, is, naturally, a skier. And Gov. Jesse "The Body" Ventura of Minneota was a professional wrestler for 11 years.
Closer to home, the two Republicans most likely to vie for Mrs. Whitman's seat next year -- Senate President Donald T. DiFrancesco and Assembly Speaker Jack Collins -- are both avid golfers (How about a sudden-death playoff instead of a primary?).
James W. Hughes, dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University, agreed with Mr. Stark, the gym manager, that Mrs. Whitman's athleticism is most likely good for her image.
"Her sports activities and the like probably really helped to humanize her, because she does come from a wealthy background in the Somerset hills, so the fact that she can fall off a bike or injure herself playing basketball with state troopers or have a skiing accident, probably humanizes her," said Professor Hughes, himself a jogger. "It probably resonates well with other maturing baby boomers who at this stage in their life are experiencing similar mishaps."
As for when the governor would climb back on a mountain bike, Ms. Otterbourg said: "I would imagine soon. She loves bike riding, and it's not going to keep her off."

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY & CO.;
In the Paperless Era, the Problem Is Too Much Paper

BYLINE: By MARGO NASH

DATELINE: NEW BRUNSWICK

 BODY:
All of his clients old economy or new, law firms or tech firms, hospitals and colleges or cellular phone companies -- have the same problem: Paper.
That is where Leon Kroll, chief executive of Archives Management Inc. here, comes in. 
 "They all think that their paper is unique," Mr. Kroll said recently. "My paper? I need my paper. I want my paper. I love my paper. Every lawyer thinks that his file is more important than all the other files in the world, that no one else has this problem. No one else has this problem? I'm in business because you all have this problem."
In this paperless economy -- in which nearly everything is stored on a computer disc and backed up on another -- storing paper records is a billion-dollar business.
For years, Pierce Leahy and Iron Mountain Inc. slugged it out for control of this country's business records. Last year, Iron Mountain acquired Pierce Leahy for $515 million in stock, and now it controls 40 percent of the market. The rest is divided among smaller regional companies like Archives Management, an 11-year-old company whose remarkable 35 percent a year growth is indicative of the nascent market.
In the records management business, one talks boxes. Eleven years ago, Archives Management had no boxes. Now it has 600,000. The company has five trucks on the road picking up yet more boxes -- 30 employees in all, 150,000 square feet of storage space and a new warehouse that will allow the company to store a half-million more boxes for clients who come from around the state as well as Manhattan and eastern Pennsylvania.
Men with scanners traverse the catwalks along the 22-foot-high shelves that seem to go on endlessly in all directions. Each box has a bar code and inside each box the files are catalogued.
Rob Kroll, Leon Kroll's son, and the company's manager of information systems and technology, says some customers are even beginning to ask Archives Management to help them manage the files in their offices as well.
"Leon and his son came in last month and showed us how we can capture control of our entire filing system," said Joseph Berger, executive director of Norris, McLaughlin & Marcus, a law firm in Somerville with offices in Westchester and Manhattan.
Mr. Berger said that when attorneys get busy, it is easy for files get misplaced "and we lose a lot of valuable time looking for them. So we have looked at Leons' system and are in the early stages of incorporating it in how we do business here."
Still, for what most companies would consider a modest fee, records centers provide secure, vermin-free, climate-controlled and smoke-sensored space. Moreover, commercial records centers provide high-tech indexing, retrieval and rapid delivery.
At Archives Management, a file can be retrieved within three minutes of a request 24 hours a day and can be faxed or delivered in hours. The company also provides electronic data protection and vault storage.
"Archives Management has become like a second filing area for us," said Robert Pinto, files and supplies supervisor at Greenbaum, Rowe, Smith, Ravin, Davis & Himmel, a law firm in Woodbridge. "They have it all computerized. We can find everything we want. We fax them every day with requests."
The 60-year-old Mr. Kroll used to be in the garment business with his father, manufacturing children's outerware, but when they closed they were left with an empty factory. Some friends asked if they could store business records at the vacant building, and soon he and his friends began learning about records management.
"Someone suggested there was a guy in Georgia who did this," he said. "We all went to Georgia, and we met this guy and he had a building that looked like a fortress, and he took us around the building and he had boxes. It was the first I had ever seen of this. I said, 'How many boxes you got?' He had about 3 million. He said, 'I get $3 dollars a box.' The next day I went into business."
Later he bought out his friends.
Mr. Kroll recruited his first clients at a New Jersey Bar Association meeting in Atlantic City in 1989 -- even though his father warned him that there was not enough paper in the world to make a business out of storing it.
But father doesn't always know best. John Ford, managing director of the equity research group at Bear Stearns & Company Inc., says storing and managing business records is a $2 billion-a-year business in the United States.
Clients buy boxes and rent space per box. A standard box costs $1.75 and about $3.25 a year to store. There is a modest fee for each retrieval and delivery, but there are a lot of retrievals and deliveries. Some company's require 12,000 a month. Companies may begin with a small amount of boxes, but sooner or later, with mergers, acquisitions, laser printers, E-mail and faxes, the boxes multiply exponentially.
"We used to do records storage ourselves," said Georgine Welch, director of materials management at Bayshore Community Hospital in Holmdel. "We would lease a warehouse. We tried to run it with our existing staff. It was just a nightmare trying to keep the inventory straight, not to mention it cost a fortune between leasing and personnel resources. So we contracted."
As Dr. dt ogilvie, associate professor of strategic management at Rutgers University School of Business, put it: "If you are going to keep your documents on-site, as time goes on you're going to have more space devoted to your documents than to your business. Commercial storage companies do it more efficiently, cheaply and give you better service."
Mr. Kroll scoffs at the notion that paper is disappearing. "Just look at lawyers," he says. "Their main product is paper."
Even the technology companies store a lot of paper, he added.
"There's more paper now than there ever, Dr. ogilvie noted. "We do more diverse things, make duplicates of E-mail messages. And because this is a more litigious environment, people want to document everything and there are legal requirements stipulating how long different types of documents must be saved."
Convincing potential customers that it is cost-effective to store their records with his company has not been hard, said Mr. Kroll, and he explained it this way:
"I go to a law firm. They say to me, No problem. We have it covered. How do you have it covered? We have it stored at the local mini-warehouse down on Route 22. I say to the lawyer, Excuse me, who is in charge of that? They say, Oh Sara. She sits in the front and the key is in her drawer. So when you need something you tell Sara? How much do you pay her $15 an hour? She drives in her car, gets there and the box she needs is on the bottom and now she has to drive back to get you? And she schleps you back to get the boxes and how long did that take? About two hours? And how much do you get paid? Two hundred dollars an hour? Four hundred dollars? I'm going to do it for $1.75."
Mr. Kroll remembers what it was like to try sell children's outerwear to buyers. "They want the button here, you got the button there," he remembered. "They want the blue, you got the red."
Convincing someone to store their records, he said, "is easy compared to selling a snowsuit to a buyer at J. C. Penny's."

HEADLINE: N.J. LAW;
Four Prisons and Counting

BYLINE: By LAURA MANSNERUS

DATELINE: LEESBURG

 BODY:
Needing a place to lock up dangerous offenders, the New Jersey Department of Corrections decided this month to take the well-worn path to Cumberland County, already the home of four prisons, more than 8,000 inmates and the recession-proof growth industry they have brought to the far reaches of South Jersey.
But the men to be sent here are not the usual burglars and drug dealers; they are sex offenders ordered committed by the courts after serving their prison terms. And what looked like the path of least resistance has led to fierce resistance as county leaders and state legislators promise to fight the agreement by Maurice River Township to take this group. 
 "This is basically economic profiling," said Freeholder Director Douglas Fisher. He noted that several years ago the state tried to put a nuclear waste dump in Fairfield, the poorest township in the state's poorest county, and has now turned to Maurice River, barely better off, as its "dumping ground for violent sexual predators."
The township already has two state prisons, Bayside and Southern State, on a 13,000-acre tract of marsh, forest and cornfields along Route 47. The new 300-bed institution is to be built on the Bayside grounds, though the exact site has not been fixed.
Prisons -- which account for 1.7 percent of the state's population and about a quarter of the Department of Corrections' population -- are the biggest business in the county. A total of about 5,000 people work at Bayside and Southern State, as well as the new South Woods State Prison in Bridgeton and the Fairton Federal Correctional Institution in Fairfield Township. Among them is Maurice River Township's mayor, Ronald D. Riggins Sr., a sergeant at Southern State.
The Department of Corrections had planned to build in Woodbridge, which challenged the proposed facility in court, choosing Maurice River instead a few weeks ago. Mr. Fisher said the decision caught county officials by surprise. He said Jack Terhune, the corrections commissioner, assured him last year that "he would not push to locate it here."
Through a spokesman, Chris Carden, the commissioner declined to comment. Mr. Carden would only say, "We're going forward with the site at Bayside.'
Mr. Fisher has asked the governor for a moratorium on prison construction in the county, and three other freeholders are planning hearings next month. Assemblyman Nicholas Asselta and Senator James Cafiero have protested, along with officials in Vineland, Millville and Dennis Township.
"There's no one in favor of this," Mr. Fisher said.
All of them are trying to overturn the vote of the three-member township committee on Aug. 17 unanimously adopting a resolution to accept the new unit in exchange for a payment of $825,000 a year by the state. The township's current budget is $3.6 million, of which $300,000 comes from state payments for Bayside and Southern State.
Mr. Fisher said he was not unsympathetic to the township committee, which he said was apparently bullied by the state. And Freeholder Louis Magazzu, who is calling for hearings, said he wanted to look at "what is driving the need for Morris River Township to be open to this."
The reason, Mr. Magazzu said, was fiscal desperation, in part because the state did not give Maurice River Township payments comparable to those it gave Camden and Bridgeton -- each $1 million -- for the two prisons it already has.
Deputy Mayor Andrew Sarclette said the concern from freeholders and state legislators was a bit late. "We have been fighting for more money for years, and our school situation is atrocious," Mr. Sarclette said. "Where were they then?"
He said that while they publicly urged a halt to the plan, none of the state and county officials had even placed a call to Maurice River Township. "That's what discourages me most," he said.
Mr. Sarclette said that the resolution was simply a statement of support and that the committee members had not made any deal with the state. Still, he made clear that they were ready to sign an agreement.
"There's no way we can ever get these kinds of ratables", he said. "A few people I've talked to tell me they're not thrilled about sex offenders, but the majority I speak with will take the money."
Residents acknowledge that the state payments and salaries -- corrections officers, for example, earn $36,100 to $55,300 a year -- are keeping Maurice River Township afloat.
As she checked out at Lillians Produce Market, a few miles up the road from the prisons, Gladys Holmes, a 77-year-old lifetime resident of the township, noted that there were prison employees in all four houses across the street from hers. "They do have good benefits and good pay," Ms. Holmes said. "I just wish they hadn't started the whole thing."
Behind the counter, Kathy Giles nodded in agreement. "They used to have the canning houses and clamming and oystering here," Ms. Giles said. "But they're gone, and a lot of people who aren't skilled are stuck with whatever they can get."
The owner of the market, Pat Buganski, volunteered that she grew up on the farm across the street from the prison dairy, a minimum-security unit, where the inmates "weren't too scary."
But Ms. Buganski also said that after Bayside was built in 1969, "Mom said, 'There won't be murderers. There won't be sex offenders.' "
Bayside and Southern State, primarily medium-security prisons, have housed some sex offenders, but the state has never had a unit like the one to be built here.
Nothing like it existed when the ominously named Sexually Violent Predator Act was passed in 1998. Enacted four years after Megan's law, it changed the standard for the civil commitment of sex offenders who had served their terms but were deemed too violent to be released. The law also required that the corrections department and Department of Human Services establish a new class of institution for such offenders, who had previously been confined in state psychiatric hospitals.
About 150 men are expected at what is now called the Special Treatment Unit, while those who are most seriously mentally ill will continue to go to the state forensic hospital in Trenton.
Mr. Carden said that security measures for the new unit were still under discussion but that the department could not apply its usual classifications to people held under civil rather than criminal law.
James Goff, the president of the Patrolmens Benevolent Association Local 105, which represents corrections officers, said the Department of Corrections was retreating from a pledge it made to Woodbridge to build a maximum-custody facility. He also said the township committee failed to make clear to residents that it would house inmates who had committed violent crimes.
"The more politically pleasing term is civilly committed offender," Mr. Goff said. "But basically, they're warehousing people too violent to be returned to society.
"The lackadaisical attitude of the department is, 'We got a lot of flak in North Jersey, so well shove it in South Jersey,' " he added. "And they're going to downgrade the level of security."
Especially after the example of Raymond Alves, the rapist who was prematurely and improperly released from Southern State in March, many residents are nervous about security beyond the state's control.
Ms. Giles said some prisoners stay in the area after their release, and she said "a lot of people in the community worry" that sex offenders will be even more inclined to do so. "Lets face it," she said. "They have a hard time going back to where they came from."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 4; Column 6; Money and Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 773 words

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW;
Home-Grown Innovation, Home-Grown Workers

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR

 BODY:
THE chronic problem of the nation's high-technology labor force? Simple: There isn't enough of it.
The shortage of technology workers explains one of Washington's annual rituals. Silicon Valley executives warn Congress that unless private industry is allowed to hire more skilled foreign workers, growth in the new economy will sputter for lack of able minds. Organized labor complains, but to little effect. The industry typically prevails, reasonably, because the problem is a real one -- and the visa quotas for skilled immigrants are raised once more. 
 Nothing is more American than immigration. Yet the persistent shortage of home-grown technology workers to fill these high-skill, high-wage jobs does suggest that something is amiss in the labor market. Why isn't the supply of graduates from the nation's universities adjusting faster to meet the demand? What policy steps can help solve the problem?
Those questions are the focus of a recent paper by Paul M. Romer, an economist at the Stanford Business School, prepared for the National Bureau of Economic Research. Mr. Romer is a pioneering thinker behind a set of ideas called new growth theory.
Put simply, new growth theory emphasizes the economic role of innovation. And innovation, according to Mr. Romer, is the X-factor in an economy, the elixir of sustained growth. So the goal of policy, he says, should be to foster innovation.
The right kinds of institutions are essential, he wrote in his paper, but "unfortunately, in the last 20 years, innovation policy in the United States has almost entirely ignored the structure of our institutions of higher learning."
In an interview, he explained that any policy analysis has to "get deeply into the details of how those institutions work."
In the university system, he sees a marketplace sorely in need of new and different incentives if it is ever to help erase the shortage of skilled workers in technology fields. He said he believes that there is a role for government to play in overhauling those incentives.
Too often, according to Mr. Romer, government programs intended to encourage scientific research have simply handed money or tax breaks to universities and companies -- which mainly increases the demand for scientists and engineers without doing anything for the supply.
"The crucial input," he said, "is to have more well-trained people who are engaged in innovative activities."
He would spend the money differently. At the undergraduate level, he recommends paying schools a bounty for increasing the number of graduates who receive science or engineering degrees -- $10,000 a head. This would reward liberal-arts schools, whose student populations tend to run heavy with English, history and social science majors, with an incentive to expand science and engineering programs.
At the graduate level, Mr. Romer sees different dimensions of the problem and suggests a different kind of supply-side subsidy. Increasingly, he said, research grants go to star professors, who then support graduate students as their research assistants. This system, he says, delivers some real benefits in basic research, but it nurtures an academic research culture instead of one that responds well to the needs of commerce.
THE Romer solution is to liberate graduate science and engineering students from dependence on money trickling down from professors; instead, he would have the government underwrite three-year fellowships with $20,000 annual stipends for nearly 17,000 students a year to pursue advanced degrees.
The two programs would combine to subsidize the right thing -- turning out more qualified people -- while giving more power to individuals and innovative institutions to decide how resources are used, Mr. Romer argues, adding that this approach sidesteps political problems. "It avoids the issues of pork-barrel science, giving money to politically favored constituents, and it also avoids the pitfall of having the government try to pick technology winners and losers," he said.
The price tag? For 100,000 additional undergraduate degrees, $1 billion a year, and another $1 billion for the graduate fellowships.
Justifying the spending, he said, would be the "social return" -- improved prospects for higher growth over the next 20 to 50 years, as more people engage in innovative activity.
In his paper, Mr. Romer cited a comparable policy that proved a winner: creation of a new academic discipline, computer science, in the 1960's. "Even now," he wrote, "with the passage of 40 years, our sense of the magnitude of the payoff from this investment is still growing."

SECTION: Section 12; Page 1; Column 1; Automobiles

LENGTH: 988 words

HEADLINE: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Toyota Avalon XLS;
How Do You Say 'LeSabre' in Japanese?

BYLINE: By LEONARD M. APCAR

 BODY:
IN the 1970's, Japan's automakers made a name for themselves in the United States with small cars that were reasonably priced, economical to own and fun to drive. Detroit sold small cars in those days -- Chevy Vega owners, please stand up -- but its heart wasn't really in it.
But whenever Toyota, Nissan, Honda or even Mazda tried to beat the Big Three at their game -- building trucks or big family cars -- they usually fell flat. There aren't many fan clubs or newsletters for enthusiasts of the Toyota Cressida. 
 Then, five years ago, Toyota brought out the Avalon, a made-in-America family sedan aimed right at the business that Buick, Chrysler and Oldsmobile had owned for years. Based on the ever-popular Camry, the Avalon was a smooth-riding, well-padded cruiser that was long on quality although a little short on flash. It looked like a fancier Camry, which itself had styling that was far from the cutting edge.
Car buffs dismissed the Avalon as a Japanese Buick. But today, even Toyota executives use that description as shorthand for what the car is about: easy-riding, mid-
range luxury for buyers in their mid-50's, which is considerably younger than the average Buick customer.
Buick, by the way, has also transcended its reputation. Last year, when I tested the redesigned LeSabre with an optional touring suspension, I was surprised by the car's relatively crisp handling and taut road manners. Taut? Crisp? These are not words one used to associate with Buicks.
So how does the Avalon measure up against the LeSabre? Pretty well, actually.
For the 2000 model, just about every visible element of the Avalon was changed. It is wider and taller to give it greater stature and more room inside. To add space, the dashboard was moved forward several inches and the rear seat was set back a tad. The result is a cabin built for stretching out.
One of the most noticeable changes inside is a Buck Rogers dashboard with a large, back-lighted liquid-crystal display showing the date, time, compass reading and outside temperature. The display is eye-catching, with amber lettering on a cool blue-green background, but it is so large and distracting that it is hard to get used to.
The interior redesign results in more headroom, and in significantly more legroom in the rear. Since the Avalon is now wider, and there is little dead space between the doors and the seats, it is not a stretch to call this a six-passenger car when it is equipped with a front bench seat. In no car, including this one, is the middle seating position comfortable for long, but the room is there to put three adults abreast in front and rear. There are three adjustable headrests in the back along with three shoulder belts.
All this interior decorating has produced an exterior design that is, at first, jarring. The idea was to make the Avalon look a lot different from the Camry, and it does. But it also comes off looking a little dated in some ways, a little heavy and oafish in others. The body seems high and disjointed, as if it was designed by committee.
The Avalon's flat sides hark back to the sheet-metal slabs that Mercedes has scrapped on its biggest cars. The fixed windows behind the rear doors serve as reminders of the opera-window craze of the 70's. And behind the sizable trunk, the tailights attempt to mimic Mercedes but miss badly with oddly positioned backup lights that detract from the otherwise simple design.
But if prospective buyers find the Avalon's look ungainly, it is not keeping them out of showrooms. Although the car is at the high end of its price bracket, with a base price of $26,300 and fully dressed XLS sedans exceeding $34,000, sales are up a whopping 90 percent from 1999. Business is so good that Toyota has increased production at its plant in Georgetown, Ky., where the Camry is also made. Clearly, many shoppers think the Avalon is worth its $4,000 premium over a comparable Camry.
On the road, the Avalon is quiet and competent, just what you'd expect from Toyota. Outside noise is pretty well muted, as are the bumps and ripples of the road. Braking is superbly confident, and while there was some minor hesitation in acceleration it was insignificant. The four-speed automatic transmission was virtually seamless.
The Avalon executed corners well for a front-drive car of its bulk, and while it backed away a bit in some twists of the road -- leaning a little here and there -- it fared better than most sedans in its category.
In a matchup with the LeSabre, I would give the Avalon a slight edge. The ride is smooth and the handling is impressive, with no hint of sloth. But a fully equipped LeSabre costs several thousand dollars less than a loaded Avalon, and Buick currently offers a $1,500 rebate, to boot.
I was disappointed that the Avalon's 3-liter, 24-valve V-6 requires pricey 91-octane gasoline, particularly since the power plant is quite similar to the regular-gas engine of the Camry. The chief difference is that the Avalon V-6 has sophisticated variable valve timing, which raises the horsepower to 210 from 194. The good news is that the fuel-economy rating ranges from 21 m.p.g. in the city to 29 on the highway.
The 2000-model test car came with some annoyances that were surprising, given its $34,033 window sticker. For one, while there were lots of thoughtful interior touches, like covered storage bins in the doors, reading lamps and power outlets, the power-window switches were not lighted at night. There were also inexcusable rattles, some from the pull-down compartments in the doors. Every time you closed the door or hit a bump the items inside jingle-jangled.
There were also rattles in the front cup holders -- particularly surprising given that their lids, and the glovebox door, are dampened to glide open slowly and softly.
 
INSIDE TRACK: Middle-of-the-road Americana, as interpreted by Japan and executed in Kentucky.

SECTION: Section 14; Page 1; Column 2; The City Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 2540 words

HEADLINE: The Pursuit of Less

BYLINE: By CHRIS ERIKSON

 BODY:
AT dusk on a midsummer evening, not long after trading on Wall Street has closed for the day, nine people gather in a Greenwich Village living room to talk money. But this group speaks not of wringing more profits out of a bull market. They want to make do with less.
Money is also on the agenda in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, as half a dozen women of varying ages sit around a kitchen table, sipping tea and picking at fruit and cookies. The topic for tonight is community, and they ponder in particular this assertion: that the culture's raging materialism will go unchecked as long as people feel an absence of meaningful social ties. 
 Such groups, which have a growing audience in New York, share a dedication to voluntary simplicity, the national back-to-basics movement whose followers renounce consumerism in favor of stripped-down living. Seeing spiritual bankruptcy in an American Dream that equates success with possessions, they have deliberately decided to earn and spend less.
Asceticism isn't a groundbreaking concept, of course; as long as there have been possessions, there have been simplifiers, from Buddha to Thoreau. Nor is the current trend brand-new. With roots in environmentalism, it has been gathering steam for a decade in the Northwest, ground zero for voluntary simplicity.
Skepticism about the movement is not new, either. Critics dismiss it as budget-cutting dressed in New Age clothes, and even some adherents reject the ideological proselytizing that can accompany the practical advice.
But the movement has been on the rise in the last year in New York, a city virtually synonymous with conspicuous consumption and fast-track living. Last fall, a voluntary simplicity conference at the Open Center in SoHo drew more than 300 people for workshops with names like "Are We Possessed by Our Possessions?" and "Leading a Life of Integrity." This fall the School of Continuing Education and Professional Studies at New York University will offer a course on voluntary simplicity.
When an Upper West Sider named Mary Barknecht posted a few lines on a Web site called the Simple Living Network (www.slnet.com) in August 1999 in hopes of starting a voluntary simplicity discussion group, the response was overwhelming. She has since started 10 groups and has a waiting list of people eager to join new ones. Her e-mail list has grown to a couple of hundred names. "It has just snowballed," she said.
Of course, any movement trumpeting the virtues of austerity has a tough row to hoe in a city where earning and spending is something of a contact sport; where too much is never enough; where dinner for four at Alain Ducasse is nearly $1,500; and $150-a-head dinners are as common as pigeons in Central Park.
"You've got the belly of the beast right here," said Pat McDonald, a psychotherapist and career counselor who will teach the N.Y.U. course on simplicity. "More people than ever are into this, but New York is the last place you'd expect to find it."
Paul Wachtel, a clinical psychologist who lives and works in Greenwich Village and the author of "The Poverty of Affluence" (New Society, 1989), also senses growing disenchantment amid the current economic bonanza. Some of those who have not been swept up in a spending frenzy are repelled by what they see around them, he says. Others feel an emptiness no matter how many things they stockpile.
"When people are in the midst of what they think is the American Dream and their lives don't feel very good, that's when they can begin to question," Mr. Wachtel said. "And I hear it much more now than I did even five years ago."
WHEN it comes to downsizing, Mary Barknecht knows of what she speaks. Dressed neatly in a plain red cardigan and a white button-down shirt, her graying hair tied back in a ponytail and her face free of makeup, she projects an aura of contented calm. But there was a time when her life was very different. She once ran a court transcription business and spent much of the go-go 80's working round the clock.
"I was mentally and physically exhausted all the time, and I compensated for that by spending my money on the usual stuff," she said. "I had enough beautiful designer linens for a 10-bedroom house, and I lived in a studio apartment. At that point I realized something was a little out of sync."
So in the early 90's, she did an about-face. With a healthy nest egg, thanks to careful saving, she quit her job. Out went the designer linens, along with bags of shoes and boxes of knickknacks. She canceled her magazine subscriptions and put a stop to the catalogs that stuffed her mailbox. Beyond essentials, she says, she stopped buying. Last summer she bought a pair of sandals on sale, her first new shoes in five years.
Today she lives on $11,000 a year, most of which goes for rent and health insurance. Her other expenses total about $100 a month. Her Upper West Side apartment is airy and attractive, and at first glance it looks like the home of an average city dweller, but on further inspection it reveals itself as a laboratory of nonconsumption.
Take the kitchen: no microwave; no food processor; cloth towels substitute for paper. Cloth shopping bags hang on the doorknob, and a compost bucket sits next to the sink. Its contents go to a community garden. There are no commercial cleaning products. Ms. Barknecht scrubs her bathroom with baking soda and her copper pans with vinegar and salt.
For transportation she uses the subway and a secondhand bike. For entertainment, she goes to free concerts or volunteers as an usher to get free theater tickets.
Her dedication to dirt-cheap living might make her an object of pity to New Yorkers for whom $100 wouldn't cover a night out, but she says she has never been happier. In her late 40's, she does a lot of volunteer work, which increasingly involves promoting the simple life.
As well as simplicity circles, Ms. Barknecht runs groups on finance, the Greenwich Village one among them. They are called Your Money or Your Life groups, after the book by that name (Viking, 1992). Written by Joe Dominguez and Vicki Robin, a former stock analyst and his wife who moved to Seattle and downsized, the book offers a nine-step program to financial independence, advising participants to track their spending and to think of purchases in terms of the "life energy" expended to buy them.
At a recent meeting, members of the Village group, who are from their 20's to their 60's, set other goals: to meditate, watch less television, fight clutter. They also discussed the environmental damage caused by Central American coffee growers. (The solution: buy free-trade coffee.)
The word addiction surfaces several times, as when talk turns to the temptation to break out the credit cards.
"It's like when someone is quitting smoking, and they go walk around the block instead of having a cigarette," said Rachel Aydt, 28, a research editor for YM magazine, who attends the meetings with her fiance, Jim Burton, an actor and contractor. "You walk into a store and see something on sale, and you think, do I want this?"
If voluntary simplicity sounds vaguely like a 12-step program, it is a little like one, says Pat McDonald, a group member. Participants say they are quitting something that is hard to shake: a mind-set that measures people by what they own.
And if resisting that temptation is hard elsewhere, in New York it can be downright brutal.
"New York City is like one big shopping mall," Ms. McDonald said. "Wherever you go, you're faced with choices to buy this and buy that. It's all about consuming." One woman in the Carroll Gardens group spoke of having "an episode" at Macy's.
WHILE the concept of paring down is straightforward enough, in practice it can be complicated. Once past the basic tenet that less is more, a host of alternative practices enter the picture, from yogic breathing to vegetarianism to composting. The philosophy is not just to spend less but to be aware of the effects, environmental and otherwise, produced by choices.
Not everyone buys every principle. Ms. Aydt says the financial advice she gets from her group has helped her be conscious of money, but she doesn't always appreciate the political proselytizing.
"It's like you're given a list of ideologies to follow," she says. "I do find it alienating."
Some find the entire movement off-putting, sanctimonious or just silly. To James Twitchell, an English professor at the University of Florida at Gainesville who studies consumerism, the only thing new about voluntary simplicity is the extent to which the consumer disillusionment of middle-aged women has been exploited by publishers of self-help books. He chafes at the "victim language" adopted by the movement and what he calls the "medicalization of consumption, where you need help, namely the 12-step method, to wean yourself away from the habit."
As Mr. Twitchell notes, telling people how to downsize is a growth industry: a flock of groups are dedicated to spreading the simple life, and a growing pile of books touts its virtues. "I mean, to have to buy books to stop buying things, to have to attend meetings to stop buying things, to see yourself as a victim to stop buying things?" Mr. Twitchell said. "Good God, woman, just take your credit cards and rip them up."
Erin Oates, 42, a public relations executive in Manhattan, said she once "shopped with the best of them." But the simplicity message hit home a few years ago, around her 40th birthday. "I started reassessing what my life is all about, and I don't want it to just be about collecting things," she said. Her first foray into simpler living was to make a family pact to stop exchanging Christmas gifts. Then she moved into a smaller apartment, shedding a lot of stuff along the way. Now she carefully tracks her expenses and is still paying off credit card debt. She brings her lunch to work and dips into a box of Quaker Oats for breakfast instead of stopping at Au Bon Pain.
She has also stopped prowling clothing stores before every new season or social event. Keeping her wardrobe up to date "used to be a lot of what my life was about," she said, but now her formerly jammed closet contains only a few modest feet of hangers and eight or nine pairs of shoes.
As she gives a tour of her tidy, antiques-filled one-bedroom on the Upper West Side, Ms. Oates is dressed plainly but stylishly in a purple cotton blouse (marked down to $17 at Ann Taylor) and a black skirt (a recent splurge she justified because the skirt is all-season and doesn't need dry cleaning).
On her salary, she says, she can still afford her old way of life. But, she added: "I want to feel like I'm living more intelligently. It's a matter of slowing down and not feeling like a rat caught in a maze."
THE spike in interest in voluntary simplicity in New York mirrors a pattern in other cities. Betsy Taylor, executive director of the Center for a New American Dream, a nonprofit group in Maryland that promotes nonconsumerist choices, said hits on the center's Web site had risen from under 125,000 in 1997 to nearly 1 million in 1998 to more than 3 million for the first seven months of 2000.
During that time, simplicity has become a marketing buzzword, and the principle behind a pair of new monthly magazines, Time-Warner's Real Simple and Simply City, which published its third issue last month in New York. With fashion layouts and articles about spa etiquette and a Parisian water bar, Simply City promotes a citified vision. Its editor and publisher, Danielle Chang, says the goal is to strip simplicity of its New Age aura and make it "more accessible, less ascetic and more fun."
She said: "The people I've spoken to in New York say things like, 'I want to embrace simplicity, but that doesn't mean that I don't care about fashion. I like shopping, I like wearing makeup, I like all of the traps, so to speak, but that doesn't make me a hypocrite.' "
WHILE the contradiction of a glossy magazine packed with fashion as it promotes downsizing has hard-core simplifiers gritting their teeth, Ms. Taylor says that it still reflects a widespread desire to relax the pace of life. She says many parents are alarmed at the sway commercialization has over their children. In a recent poll by the center, 87 percent of parents said their offspring were too materialistic.
This is a concern for Vicki Madden and Jim Ebersole of Park Slope, Brooklyn, who are raising Ms. Madden's 8-year-old son, Jacob, and have a 3-week-old baby of their own, Samuel.
Ms. Madden, who teaches "very part time," and Mr. Ebersole, who works for a company that ships fine art, have a budget of $200 a week for food, transportation, entertainment and other expenses, not counting rent and insurance. They track their spending in minute detail, cracking down on casual expenditures, like a morning latte, that many take for granted.
Yet striving for simplicity in New York can be lonely. "You're definitely swimming against the tide," Ms. Madden said.
The philosophy can also complicate social life. Jean Thilmany, 33, who writes for writes for the trade publication Mechanical Engineering, says for her friends, a typical night out involves "spending $9 for a movie and then going out for an expensive dinner."
"I'm constantly trying to get out of dinner invitations," said Ms. Thilmany, who lives in a railroad flat in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, where country and jazz records clutter the shelves and a stacked pair of old suitcases serves as a coffee table. "I usually make an excuse, like that I'm having money problems. I don't feel comfortable telling people about it. I just feel like I have to get into a whole political thing that's not going to be appreciated."
Ms. Thilmany, a soft-spoken blond with pale features and a taste for prowling vintage clothing stores, came to voluntary simplicity after a disconcerting stint at a paper covering the retail industry, where she "started to become aware of how many ads there are, and all the ways one is manipulated to buy."
It's a particular issue in New York, she said, where ever-present billboards are much more intrusive than in her native Minneapolis.
Which leads to this question: Why live in New York at all if simplicity is what you're after? Isn't it a bit like moving to the hills of Montana to become a stockbroker?
The answer, simplifiers say, is that they live here for much the same reason as anyone else: the culture, the diversity, the creative energy. They say that inflated housing costs aside, New York is a great place to live cheaply. A car is unnecessary, and inexpensive ethnic restaurants abound, along with free concerts and art galleries.
Also, living in the shadow of big spenders has its benefits, like thrift shops where designer goods can be found with the tags still attached. There is plenty of free stuff for the taking, too.
Roger Kaufman, who used to run a graphic design business and now works as a home health care aide, said he had collected many a treasure discarded by fellow tenants at his Bay Ridge apartment building.
"I went from one TV to three," he said. "And I have cast iron and Pyrex cookware beyond belief."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 7; Column 3; Money and Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 768 words

HEADLINE: FIVE QUESTIONS for ELIZABETH WARREN;
Bankruptcy Borne of Misfortune, Not Excess

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON

 BODY:
A DECADE ago, in a widely praised analysis of bankruptcy filings, three scholars destroyed the myth that most of those seeking refuge from creditors were blue-collar workers. People in every occupation go bankrupt in rough proportion to their numbers, they found.
Now, in "The Fragile Middle Class" (Yale University Press, 2000), the same three writers -- Elizabeth Warren, Teresa A. Sullivan and Jay Lawrence Westbrook -- have refined their research and shown that behind most bankruptcy filings lies misfortune, not profligate living. 
 Ms. Warren, a Harvard Law School professor, says the findings suggest that the recent slight decline in bankruptcy filings nationwide is misleading. The next time the business cycle hits bottom, she said, many people who are now solidly employed may find themselves out of work with bankruptcy as their only recourse. Following are excerpts from a recent conversation.
 DAVID CAY JOHNSTON

Q. What did your latest analysis reveal about the finances of middle-class Americans?
 
A. The number of middle-class families declaring complete financial failure exploded from 313,000 in 1980 to 1,281,000 in 1999. And they were much deeper in debt. In 1981, these people owed nonmortgage debts equal to nine months of income, compared to more than 22 months in 1997.
 
Q. Don't people file for bankruptcy because they misused credit, lived beyond their means?
 
A. In the same way that dead bodies help pathologists understand illness in a living population, the people in bankruptcy help us learn about the economic risks facing families generally. Many people in bankruptcy were solid bill payers until something knocked their legs out from under them. For two-thirds of these people, it was loss of a job, for 40 percent it was a serious medical problem and for 20 percent it was the economic fallout of divorce.
Some were loaded up with debt already, but many others were swamped trying to survive joblessness, illness or divorce -- risks which all middle-class Americans face. The bankrupt debtors are the ones who didn't survive economically.
 
Q. You and your colleagues write that in the last two decades, government policies have shifted risks from capital to labor. What does that mean for families?
 
A. The American economy has benefited from agile companies that can quickly shed or add workers, often on a contract basis without fringe benefits such as health insurance. But this agility for companies brought vulnerability for workers, through interrupted employment and medical bills not covered by insurance.
The question we face as a society is how much of the economic risk of job loss and medical problems should be borne individually by each family and how much should be spread among everyone. The portion of families who are failing economically in this new environment has increased by fourfold over the past two decades, and we need to recognize that there is no free lunch, that the new policies that made companies agile also impose costs.
 
Q. You write that it makes sound economic sense to have a two-income family. Why?
 
A. Two incomes represent the only strategy most people have to spread the risk of unemployment or catastrophic medical bills. Our data show that if either spouse is unemployed, the chance that the family will be in bankruptcy skyrockets by about 320 percent. Following divorce, the chances of filing bankruptcy triple, and that risk falls again, statistically, only when a divorced woman remarries. The bankruptcy data show that a two-earner family is not a matter of choice, but of economic survival.
 
Q. So is there a way out of this through individual action or changes in government policy?
 
A. Bankruptcy is a solution invoked one at a time by families who have fallen through the social safety net. The next time the economy contracts we will see the disastrous effect of allowing 125 percent debt-consolidation mortgages and allowing lenders to charge rates of interest that were illegal just 20 years ago. Bankruptcies will explode and we will all pay the price for this folly.
Better unemployment insurance would help, and so would bankruptcy rules that let families survive and rebuild. If we are reluctant to close some of the holes in the social safety net for families, then we might be better off leaving the bankruptcy system alone.
As it is now, bankruptcy is the classic American free-market deal -- debtors and creditors can do whatever they like, with bankruptcy as the "reset" button if things go badly. Everyone takes chances on that result.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 3; Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 885 words

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends;
A Rising Tide, but Some Boats Rise Higher Than Others

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE

 BODY:
FOR the labor movement, Public Enemy No. 1 has long been the nation's growing income gap. John J. Sweeney, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. president, frequently complains in speeches that the economic boom under Mr. Clinton has left millions of hard-working Americans behind and that corporate chieftains have rewarded themselves richly while downsizing their work forces and clamping down on wages.
To fan the flames of blue-collar and white-collar discontent, the labor federation has set up a Web site (www.paywatch.org) that shows workers how many hundreds of times more the C.E.O.'s at their companies earn than they do. 
 And now comes Vice President Al Gore, who has borrowed much of labor's class-edged, us-against-them rhetoric, with an eye to making America's steel-mill workers and truck drivers feel enthusiastic about his candidacy. Mr. Gore rails against the powerful and declares himself the champion of working families. Intending to please the have-nots and the have-littles, Mr. Gore says he will oppose "a huge tax cut for the wealthy at the expense of everyone else." In his embrace of labor, Mr. Gore plans to speak alongside Mr. Sweeney in Pittsburgh tommorow, Labor Day.
But while co-opting some A.F.L.-C.I.O. rhetoric (Mr. Sweeney's favorite phrase is "working families"), Mr. Gore steers clear of the income gap, which only widened on his and President Clinton's watch.
While the Clinton administration points to statistics showing that the gap has grown far more slowly than under Presidents Reagan and Bush, recent trends are still daunting. Last year, it took 100 million of the lowest earning Americans to equal the after-tax dollars of the top 1 percent. In 1977, it only took 49 million of the lowest earners to equal the top 1 percent.
Another politically embarrassing nugget: the bottom four-fifths of households -- numbering 217 million -- took a thinner slice of the nation's economic pie last year, 50 percent, than in 1977, when it was 56 percent. One reason, according to data from the Congressional Budget Office, was that nine-tenths of the growth in the economic pie since then went to the richest 1 percent of households, which last year averaged $515,600 in after-tax income, up from $234,700 in 1977.
With the campaign heating up, labor leaders have been bringing up the income gap less frequently, partly because focusing on it might embarrass their preferred candidate. In an interview, Mr. Sweeney said that he had not forgotten the issue, but that many of the forces spurring the gap were largely beyond the control of the Democratic administration. For instance, rapid technological change and the decline in manufacturing have wiped out millions of unskilled jobs and have thus held down wages for many low-wage workers.
Mr. Sweeney praised the Clinton-Gore team for pressing for legislation that would reduce the income gap, both pre-tax and after-tax. He cited the administration's push for a higher minimum wage, more money for job training and billions of dollars for an expanded Earned Income Tax Credit.
The A.F.L.-C.I.O. president added that he expected Gov. George W. Bush to do considerably less than Mr. Gore to help middle-income and low-income Americans. Mr. Bush has repeatedly asserted that his proposed $1.3 trillion tax cut will do far more for the middle class than Mr. Gore's proposal for a smaller, focused tax cut.
Last week Mr. Bush campaigned with a $40,000-a-year teacher and high school coach from Louisiana, Andrew Beechac, who hailed Mr. Bush's tax proposal, saying: "We all want tax relief, especially for my family and for middle America around the country. We really need this plan."
Geoffrey Garin, a pollster who often advises the A.F.L.-C.I.O., predicted that workers concerned about the income gap would be unlikely to favor Mr. Bush. "The concern about Bush among A.F.L.-C.I.O. members," he said, "is that he will be a rich man's president and will have the kinds of policies that are designed to let the well-to-do have all the benefits of the economy. And they think Gore will be much more likely to spread the benefits around."
As evidence that Mr. Bush's policies would widen the gap, labor leaders point to his proposal to allow individual states to opt out of any increase in the minimum wage beyond the current $5.15 an hour.
Some unions -- most notably the Teamsters, one of the few not to endorse Mr. Gore -- are not willing to give the vice president a pass on the swelling income gap. For these unions, globalization and freer trade are among the biggest factors behind the widening gap. James P. Hoffa, the Teamsters' president, has often argued that trade liberalization measures, like the administration-backed China trade bill, encourage a flood of imports from low-wage countries and an exodus of American jobs. These developments, Mr. Hoffa said, and many free-trade economists acknowledge, help hold down blue-collar wages and thereby worsen the income gap.
Mr. Sweeney has sought to persuade the Teamsters that the best way to reduce income disparities is to elect a Democrat. "Many of the initiatives the administration has taken to spread the wealth more fairly, like increasing the minimum wage, have consistently been blocked by the Republican leadership in the Congress," he said.
