PUB-DATE: September 3, 2000

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 2; Money and Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 2916 words

HEADLINE: TALKING MONEY with JOHNNIE L. COCHRAN JR.;
Finding a 'Dream Team' for His Finances

BYLINE: By GERALDINE FABRIKANT

 BODY:
BILL COSBY has a jet named Camille, for his wife, and even Oprah got a jet," Johnnie L. Cochran Jr. said recently over lunch at City Hall, a restaurant near his law office in Lower Manhattan. "She wanted a plane just like Bill Cosby's. It's, like, amazing. He goes to sleep on the plane. It's wonderful."
Clearly dazzled by the luxury of personal transportation, Mr. Cochran has studied the subject. He is now getting a jet, too. 
 Mr. Cochran, who broke into the top-level national law leagues when he successfully defended O. J. Simpson against charges that he murdered his former wife, is now hitting the major money leagues as well, and he has the status-symbol issue down pat.
"We're not getting a GII," he conceded, his voice showing a tinge of disappointment that he is not buying a Gulfstream model favored by many chief executives. "My plane won't be that big -- more like a Hawker or a Citation."
But Mr. Cochran, showing his newfound financial prudence, will not make the purchase rashly. His law firm, which is building a national practice, is still deciding whether to buy or lease the plane. "We are going to see how often we would use it," he said.
Success is hardly new to Mr. Cochran, who is now 62. Long before his disciplined, relentless cross-examination and his flamboyant attire became a daily staple of the grueling O. J. Simpson murder trial, he was a prominent lawyer with a busy criminal and civil practice. His performance at the televised trial, however, made Mr. Cochran, a member of the "dream team" defense, a celebrity in his own right.
But it did not leave him as rich as it left him famous. Now he is trying to close that gap, adopting a new money-management philosophy that includes putting more money into the stock market.
His success "allowed him to move up the lawyer food chain," said his accountant, John Baiardi, a partner at Mitchell & Titus, the nation's largest minority-owned accounting firm.
Mr. Cochran no longer takes criminal cases, but he has a thriving personal practice that includes intellectual property, personal-injury and business lawsuits. And last year, in a move that leverages his brand name, he merged his firm with Schneider, Kleinick, Weitz, Damashek & Shoot, a personal-injury firm based in New York. Partners share the legal fees in cases they win together.
Mr. Cochran says his net worth is more than $5 million -- in retirement plans, private investments, a sprinkling of stocks and his major holding, real estate. His properties include homes in Los Angeles, including beach homes in Marina del Rey for himself and his parents, a new condominium in Manhattan where he now spends one-third of his time, and two apartment buildings in West Hollywood that he bought as an investment. That net worth figure does not include the value of his law firm.
But he may be about to make a quantum leap.
Within five years, his net worth could soar to $25 million or even $50 million, Mr. Baiardi said, as fees roll in from the exploding demand for his legal services.
To which Mr. Cochran replied, "I hope we will do that well."
Lester Brickman, a law firm compensation expert and a professor at the Benjamin N. Cardoza School of Law, agreed that the personal-injury fees could contribute to a bump-up in Mr. Cochran's net worth. Lawyers in that area are very selective about the cases they take on, have a high success rate and often reap big financial rewards. But maybe not as high as Mr. Baiardi suggested. "It is in the realm of possibility that Cochran can net over $10 million a year," Mr. Brickman said.
By contrast, Mr. Cochran was earning $1 million or so annually by the time the Simpson trial ended in 1995.
"Before, I was interested in earning money," Mr. Cochran said. "Now, I'm interested in what happens to it. I don't want to be haphazard -- I want a team I can count on."
WITH the help of people like Earl G. Graves Sr., the publisher of Black Enterprise magazine and leading black entrepreneur, whom he had met through some business dealings, he is tapping into the African-American financial establishment in New York. The goal is to help build that dream team and to create a network of relationships in the financial sphere, much as he once did in the legal establishment.
Mr. Cochran's new focus on finances started in early 1997, when he decided that he had been spending so much time in Manhattan for his program on Court TV that he ought to put down roots. So he bought a pied a terre on West 57th Street in Midtown for about $750,000.
After settling in, he called Mr. Graves. "He is one of my gurus," Mr. Cochran said. "Earl is into wealth."
Mr. Graves said Mr. Cochran peppered him with questions. "He said, 'Tell me what I need to know in town,' " Mr. Graves recalled. First, he steered him to Carver Bancorp, the largest black-run bank in the country, where Mr. Cochran's personal-injury clients could borrow money. "Then Johnnie told me, 'The way you look is the way I ought to look.' " So I sent him to the John Atchison hair salon on West 56th Street. He told me it was too expensive, so I sent him a gift certificate."
As for Mr. Cochran's finances, "I asked him, 'What are you going to do about your own money?' " Mr. Graves added. "And he asked me who I should invest with." Mr. Graves introduced him to Bert N. Mitchell of Mitchell & Titus and other black financial leaders.
"New York has been a real eye-opener for me," Mr. Cochran said. "Most of the people in L.A. who have money are entertainers. And L.A. is more spread out -- here you talk, you find out what other guys are doing. In New York, everything is geared to business."
The team that Mr. Cochran has assembled is ethnically diverse. Guided by Mr. Baiardi, who is white, and Jeri Norris, a black financial consultant and a stockbroker at Merrill Lynch, Mr. Cochran is educating himself about more sophisticated investing strategies. "We didn't grow up on Wall Street, but we should move there now," he said, remembering something that Jesse Jackson said while trying to encourage blacks to invest.
"I should have gotten into the stock market earlier," Mr. Cochran said over the recent two-hour lunch of seafood and creamed spinach.
Ms. Norris is seeing to that. Wanting to preserve Mr. Cochran's capital, she said, "we want a mix of old-economy and technology stocks." Among her picks for his portfolio are Sun Microsystems, J. P. Morgan and the American International Group. Her long-term goal for him is 70 percent equities, 20 percent bonds and 10 percent cash.
Mr. Cochran said he preferred to leave the decisions to Ms. Norris: "My wife and I don't want to wake up worrying about the market," he said. But he did make one choice: last year, he bought about $150,000 worth of Time Warner stock. He knew the company because it owned Court TV, where for two years he had a talk show on legal issues, but he does even know today what the value of that investment is -- except that the stock has gone up.
Though he does not want the final responsibility of making investment decisions, Mr. Cochran wants to know the issues and speaks often to Ms. Norris. To cement the relationship, he and his wife recently took Ms. Norris and her husband to the theater and to dinner at Aquavit in Midtown Manhattan.
Mr. Cochran is also listening to advice about his real estate and about the kinds of deals in which he invests. Gone are the days of jumping into deals heard about at cocktail parties. Mr. Cochran says future deals will be more carefully vetted by Mr. Baiardi, "who is my sounding board."
IF Mr. Cochran cannot resist gambling in venture capital and private equity, Mr. Baiardi wants him to go only with blue-chip recommendations. "It is one thing if your brother-in-law introduces you to someone who has a deal," Mr. Baiardi said. "It is another thing when you go to an investment bank and they do some private equity."
Mr. Baiardi would also like Mr. Cochran to sell the two apartment buildings in West Hollywood. "If you are in real estate, you have to collect your own rents," Mr. Baiardi said. "It's one thing to own commercial property that Trump manages. It is another thing to own rental properties and collect rent."
Mr. Baiardi is not having a problem convincing Mr. Cochran. Though real estate had represented his main investment for years, the risks became apparent in the late 1980's. "You never thought about the stock market when I started buying real estate," he recalled. "You just assumed real estate was stable and would keep going up. Then it went down, so that was unsettling."
A Merrill Lynch team suggested that Mr. Cochran borrow the entire purchase price of his new condominium against his existing real estate, rather than raising cash to make a large down payment. The move let him deduct all the interest and reduce taxes. "His first instinct was to pay off as much as possible," Ms. Norris recalled.
Until now. "My first thing is always to pay things off," Mr. Cochran said. But he said he had learned that "you can get deductions and it does not always pay to pay it off."
"I really wanted to get good tax advice," he added.
Mr. Cochran is even toning down his lifestyle a bit -- to be less showy. No more Rolls-Royces, like the one he drives around Los Angeles. Today, he said, he likes "stealth wealth -- Jeeps, all that stuff."
"I think now, where I am, I would not drive a Rolls in New York," he added. "But as a young man, it was a sign of success. My clients wanted to see that. Driving a Toyota or a Mazda was terrible. If you didn't have a Rolls, you weren't very successful."
He has given up his Rolexes, too. "After a period of time, that's not as important," he said.
Mr. Cochran has also become more pragmatic about his personal life, which was once in disarray. The other night, he said, he and his wife of 15 years, Dale, a marketing executive who is now starting a new business, were watching an episode on HBO's "Sex and the City" that dealt with prenuptial agreements. "I mentioned a prenup and we laughed about it," he said. "But absolutely I would have one now. My estate has gone up, and I think in this world, that's the way to go."
Mr. Cochran's current life is a far cry from a childhood that began in Shreveport, La., where his father was once a sharecropper. But the family was ambitious. By the time he was 6, his father and mother had packed up their four children and moved to California, where the elder Mr. Cochran eventually became a successful insurance salesman.
The Cochrans were also determined that their children receive a good education. They sent Mr. Cochran to Los Angeles High School, which had a far better academic reputation than the school closer to his home.
VISITING the homes of wealthy white friends whom he met at school was a revelation for Mr. Cochran, who grew up without television or other entree to that world. "I had no way to know how they lived before that," he said. "Remember, there was a big class thing. How would you know unless you worked for them?" he added, speaking of his friends' families.
And though Mr. Cochran made friends at the school whom he has kept until this day, he said he did not bring them to his house.
His parents encouraged him to become a professional. His mother wanted him to be a doctor, but Mr. Cochran thought that law would suit him better, letting him use his skills of persuasion.
In 1963, after graduating from Loyola Law School in Los Angeles, he became the first black law clerk in the Los Angeles city attorney's office, making $608 a month. His job involved prosecuting people, primarily black, who were charged with avoiding arrest. But that, he came to believe, was aimed at keeping them from filing civil suits against the city for compensation for their injuries.
By 1965, he and Gerald Lenoir, a seasoned criminal lawyer, had started a practice together. Their first windfall came fast. When rioting exploded in Los Angeles's poor, mainly black, Watts district, Mr. Cochran was alone in the office. As the rioting escalated and the police began making arrests, clients came to the office until 11 or 12 at night, putting retainer fees on his desk -- in cash.
"That was the first time I became aware: 'Geez, you can make a lot of money doing this,' " Mr. Cochran said. "People would come with $3,000 or $4,000. It was sad. You had a weird feeling. The city was going up in smoke. But it was the first time I knew the practice of law could be remunerative."
Mr. Cochran learned quickly that criminal defense lawyers need the money up front. "They used to say, 'Get the money while the tears are falling,' " he recalled. Otherwise, he added, an acquitted client would say, "I was innocent anyway," and a convicted one would ask, "What did you do for me?"
His practice expanded to civil cases, including police brutality suits. "Later, I started getting the big fees from contingency cases," he said. "You get one-third after you win, so you got to win."
In those years, Mr. Cochran worried a lot about the cash flow, often asking whether any checks had come in while he was in court.
Still, he set parameters. When a known drug dealer showed up with a suitcase filled with $600,000 in cash, Mr. Cochran refused to represent him. "It was the most money I had ever seen," he said. "But I knew drugs were killing kids in the black community, and I didn't take the case. I knew where the money had come from."
Over time, as word spread about his successes, the money poured in. And Mr. Cochran was not shy about spending his earnings on his family and personal luxuries. "I would buy clothes and nice cars," he said. At one point, he had six fancy cars. "It wasn't always wise," he added.
He spent money on a handful of deals, involving oil, a supper club, radio stations and other things, with mixed results.
He also spent a lot of money on an extramarital relationship, according to "Life After Johnnie Cochran," a 1995 book by his former wife, Barbara Cochran Berry. In 1965, he started a relationship with Patricia Sikora, who would become the mother of his only son, Ms. Berry wrote. In 1973, according to Ms. Berry, he took out a loan to help pay for a house he was buying for Ms. Sikora, and he tried to get Ms. Berry to sign an agreement that she had no rights to the house, an accusation that Mr. Cochran has denied. In the view of Ms. Berry, with whom he has two daughters, he used his money as a form of manipulation.
"Money and the gifts it bought were the sum and substance of what a woman had a right to expect from a man," she wrote, interpreting what he conveyed to her. "This need of women for money and security were tools to be used in their control, to keep them in their place."
Mr. Cochran said: "This is ridiculous. My poor dear ex-wife -- it is not true. She saw a chance to write a book and to try to make some money."
Even after the Cochrans divorced in 1977 and Mr. Cochran married his current wife in 1985, he continued to send Ms. Sikora $4,000 a month, according to a palimony suit that Ms. Sikora filed in 1995 after, she said, Mr. Cochran cut her off.
Mr. Cochran said he sent the money because "I was supporting my son." Now 27, the son, Jonathan Cochran, is on his own, working for the California Highway Patrol.
The suit was dismissed and is on appeal.
Mr. Cochran's financial contributions extended to other family members as well. For years, he helped his parents and a brother; his widowed father now lives with him in Los Angeles.
He even sent his first wife a television set as a wedding present when she remarried. He has also given money away, most recently creating the Johnnie L. Cochran Jr. Art Fund, financed with several hundred thousand dollars to help minority artists.
Though he spent his money liberally, his investment strategy was conservative. (He agrees with a friend who once told him that his ties were more flamboyant than his investing style.) He stuck with real estate and he avoided the stock market -- a strategy that several experts say is common among blacks.
"The stock market is still the easiest way to get into the wealth game," said Brooke Stephens, author of "Talking Dollars and Making Sense: A Wealth-Building Guide for African-Americans." "But many blacks don't trust it and don't understand it."
Mr. Cochran said his conservatism was in part a result of memories from childhood that left him worried about taxes. "You would hear stories about Joe Louis and Sammy Davis Jr." he recalled. "They took Sammy's house away from him. And I would think: I am never going to be like that. I want to pay my taxes."
"You grow up with certain fears," he added. "You want to be secure. If you have been poor, you understand that if you worked real hard, you don't want to go back and be there anymore. Tax problems have always been a big problem for people who became successful in our community. I vowed that would never be a problem."
He sees himself as still somewhat of a target. "I get audited every year," he said. "I am getting audited right now. They read about my book deal," he said, referring to his advance for "Journey to Justice" of about $3 million. He added that they say, " 'Where is the money,' as though you are not going to pay taxes."
But over the next decade, Mr. Cochran's biggest problem will not be taxes, but how to invest all the wealth he is accruing after he pays his taxes. And he seems to be well on his way to solving that problem.

PUB-DATE: September 3, 2000

SECTION: Section 4; Page 11; Column 5; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 688 words

HEADLINE: Liberties;
Acid Tongue in Cheek

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The Bush campaign has dissolved into a whiny puddle. The Austin team put out a press release Friday bawling that Joe Lieberman was a big meanie to compare Governor Bush to Barney Rubble.
You'd think, after the risible rift between Dan Quayle and Murphy Brown, that Republicans would know better than to whinge about fictional characters. 
 W.'s attempt to be nasty and nice at the same time is so lame, it's making me miss Lee Atwater. At least Atwater knew where he wanted to be -- in the gutter.
The cocky, jagged-edged strategist, a jogging partner and political ally of W. during the '88 campaign, would have snickered at the oxymoron some Bushies have used to describe the ad campaign against Al Gore: soft negative.
When Atwater ran Poppy's race against Michael Dukakis, he bragged on a less euphemistic approach: "Attack and destroy!"
His fellow dark prince of strategy, Roger Ailes, who helped Atwater turn Willie Horton into a bludgeon, was once asked by a Time reporter if they had any qualms about using Mr. Horton in an ad. "The only question," Ailes replied breezily, "is whether we depict Willie Horton with a knife in his hand or without it."
You can't insist that a scalding ad is soft without looking foolish. Or, as W. himself so memorably put it after John McCain attacked him in the primary: "You can't take the high horse and claim the low road."
The Republicans' new ad has a female narrator sarcastically mocking Mr. Gore's image on TV as he says he "took the initiative in creating the Internet" and as he hangs with Buddhist monks.
The ad is designed to rip Mr. Gore's truthfulness and ethics. Yet on Friday Mr. Bush defended it by parroting his aides' assertions that it was merely "humorous" and "tongue in cheek."
In two short weeks, W. and Al have switched roles, and it's making the Bush campaign nuts. Al is now the sunny one, crowing to The Washington Post that "the wind is at our backs and it's filling our sails." He's 10 points ahead, according to a Newsweek poll. And he's now seen as smarter and better-looking than W., according to a Gallup poll, and also the one voters would rather dine with. Thanks to the big smooch, women have finally cottoned to the Democratic nominee. And suddenly W., who had been loftily promising to restore civility to politics, seems like Slashing, Opportunistic Guy.
Thrown off his strut, W. veered between impatience and sentimentality talking Friday to The Times's Alison Mitchell and Frank Bruni, and grew misty over the "amazing experience" of running for president.
Besides the cheap-shot ad, W. looks sulky about setting the debates. The Bush family has a proud history of aversion to debates, which don't suit them because of their curious relationship with grammar and because they feel they should be trusted to govern without having to prove themselves.
But there was something surreal in watching the candidate who is so allergic to details dwelling on every detail of the debate format, from the location (nothing adjacent to anything named after a Democratic president) to the questioners (Larry King would be best) to the furniture (a table instead of podiums would be nice).
And then there was the dead weight known as Dick Cheney. Mr. Cheney finally faced up to his potential conflict of interest, announcing that, if elected, he would forfeit Halliburton stock options worth about $3.5 million.
He also released his tax returns, showing why $3.5 million was a piddling sacrifice. His income went from $258,394 in 1992, when he was the Bush secretary of defense who helped direct the Persian Gulf war to save a ritzy gas station called Kuwait and keep American oil prices down, to $4,423,289 in 1999, when he was an avatar of Big Oil.
The Gore campaign might think about using that Cheney financial statement in an ad. Mr. Cheney didn't fare too shabbily in the Democratic economy. His annual income multiplied 17 times during the Clinton-Gore administration. He got a whopping $20 million in 10 years and gave a measly 1 percent to charity.
But you can see why the guy wants to give himself a bigger tax cut.

HEADLINE: Learning by Just Being There

BYLINE: By Susan Mayer and Christopher Jencks; Susan Mayer, a professor at the University of Chicago's Harris School of Public Policy, is the author of "What Money Can't Buy." Christopher Jencks teaches at Harvard University's Kennedy School of Government.

 BODY:
"Accountability" has become the favored solution to the nation's educational problems. For schools, accountability usually means that standardized tests identify failing schools, which then become candidates for administrative shakeups, closure or voucher programs.
For students, accountability typically means requiring anyone with low test scores to attend summer school. Students whose scores do not improve may have to repeat a grade. Some states plan to withhold high school diplomas from low scorers, although that threat may be politically difficult to carry out. 
 These stabs at accountability rely entirely on standardized tests, which seem like a reasonable measure. After all, if students aren't learning, something is wrong. But test scores should not be the only measure of success.
Contrary to what many assume, students can benefit from attending school even when their test scores do not improve. Among men and women in their late 20's who worked full time throughout 1998, those with high school diplomas but no post-secondary education typically earned $5,000 more than high school dropouts.
Sounds good. But test scores have little to do with this difference in wages. Numerous economists have shown that test scores, on average, account for no more than $1,500 of the $5,000 difference between high school graduates and dropouts.
Of course, book learning is not useless. Students who do well on tests tend to make more money than those who don't. But test scores are only one factor among many that affect wages, and simply staying in school, regardless of test scores, changes people in ways that employers value.
We social scientists do not know what specifically accounts for the wage gap between high school graduates and dropouts. But if employers are asked why graduates make better workers than dropouts, they give a multitude of answers: Graduates have a better attitude; they are more responsible; they have better people skills.
There is also evidence that when schools change these character traits, the result is long-lasting.
Model preschool programs almost always raise children's test scores, but after a few years the advantage fades. Yet in the long run, students who attend good preschools have fewer behavioral problems and are less likely to be placed in special education classes, less likely to drop out of high school and less likely to become teenage mothers.
Because schooling helps students in many ways, measuring performance solely through test scores can do harm as well as good. If teachers know that their school may be closed unless scores rise, they may not spend much time trying to make students more considerate, trustworthy or respectful.
Likewise, denying diplomas to high school students who fail a standardized test may backfire. A recent national study by Brian Jacob, a doctoral student at the University of Chicago, shows that high-stakes testing increases the odds that students with very low scores will drop out.
 So how should we measure school performance? While some schools create a climate in which students learn to show up, hand in their homework and meet their other obligations, others do not.
We need to take such differences into account. We should ask not just whether a school imparts knowledge, but also how many students stick around until graduation and how many complete college applications. We should assess how students behave by asking how many students come to school with guns and how many have babies before graduating.
Woody Allen famously quipped that 90 percent of life is showing up. Students who finish high school do better than dropouts partly because they have learned this lesson.

HEADLINE: Editorial Observer;
Attracting New Immigrants to the Heartland

BYLINE: By VERLYN KLINKENBORG

 BODY:
Iowa isn't a crowded place. It wasn't crowded when I was growing up there in the 1950's and early 60's, and it isn't crowded now. In 1960, when I was in third grade, the state population was 2,757,537 and still slowly climbing, as it had been all century, until it reached a peak of just less than three million people in 1980.
Yet things haven't been as static in Iowa as these figures suggest. The way that Iowa isn't crowded has changed. The number of third graders has plummeted, and the population as a whole has gotten older. The percentage of the population over 80 is larger in Iowa than in any other state. Iowa is the only state besides Florida with more people over 75 than under 5. 
 That is one of the reasons the state -- which has nearly always experienced annual net migration losses -- wants to encourage immigration. A plan to do just that, produced by a bipartisan governor's commission called the 2010 Committee, has caused an uproar in a state that is overwhelmingly white. In fact, the commission's report merely recognizes a demographic reality. Without immigration, the state's labor force will steadily dwindle. The only reason Iowa's population has not fallen further is because of immigrants who have come from Mexico, Vietnam, Bosnia and elsewhere. The greatest demand for labor comes from industries like meat packing.
The population problem in Iowa isn't merely that its residents are getting old and its young people are leaving. The problem is tied directly to the character of agriculture in the state. In 1960 there were 174,707 farms in Iowa, down from a peak of around 215,000 in 1930. Last year there were about 96,000 farms, though the amount of farmland in cultivation had barely changed. There are 15 million hogs in Iowa, but they are raised on fewer than half as many farms as just a decade ago.
It can be hard to grasp the implications of a shift that large. Think of a farm, for a moment, not as a tract of land or so many acres of corn and soybeans. Think of a farm instead as a constellation of people, each of whom has ties to a local community -- to churches and schools, to banks and farm-implement dealers, to co-ops and Lions Clubs. In 1960, small towns were thriving not on the prosperity of town residents alone but on the prosperity -- and the population -- of farms in the adjoining countryside.
Now half of those farms are gone, their groves cut down, their houses bulldozed, their constellations of people dispersed. Year by year, the size of farms increases and their work force diminishes. The towns are very quiet, except the ones lucky enough to hear the roar of enormous grain driers at the elevator out by the railroad tracks. School districts have consolidated, and small-town business is just a ghost of itself. It is not uncommon to come across a sense of disinheritance among Iowans, especially those living in small towns. The bond that tied them to the farmland around them -- a bond that was social as well as economic -- has to a striking degree been severed. There is no one on the farms, and the towns have no one to serve except their aging residents.
All of this has come about because of a faith -- an unproved faith -- that the only way for agriculture to prosper is for farms to become bigger and bigger. There is no question that Iowa raises vastly more corn and soybeans than it did in 1960. But at what cost? Farm prices are as low as they have ever been, and farmers now pray for emergency funding from Congress the way they pray for rain. One of the indisputable results of large-scale corporate farming in Iowa has been the depopulation of the countryside. An agricultural job in Iowa is now a meat-packing job, highly dangerous, badly paid and emblematic of an approach to farming that will serve Iowa's new immigrants as badly as it has served its longtime residents. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE ELECTORATE;
For Last Dance, Candidates Eye The Wallflower

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE

DATELINE: TOLEDO, Ohio, Aug. 31

 BODY:
Labor Day is the unofficial opening of the general election campaign, but for most voters the race is already over. Strategists on both sides agree that more than 90 percent of the electorate has by now settled on either Gov. George W. Bush or Vice President Al Gore.
That leaves the outcome in November hinging on a sliver of expected voters -- fewer than 10 percent -- who truly have not made up their minds. This narrow pool of voters reflects what pollsters say has been an appreciable shift in the electorate in the two weeks since the Democratic convention: Mr. Gore consolidated the base vote in his party, something Mr. Bush accomplished weeks, if not months, earlier. 
 Both sides will still strive to ensure the highest possible turnout from their most faithful partisans. But the campaigns are now devoting their two most precious commodities -- time and money -- in the remaining two months to persuading up-in-the-air voters to side with them.
Of the 148 million registered voters, 103 million are expected to vote. Of those, an estimated 5 million are undecided. But if this pool is further narrowed to include undecided voters in important battleground states, the actual number of voters that both camps -- and to a lesser degree the third-party contenders -- are fighting over may be fewer than one million. That is minuscule, especially when contrasted with a voting-age population of more than 205 million.
"That's the gold," said John Zogby, a pollster who is not affiliated with either party. "Kind of sobering, isn't it? Three-quarters of a million to a million voters in 10 states."
The competition over these swing voters is driving the political calculations of each side. It explains why Mr. Bush traveled to Ohio today to visit a high school -- his 100th school visit -- and in fact spent all week promoting his education plan. It also explains the Gore campaign's decision to celebrate the Labor Day weekend with a 24-hour "American Workathon," for which the vice president will travel to five cities to spend time with people who are working.
The push and pull over swing voters is particularly intense and of utmost consequence this year because both sides acknowledge that the electoral dynamic has changed significantly, with polls now showing a dead-even race between Mr. Gore and Mr. Bush. For months leading to the party conventions, Mr. Bush clung to a small but unmistakable lead. In some current polls, Mr. Gore has even pulled ahead.
Now, Mr. Gore's aides, citing private and public polls in several states, are confidently declaring for the first time that they are leading in the Electoral College tally. "We're ahead substantially," said Tad Devine, a top strategist for Mr. Gore. "I've been surprised at the depth of the movement to Gore."
Karl Rove, the architect of the Bush strategy, conceded that Mr. Gore had made inroads. Yet Mr. Rove disputed the surveys cited by the Gore camp and insisted that the Texas governor was still dominant in the Electoral College. But, sounding a bit frustrated by questions about his candidate's potency in the polls, Mr. Rove added: "Tune in, man. We've been saying for about three weeks that the race will essentially be dead even by Labor Day. Welcome to reality!"
While the undecided voters are not a monolith, surveys show that they do share some characteristics: More than half consider themselves independents. They are mostly married, between the ages of 45 and 64. They hold moderate stands on issues. They voted overwhelmingly for President Clinton's re-election. They are generally from working-class families in which both parents work and the income is between $30,000 and $50,000. Many live in suburbs in the Midwest, and some in rural areas. More than half are women.
One swing voter is Francis Steffee, 76, a retired food services worker in Kent, Ohio. "This one is hard to figure out," she said. "One day I'm leaning for one and the next day, well, I'm leaning for the other. I thought I'd wait until they have the debates and see what goes on."
Whom does she favor today? "I'm thinking of Gore," she said, explaining that she was put off by Mr. Bush's promises about improving education. "Everybody says they're going to do this and do that. You know it never happens that way."
Arland Van Kirk, 68, a retired worker in a carburetor shop in Lock Haven, Pa., also has not decided. She identifies more with Republicans than Democrats, she said, but voted for Mr. Clinton twice -- and is torn between Mr. Bush and Mr. Gore.
"I think they are both trying too hard," Ms. Van Kirk said. "If they'd just give a straight answer on the tough questions, without all the hemming and hawing."
Explaining that she was not inclined to back Mr. Bush, she said: "I never liked Bush the father. I always thought he was too mealy-mouthed." Her problem with Mr. Gore was also one of style. "He sometimes acts like he's Mr. Big," she said.
Even as Mr. Gore and Mr. Bush battle over these voters, the candidates' target audiences are slightly different. Strategists on each side said that among undecided voters, Mr. Bush was aiming at a younger, slightly more upscale pool by promoting measures like privatizing Social Security.
Mr. Bush is struggling to hold on to a chunk of women voters in that swing group who polls show are slipping back to the Democratic fold. That, his advisers said, was the impetus behind his visits to schools because women are particularly supportive of improving schools.
With his emphasis on prescription drugs and protecting Medicare, Mr. Gore is fashioning his appeals for slightly older swing voters who are faring adequately economically but not as well as they would like. Although his campaign has had far more success with women than men, Mr. Gore is trying to eat into the support for Mr. Bush among working-class men.
The Bush campaign has been more aggressive than the Gore operation in homing in on those swing voters.
That relentless focus was on display this week in the northwestern corner of Ohio, a crucial battleground state. After Mr. Bush's plane landed at the Toledo airport, one of his aides told reporters that the media market here had the fourth-largest number of swing voters in the state.
It was no accident that when he arrived, Mr. Bush was greeted by what he called "a real family of four," with an annual income of $50,000, that he said would benefit from his tax cut plan. And it was no accident that on his one stop in Ohio, Mr. Bush headed for Springfield High School in Holland to promote himself as the candidate most dedicated to improving education.
The Bush campaign could afford to be more narrow in aiming at swing voters, Mr. Rove explained, because Republicans rallied behind Mr. Bush faster than Democrats did behind Mr. Gore.
"Elections are won by doing two things: mobilizing your base and winning the independent swing voters," Mr. Rove said. "Our base is mobilized and we're winning independent voters. It's just a question of grinding it out, keeping a focus on the agenda, on your issues -- and pushing it through."
Mr. Devine acknowledged that his campaign has been less surgical in pursuing swing voters. He said that was not because the campaign was still trying to woo core supporters but because at this point "it would be a mistake for us to limit the target audience too narrowly."
"We're casting a pretty wide net," he said. "We're not into laser surgery here. It's not like a piece of direct mail that will land in the last two weeks of the election. We're still very much in a very broad, thematic, formative stage of the election."
While Mr. Bush was in Ohio today, Mr. Gore was stumping in Seattle with a message of his own for the undecided. Rather than specifically refer to a family with the demographics he is seeking to reach -- as did Mr. Bush -- Mr. Gore broadly appealed to voters who acknowledge the nation's prosperity but worry that they have not benefited sufficiently from it.
"We've got to fight to make sure that everybody participates in the prosperity," Mr. Gore said at an outdoor rally in downtown Seattle, "that nobody is left behind."
That Mr. Bush and Mr. Gore are competing over slightly different profiles of swing voters is apparent in their television commercials. Since the Democratic convention, advertising by the Bush campaign and the Republican Party has included images of 40 children or young adults, 18 adults and 15 elderly people, according to an examination by Kathleen Hall Jamieson, dean of the Annenberg School of Communication at the University of Pennsylvania.
By contrast, in keeping with Mr. Gore's focus on older voters, Ms. Jamieson found that the Gore and Democratic Party advertisements in that same period featured 23 children or young adults, but 56 adults and 25 elderly people.
Given that most voters have made up their minds, it is striking that the campaigns' onslaught of advertising is only beginning in earnest.
Each of the two party nominees receives about $68 million in federal money. So if that money were intended to influence one million voters, that would amount to roughly $136 that both campaigns are spending to sway each of those all-important voters. And while the networks estimate that 50 million people could watch nationally televised candidate debates, the audience the candidates are trying to reach in those debates is far narrower.
For all the emphasis on swing voters, neither camp wants to neglect its own supporters who may not be as loyal -- and could be susceptible to entreaties from the other side. Mr. Rove said that while his campaign's strategy "is principally aimed at swing voters, you want to get some of the weak identifiers on the other side."
But mostly, the campaigns are debating how to find the formula to entice those swing voters. The problem is that while those voters have been polled again and again, no one can say what moves them.
"Neither of these guys," said Paul Maslin, a Democratic pollster, "is so strong right now to assume they have the magic answer."
Some voters, of course, are out of reach.
Joe Hesler, 48, a house painter in Collingswood, N.J., said he planned to support Ralph Nader, the Green Party nominee. Asked what it would take to change his mind, he laughed and replied: "A million dollars. On my doorstep. In cash."

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE DEMOCRATIC RUNNING MATE;
In Praise of the President, Lieberman Is Unabashed Where Gore Is Reticent

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA

DATELINE: PORTLAND, Me., Sept. 1

 BODY:
The candidate praises President Clinton's "extraordinary record," crediting the president for the muscular economy. He tells audiences that Mr. Clinton has fought crime. He reminds people that he has been the president's friend for 30 years.
These are not the words of Vice President Al Gore, who rarely mentions Mr. Clinton on the campaign trail. Mr. Gore has spent much of this campaign year trying to put distance between himself and a president whose record, foibles and outsize personality have made him a mixed blessing to his partner and political heir. 
 No, the speaker is Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, Mr. Gore's running mate, who was the first Democrat in the Senate to chastise Mr. Clinton for his sexual misbehavior and is sufficiently distant from Buddhist temples, Oval Office dalliances and Arkansas land deals that he does not feel the need to hold the president at arm's length. Mr. Clinton has hardly been a centerpiece of the senator's pitch, but in the weeks since his nomination, it has been clear that Mr. Lieberman feels far freer than Mr. Gore to embrace the president and claim bragging rights to the achievements of his administration.
"For the last eight years, Bill Clinton and Al Gore have led a fight to get tough on violent crime," Mr. Lieberman said on Monday at a union rally in Chicago. Earlier in the day, he had told a gathering of religious leaders, "I'm very proud of this extraordinary record the Clinton-Gore administration has built up."
On Tuesday in Anaheim, Calif., he told the Communications Workers of America that a strong economy and investments in technology were "the kind of change Bill Clinton and Al Gore brought to America," citing their "brilliant leadership." And on Thursday in Portland, Ore., he said, "There's a lot for the president to be proud of."
Mr. Lieberman often mentions Mr. Clinton by name, and even when he does not, the connection is obvious. In one of the segments of his standard stump speech that draws some of his loudest applause and cheers, he rebuts the Republicans who have called Mr. Clinton's two terms a time of squandered opportunities.
"If you're one of the 22 million people who's in a job that was created in the last eight years, you sure know that the last eight years have not been squandered," he said today in Portland, Me. "If you're one of the four million new businesses in America -- two million small businesses -- that have been created in the last eight years, you know they haven't been squandered. If you are one of the millions who've gone from the dependency of welfare to the self-sufficiency of work, you know these last eight years have not been squandered. And if you're one of the other millions who have either bought a new home or refinanced the ones you have because we did turn deficits into surpluses and kept the interest rates down, you know these last eight years have not been squandered."
Chris Lehane, a spokesman for the Gore campaign, played down what he conceded were differences in the two running mates' treatment of the president, but even in doing so, he referred to Mr. Clinton only indirectly. "I do think the vice president acknowledges the great success of the last eight years," he said. "Maybe not at every event. But what the vice president has been talking about mostly is about the future."
What to do about Mr. Clinton has posed a dilemma throughout the campaign for Mr. Gore. The vice president has been an unusually influential second-in-command to a popular president during a time of enormous prosperity, but he has had difficulty being seen, as he proclaimed himself at the Democrats' convention in Los Angeles, as "my own man." And his reputation for rectitude has been shaken by the investigation of fund-raising for the 1996 campaign and by association with Mr. Clinton's private behavior.
The Gore campaign has frequently used current or former Clinton administration officials as surrogates in making his case to the reporters. And in Mr. Lieberman, Mr. Gore has a vehicle for boasting about his role in the administration, without doing so himself.
For the Democratic faithful, at least, the praise of the president has been well received. Interviews with people at Mr. Lieberman's rallies found that most agreed with Virginia Minarik, who said in Chicago, "I'm glad he's not running away from Clinton like Gore is, because Clinton's been a great president."
In an interview, Mr. Lieberman was effusive in his praise of Mr. Clinton. "I feel really comfortable doing it, because President Clinton deserves it," he said. "We have become the party of fiscal responsibility and economic growth," an achievement he attributed to "the president and the vice president."
He was careful to distinguish Mr. Clinton's personal behavior, which he deplored so publicly in 1998, from his performance as president.
What few voters realize is that in 1992, before Mr. Clinton chose Mr. Gore as his running mate, he was closer to Mr. Lieberman.
In 1970, while a student at Yale law school, Mr. Clinton worked on Mr. Lieberman's first political campaign, for the state Senate, and they have kept in close touch since. They worked together in the 1980's on the Democratic Leadership Council, committed to pushing the Democratic Party toward the center, and Mr. Lieberman succeeded Mr. Clinton as head of the group.
"I was the first senator outside of Arkansas to endorse him" in 1992, Mr. Lieberman recalled. He spoke of the "extraordinary joy" he felt that year in watching Mr. Clinton succeed in conveying his ideas. "And then, to have the tremendous satisfaction of seeing them work. You know, the extraordinary good times, welfare reform, crime is down. So, you know, that's a remarkable record."

HEADLINE: Lebanon Challenger Takes On Syria, Too

BYLINE: By JOHN KIFNER

DATELINE: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 2

 BODY:
Lebanon is slipping toward a constitutional crisis -- and a tough early test for Syria's new young leader, Bashar al-Assad -- as it goes into a final round of parliamentary elections on Sunday.
Rafik Hariri, the flamboyant multibillionaire real estate developer, appears poised to roll up a majority in the 128-seat Parliament, probably 70 seats or more, in his effort to come back as prime minister. 
 But President Emile Lahoud, annointed by Syria, which for a decade has been the only real political power here, appears determined, somehow, to block Mr. Hariri from regaining the office he held from 1992 to 1998.
Mr. Hariri threw up showy projects, including rebuilding the downtown devastated by the 15-year civil war, but Mr. Lahoud has accused him of plunging the country into debt and corruption.
The government took a terrific blow in the first round of elections last Sunday in the far north, the Christian heartland, and the Druz mountains, with final tallies showing 41 of the 63 seats going to government critics or candidates allied with Mr. Hariri. Riding a wave of economic discontent, the tycoon has built an imposing set of alliances for the vote Sunday in Beirut, the south and the Bekaa region.
Winding up with a series of packed, emotional street rallies, Mr. Hariri exuded confidence this morning in his huge, ornate palace, as aides and candidates on his ticket scurried about.
"The polls are good," he said. "Tomorrow we will see if they are right. The battle is for Beirut."
Nevertheless, President Lahoud's main political ally, Michel Murr, the powerful interior minister, says no matter how many votes and how much parliamentary support Mr. Hariri gets, he is not coming back.
"Hariri may have become the Gamal Abdel Nasser of the Sunni Muslim sect, and he may be able to sweep Beirut in the elections, but this will not bring him closer to the Grand Serai," he said, referring to the huge stone building that houses the prime minister's office.
"On the contrary, this will push him much farther from the premiership," Mr. Murr was quoted by the newspaper As Safir as having told visitors after last week's voting.
"Even the support of 70 Parliament members will not be enough to get Hariri to the prime ministry slot, because everyone knows how a prime minister is manufactured in Lebanon," he went on.
"The basic element in this process is a consensus between Syria and the president about the new prime minister. It seems that many are not fully aware of the depth of the strategic relationship that exists between President Emile Lahoud and President Bashar Assad."
On paper, at least, it would seem difficult to deny Mr. Hariri the office. Under the Constitution and the 1989 Taif agreement -- brokered by the United States, Saudi Arabia and Syria to end the bloody sectarian war -- the president must be a Maronite Catholic and his prime minister a Sunni Moslem, to be named after binding talks with Parliament.
In practice, this usually means a number of hopefuls might assemble blocks of supporters, and Syria would weigh in, using its influence over Lebanese politicians to assemble a simple majority for its candidate. In the departing Parliament, Mr. Hariri had only a 14-member bloc and about 10 additional sympathizers.
But the rules are often flexible.
The impasse is the first major problem for Mr. Assad, a mild-mannered 34-year-old eye doctor and computer enthusiast who inherited leadership of Syria, along with the rank of lieutenant general and commander of the army, upon the death in June of his father, Hafez al-Assad, who had run both countries with ruthless skill.
And it is a particularly difficult impasse. Two years ago, the younger Mr. Assad was given responsibility over Lebanon as part of his training to assume leadership.
In his first exercise of power, he selected Mr. Lahoud, a military commander with no political base, to be president. This also, in effect, meant firing Mr. Hariri, who was detested by Mr. Lahoud but was a favorite of the Syrian officials who had been in charge of Lebanon: the longtime vice president, Abdul Halim Khaddam, and a military intelligence chief, Maj. Gen. Ghazi Kanaan.
For a week, the top-ranking Lebanese politicians have been trooping to Damascus to meet with Mr. Assad, as they had so often before been summoned by his father.
But the signals from Syria were far from clear. Some Beirut newspapers have reported that Damascus wanted no further electoral embarrassment to its loyal supporter, President Lahoud.
At the same time, however, the speaker of Parliament, Nabih Berri, leader of the Shiite Muslim Amal movement, who is noted for being acutely responsive to Syrian desires, returned from Damascus, stopping off to see General Kanaan at Syrian intelligence headquarters in the Bekaa region, and promptly announced that his joint Amal-Hezbollah ticket in the south would join in alliance with Mr. Hariri.
Mr. Hariri's forces are contesting 18 of the 19 seats in three districts in Beirut, the main battleground on Sunday, each reserved for a specific religious sect. Mr. Berri's 23 candidates on the Amal-Hezbollah ticket are expected to sweep the south, which was freed in May from more than 20 years of Israeli occupation, and Mr. Hariri should pick up a dozen or so Christian seats in the Bekaa and other places.
While political alliances in Lebanon are often fragile and shifting, sometimes in bloody ways, the current situation represents a major change. Broadly speaking, usually contending religious groups -- the basic political division here -- have been brought into an unusual alliance against the government.
Most notably, Walid Jumblatt, hereditary chieftain of the Druse, an offshoot of Islam, and a major ally of Mr. Hariri, has reached across the old civil war lines to befriend his former enemies on the Christian right.
Among them are former President Amin Gemeyal; Dori Chamoun, survivor of a leading Maronite family in the Chouf mountains with whom Mr. Jumblatt had battled; the supporters of the exiled former army general, Michel Aoun, who fought the last clash with the Syrians; and even the Christian warlord Samir Geagea, who has been jailed on multiple murder charges.
And there are even hints, until now unspeakable, of challenges to Syria's long domination. In a three-hour television interview the other night, Mr. Jumblatt said he was calling for "a correction of the relationship with Syria to be re-established on a balanced basis."

HEADLINE: Reservations With Casinos Gain Ground On Povety

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2

 BODY:
The Indian casino boom of the 1990's has helped decrease the historically high rates of poverty and unemployment on Indian reservations, a computer analysis has found.
The review of federal records by The Associated Press found that the explosive growth of the Indian gambling industry -- to $8.26 billion in 1998 from $100 million in 1988 -- has slowed the growth of welfare on reservations and given some tribes hope of reversing decades of poverty. 
 The influx of money has also set off a debate over whether the proceeds should go directly to tribal members or be invested in schools, housing and public works.
"If tribes are making all that money, members are asking, 'When am I going to see some of it?' " said Eddie Brown, who headed the Bureau of Indian Affairs during the Bush administration. "That pressure is beginning to build."
Among the 72 tribes with casinos that use the Agriculture Department's Food Distribution Program on Indian Reservations, household participation increased by 8.2 percent between 1990 to 1997. But that was far less than the 57.3 percent increase among the 44 tribes without Las Vegas-style casinos.
Similarly, the number of Indian households participating in the food stamp program in states that permit casino gambling increased 5.6 percent between 1990 and 1998. But in states that do not allow casinos, the number of Indian households using food stamps jumped 17.7 percent.
Mr. Brown said that in many cases the slower growth in welfare rolls for tribes with casinos could be traced to direct payments to tribal members from casino profits. The Fort McDowell Mohave-Apache Indian Community near Phoenix, he said, has become "welfare independent." Its 849 members receive up to $30,000 a year each in casino payments.
A total of 48 tribes have obtained approval from the Bureau of Indian Affairs to transfer casino profits directly to members. While the bureau refuses to provide details, payments range up to $900,000 a year for each of the more than 200 members of the Shakopee Mdewakanton Dakota Sioux Community in Minnesota.
Such direct payments can shrink welfare rolls, but many tribal leaders argue that the best way to attack poverty and unemployment is to invest in education and infrastructure.
At the 20,000-member Gila River Indian Community just south of Phoenix, tribal leaders have used more than $100 million in casino profits for capital improvements.
"We're committed to providing services to the community rather than the individual," said Donald Antone, the new Gila River governor.
Gila River now provides college or vocational-school scholarships to any member who meets academic standards. A $120 million resort hotel and golf course are scheduled to open over the next two years.
The Mille Lacs Band of Ojibwe in Minnesota followed a similar route, investing most profits from its two casinos in reservation programs, while paying members $1,500 a year.
But the band's nine-year leader was defeated in a landslide this summer by a candidate promising to abide by a referendum on increasing casino payments to members.
The Mille Lacs Band and the Gila River Community are two of 23 tribes across the country owning casinos that grossed more than $100 million in 1998. Those 23 together accounted for 56 percent of total Indian gambling revenues that year.
For the 80,000 Indians in those 23 tribes, about 5 percent of the Indian population, the effect of casino gambling has been substantial.
Unemployment among those 23 tribes dropped to 27.7 percent in 1997 from 34.5 percent in 1991, according to Bureau of Indian Affairs' records. The average poverty rate in counties that have reservations fell to 14.2 percent in 1995 from 16.7 percent in 1989; the median household income increased by 30 percent, to $31,153 from $23,937.
But tribal leaders say casino profits have just scratched the surface of the economic and social problems confronting their reservations.
On the 582-square-mile Gila River reservation, adobe houses without indoor plumbing or utilities still dot the landscape. Utility service has been provided to 500 new home sites since 1995, but hundreds remain on waiting lists for housing.
"We've been so far behind in everything that the money we're getting is almost like a drop in the bucket," Mr. Antone said.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE MEDICARE ISSUE;
No Simple Answers to Rising Cost of Drugs for the Elderly

BYLINE: By SHERYL GAY STOLBERG

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2

 BODY:
On the campaign stump, Vice President Al Gore pushes his plan for a Medicare prescription drug benefit as a humane effort to help older Americans who are being gouged by profit-hungry pharmaceutical manufacturers. In television commercials, Gov. George W. Bush's campaign characterizes the Gore plan as another example of bureaucracy run amok.
But presidential politics, where sound bites often trump substance, is far simpler than drug pricing, and beneath the candidates' harsh oratory lurk complex questions about the economics of drug advertising, the dynamics of price controls, and the budgets of research laboratories. 
 The answers will affect not only the elderly and taxpayers in general, but also the shape of the prescription drug business, one of the nation's most lucrative industries.
With more sophisticated and expensive medicines being introduced every year, a big question is whether Medicare will be able to afford them. The drug industry's trade group says the plan will inevitably run out of money, resulting in price controls, which could prompt cutbacks in research. But the drug companies typically spend more on advertising than they do on research, leading the vice president to suggest they can well afford a dip in prices.
"Unfortunately, this is not the kind of issue that bumper stickers are made of," said Gail R. Wilensky, who ran the Health Care Financing Administration, the agency that administers the Medicare program, under Mr. Bush's father when he was president. "The good news is we don't pass legislation in campaigns."
Pharmaceutical pricing legislation is fraught with unintended consequences. The last time Congress passed a bill it thought would lower drug prices was in 1990, when it required drug manufacturers to offer their lowest prices to the federal Medicaid program. The result, according to a 1996 study by the Congressional Budget Office, was that the manufacturers simply raised prices for health maintenance organizations. So the government paid less, but private insurers paid more.
With profits that rank consistently higher than other Fortune 500 companies and products that can cost tens of thousands of dollars a year, the drug industry has long been an easy target for politicians. Forty years ago, Estes Kefauver, the Democratic senator from Mr. Gore's home state of Tennessee, held hearings into the pricing practices of drug companies.
Perhaps no issue touches as many lives as the price of medication, which is one reason the issue is dominating the political debate. Another has to do with economics: while prescription drugs account for only 9 percent of all health care spending, they are now the fastest-growing segment of the national health bill.
In 1998, according to the Kaiser Family Foundation, Americans spent $91 billion on prescription medications; the total is expected to reach $243 billion in 2008. The elderly bear a disproportionate burden: they account for 13 percent of the population but more than a third of all drug spending, and nearly one-third of them lack insurance coverage.
Mr. Gore's plan to ease that burden is nearly identical to President Clinton's. Except for the poorest of the poor, the elderly would not have insurance covering the full cost of all their prescription drugs. Older Americans whose incomes are 135 percent of the poverty level or lower, about $12,000 a year for an individual and $14,000 for couples, would have all of their drug costs covered.
Others would pay premiums on a sliding scale, and would be reimbursed for half the cost of their prescriptions up to $5,000 a year. Once the $5,000 cap has been met, beneficiaries would pay out of pocket, up to an additional $1,500. After that, a catastrophic insurance provision would kick in, and the government would pay all additional drug bills.
The Gore campaign estimates the cost of the proposal at $253 billion over 10 years; an analysis by the Congressional Budget Office estimates the president's plan would cost $297 billion during that time. But the actual cost, Ms. Wilensky said, is extremely difficult to predict.
"Our ability to accurately project prescription drug costs, particularly if you say you are not going to have administered pricing -- that's the polite word for price controls -- is poor," Ms. Wilensky said.
A central feature of the Gore plan is that it offers a uniform benefit; in each region, all Medicare beneficiaries would be covered by the same plan, administered by a single pharmacy benefits manager under contract with Medicare.
That kind of government control worries the pharmaceutical industry. Mr. Gore's plan would effectively give Medicare vast purchasing power, enabling the government to extract deep discounts from drug makers. Medicare drug prices would then become public -- in the private sector, negotiated discounts are kept secret -- and private insurers would inevitably demand similar breaks.
"Medicare is the big gorilla," Prof. Uwe Reinhardt, the Princeton University health care economist, said in an interview last month. But with more people covered by insurance, he argued, the volume of prescriptions would rise, which would offset any decrease in prices.
Like most Republicans, Mr. Bush favors letting the private sector handle prescription drug coverage, an approach that has drawn criticism because many private insurers say they will not offer drug benefits. The Bush campaign has characterized the Gore proposal as a "one-size-fits-all plan" that would interfere with the authority of doctors, presumably by restricting the list of drugs covered by insurance.
In fact, said Robert D. Reischauer, president of the Urban Institute, a research organization in Washington, such restrictive lists, called formularies, are far more likely to emerge under the Republican approach. That is because the private sector would offer varied plans, giving consumers the opportunity to save money by choosing plans that restricted access.
Under Mr. Gore's plan, Mr. Reischauer said, "The notion that the government will choose your drugs is far from the reality that will evolve."
Mr. Bush will offer a specific prescription drug proposal next week, his campaign says. His aides have said he would incorporate a prescription drug benefit into an overhaul of the Medicare program, building on work of a bipartisan Congressional commission that has called for competition between the public and private sectors. The commission's proposal, which like the Gore plan would have the government absorb prescription drug costs for the very poor, has been introduced as legislation by Senators John B. Breaux, a Louisiana Democrat, and Bill Frist, a Tennessee Republican.
These two approaches -- a uniform Medicare benefits package versus a range of private sector plans -- reflect deep ideological differences between Democrats and Republicans about the proper role of government. Caught in the middle are the drug makers, who are siding with Mr. Bush. Since last year, according to an analysis by the Campaign Study Group, drug makers have contributed $235,515 to Mr. Bush compared with $50,700 for Mr. Gore.
During his campaign, the vice president has relentlessly attacked the companies as price gougers. But the forces that are driving prescription drug spending are complicated.
The increase, experts say, is not so much because manufacturers are raising prices on existing medicines but because patients are switching to newer medications that cost more. At the same time, more prescriptions are being written, because the population is aging and older people take more drugs.
And there is another possible explanation: advertising, according to Steven Findlay of the National Institute for Healthcare Management Foundation, a nonprofit research group. During campaign stops in Florida and Oregon this week, Mr. Gore has asserted, correctly, that many drug companies spend more on marketing than research. He singled out one of the most widely advertised medications, Claritin, the antihistamine by Schering-Plough.
Mr. Findlay is studying television advertising of prescription medicines, which has flourished since the regulations were relaxed three years ago. "The numbers are quite compelling," he said. "The drugs that are the most heavily advertised to consumers are the ones that are driving the increase in spending," he said.
Those figures raise more questions: Are some people taking costly prescription drugs when cheaper, over-the-counter ones will do? If so, who? And how can they and their doctors be persuaded to use medicines more cost-effectively?
There is scant literature on the topic, said John Golenski, executive director of RxHealth Value, a coalition of consumer, labor, business and insurance groups. "The question of what is appropriate from a medical perspective is more acute than it ever was," Mr. Golenski said, "and that question is not addressed by either party's plan."

HEADLINE: Globalization Tops 3-Day U.N. Agenda For World Leaders

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE

 BODY:
The stormy battle over globalization that brought protests to the streets of Seattle and Washington moves this week to the heart of the world's only truly global organization, the United Nations.
An extraordinary, three-day summit meeting of more than 150 world leaders called to thrash out problems of poverty and peace is turning instead into a debate about the future of the organization, as well as the world, at a time when national boundaries have become nearly as irrelevant to economic and political tides as they are to infectious diseases or popular music. 
 The summit meeting, which will begin Wednesday and end Friday, is the pivotal event in a two-week, traffic-stopping extravaganza for New York that began last week with a conference of world religious leaders, an assembly of scores of speakers from nearly all the world's elected parliaments and a meeting of hundreds of nongovernmental organizations from every continent.
A dozen or more other events are planned for the fringes this week, including a "dialogue of civilizations" featuring President Mohammad Khatami of Iran, a "state of the world forum" of government and private sector leaders, numerous street protests and a 10-hour teach-in against a greater role for global business in world affairs.
The United Nations is a more diversified organization than those that have been the focus of recent protests -- the World Bank, the International Monetary Fund and the World Trade Organization.
So it is still seen as a hope for solving problems of globalization, rather than as a source of them, and it is not expected to be subjected to the same heated demonstrations that caused so much havoc in Washington and Seattle. Still, the debate over globalization will be intense.
At the United Nations, globalization means many things to many people. It is not simply the greater movement of goods, jobs and capital across borders, but also includes equally important cultural, environmental and political components.
For some countries, most in the industrial world, globalization is an opportunity to expand international standards in law, social development and human rights. For others, many of them developing countries, it holds out the worrying prospect of a United Nations aligning itself ever more closely with new power centers: the big corporations, high technology gurus and cultural icons of the industrialized world.
But unlike other summit meetings, the one here will give the fears and frustrations of the world's smallest and weakest nations equal time alongside the powerful, whose governments and -- increasingly -- corporations are feared for the influence they seem to be gaining inside the organization.
President Clinton, who will give the opening address and stay for three days, will be followed to the podium by the president of Equatorial Guinea. Russia's president will be followed by the leader of the Maldives, who likes to remind others that the big worry for his tiny nation of atolls is that globalization could mean disappearing completely -- if the warming of the world's climate is not halted.
"Globalization is seen by some as a force for social change, that it will help to close the gap between the rich and the poor, the industrialized north and the developing south," said Theo-Ben Gurirab, the foreign minister of Namibia and the General Assembly president for the last year.
"But it also is being seen as a destructive force because it is being driven by the very people, the colonial powers, who launched a global campaign of imperial control of peoples and resources in what we call now the third world. Can we trust them?"
Secretary General Kofi Annan, a Ghanaian with an American education who straddles two worlds, is at the center of the debate.
"Globalization is really defining our era," he said in an interview, explaining why he forged alliances with multinational corporations to improve labor and environmental standards as well as to bridge cyberspace gaps between the industrial and developing worlds.
He also warns political leaders that they have to govern well and learn to take advantage of international opportunities or their fragile economies are doomed. He argues that when citizens of any country are abused, the rulers can no longer tell others to stay out of their affairs.
"It's not that the secretary general is changing things too fast," Mr. Annan said, ranging over topics of relevance to the United Nations as varied as genetically modified foods or intellectual property rights. "The world around us is changing, and we change with it or we will be left behind. We have to adapt to the realities outside."
Mark Malloch Brown, administrator of the United Nations Development Program, said the organization cannot ignore economic changes at a time when government aid has shrunk and international organizations have to look for new sources of money.
"At the end of the day," he said, "everybody has to acknowledge that the primary source of finance for development is going to come out of the private portion of the global and national economy."
Within the United Nations system, some officials are concerned that overtures to giant corporations and multinational industries from the top of the organization will set the stage for problems at lower levels. There are rules of engagement for working with governments, one official said, but there are no guidelines for working with businesses or independent advocacy groups.
Powerful corporations, encouraged by an open door in the secretary general's office, have the means to introduce corrupt arrangements or to pay for special favors among lower-ranking officials, including the handing over of insider information like unpublished research findings, some United Nations employees fear. Such acts would be easier to conceal than overt pressure from governments, which is a constant problem in the organization.
Mr. Annan's "global compact" -- a program intended to enhance cooperation between the United Nations and private corporations on things like labor standards and the environment -- has drawn the strongest criticism from American groups opposed to globalization, among them the Transnational Resource and Action Center in San Francisco.
Its director, Joshua Karliner, said the image of the secretary general standing beside the top executives of companies with bad reputations in the developing world sent the wrong message about the United Nations, and could make it a target of protest. Mr. Karliner's organization is part of the International Forum on Globalization, which is sponsoring the 10-hour teach-in at Town Hall in Manhattan, beginning at 1 p.m on Tuesday.
Debi Barker, deputy director of the forum, said in an interview that the teach-in follows similar events in Seattle and Washington, where the targets were the World Trade Organization, the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund. "The U.N., unlike the W.T.O., the World Bank and the I.M.F., was really created to be a space to promote peace, human rights, the environment, social justice, livelihoods and democracy," she said. "This is a worthy institution and these are worthy goals.
"We are concerned that things such as the global compact, encroaching its way into the U.N., means that the U.N. is being usurped a bit by corporations and by people who are driving this globalization agenda. We would encourage the U.N. to take the high road; keep to its mandate; separate itself from corporations and deal instead with citizens."
Carol Bellamy, the executive director of Unicef, the United Nations Children's Fund, said that in the confrontation over globalization there has been an unfortunate tendency to adopt extreme views about business and that these get in the way of exploring new ways of cooperating with the private sector.
Ms. Bellamy, a former American Peace Corps director and New York City politician, has been wrestling recently with critics who want the Children's Fund to break ties with international corporations contributing to the organization. "The world demands a more sophisticated response today," she said.
"An outright rejection of globalization is a head-in-the-sand approach," she said in an interview, adding that the goals of international aid organizations may often coincide, at least in part, with those of business.
"The business community needs peace to see economic growth," she said. "They need kids to be educated to be consumers and workers. The rule of law, good governance, is important for creating an environment that will probably also be good for investment."
Mr. Malloch Brown of the United Nations Development Program says the debate about globalization in richer countries clouds the fact that a significant number of political leaders and nongovernmental organizations in developing nations are not opposed to a more interdependent world economy. They just want to be part of it, and they want it to be more sensitive to the needs of those least able to compete.
Mr. Annan, responding to frustration about the pace and effects of globalization in the developing world, said he had asked the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development to work on ways to assist smaller nations in analyzing and simplifying complex economic and trade agreements so that they can benefit.
"It has been said that arguing against globalization is like arguing against the laws of gravity," Mr. Annan told the international conference of nongovernmental organizations last week. "But that does not mean we should accept a law that allows only heavyweights to survive. On the contrary, we must make globalization an engine that lifts people out of hardship and misery, not a force that holds them down."
The United Nations expects all the world's major powers to be represented at the summit meeting, and will make an effort to limit their formal speeches to five minutes each, with unlimited time for more informal talking later.
In addition to President Clinton, President Jiang Zemin of China will attend, as will President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, President Jacques Chirac of France and Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain.
Leaders of most African nations, including Olusegun Obasanjo of Nigeria, will speak. President Abdurrahman Wahid of Indonesia is coming, as are Prime Minister Ehud Barak of Israel and the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat. Fidel Castro, the Cuban leader, is also planning to come.
Shadowing the United Nations summit meeting will be the fifth annual State of the World Forum, a private gathering at the New York Hilton of more than 500 prominent figures in finance, labor, science and government. Speakers include Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the former Soviet president; Thabo Mbeki, president of South Africa; Gen. Colin L. Powell, former chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff; the financier and philanthropist George Soros, and John Sweeney, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O.
When the summit meeting ends, there will be commitments to some very ambitious goals, part of an action plan advertised on billboards around New York. World leaders will pledge to halve the number of the world's people who live on less than $1 a day. There are more than a billion of them. Almost an equal number -- many of the same people -- do not have access to clean water.
Their number should also be halved by 2015. By that year, leaders will pledge to have given all children a full primary school education. To show determination in the battle against H.I.V. and AIDS, the leaders will be asked to halt and reverse the spread of the disease by 2015.
