HEADLINE: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK;
Turnaround in Texas: Two Teams Plunge

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
A certain Texas officeholder who is a candidate for office elsewhere has to hope that he will fare better in his race than the state's two major league baseball teams have this year in theirs.
The Texas Rangers and the Houston Astros have had remarkably similar experiences. Winners of three division championships in the past four years but not advancing beyond the first round of the playoffs in any of those years, the Rangers and the Astros both lost key players, voluntarily or involuntarily, last winter and both have spent most of the season in last place. 
 One of the few bright spots for each team has been a player who has broken the franchise's record for hitting in consecutive games. But their season will not be remembered for the feats of Gabe Kapler and Tony Eusebio. The season will be remembered for the great plunge.
"It must have something to do with the drought we're having in Texas," Gerry Hunsicker, the Astros' general manager, said.
"Yeah, it's been a rough year in Texas," said Doug Melvin, the Rangers' general manager, referring to baseball, not weather. "Things just didn't go as planned. I think with both of us it was the cost of having success, the cost of winning divisions."
The Rangers last year had the second highest payroll; only the Yankees paid their players more. They began this season as No. 9, having lowered their payroll from $81.6 million to $70.8 million. The Astros ended last season 11th in payroll ($55 million) and began this season 19th ($51 million).
During the winter, the Rangers traded Juan Gonzalez and lost, not all willingly, Todd Zeile, Aaron Sele, Mark McLemore and Tom Goodwin as free agents. The Astros traded Mike Hampton, Carl Everett and Derek Bell and let Ricky Gutierrez leave as a free agent.
"Winning once you can get by," Melvin said, speaking of the economics of success. "We won three of four; they won three in a row. Your payroll goes sky high. The salaries continue to escalate."
Hunsicker acknowledged that the Astros made moves partly for economic reasons. They also wanted to make room for some younger players they thought were ready, he said.
Addressing the economic part, he said: "We have a budget and we have to live within our means, even moving into a new stadium. A player like Rickey Gutierrez was probably missed more than we anticipated. He's a player we undervalued."
"We didn't strengthen ourselves with the moves we made during the winter," he added. "But I expected the team to contend in our division. A lot of people point to the off-season moves as the beginning of our demise. I don't share those opinions. I think the lineup we put on the field had the potential to be as good as the '98 team, which was the best offensively in the history of the franchise."
The Astros' pitching, Hunsicker said, was a question mark going in. But, he said: "It's been a question mark for this franchise every year. But every year we've had people rise to the occasion and perform above expectations. More and more I think that's what has to happen for clubs to win. Pitching has to exceed expectations."
No one expected the Astros' pitchers to suffer the major shock that accompanied the move from the Astrodome to Enron Field.
"I think the new park has had a greater effect on our club than anticipated," Hunsicker said. "No club can win without a home-field advantage. In the first half it wasn't an advantage for us. We've played much better since then at home. Pitchers are adapting more to the ballpark, realizing that it is realistic to pitch well in this park. You just don't have the margin for error you have in other parks."
The Astros have gone from having one of the most efficient pitching staffs in the league (3.83 earned run average) to having the least efficient (5.33) and from allowing the fewest home runs (128) to being among the leaders in giving up the most (184). The pitchers haven't been helped by the defense, which has already committed more errors (110) than last season (106).
"Our record would be better if we hadn't made any moves in the off-season," Hunsicker said, "but I would be hard pressed to think we'd be in first place or close to first given the breakdowns we've had in key areas."
The Rangers ended last season with eight players who could be free agents.
"We had a chance to be older and more expensive," Melvin said. "For us to keep the players that helped us win the past two years we probably would have had a $95 million payroll with players on long-term contracts. We would have had to stay at 95 for a good two or three years. That's why we felt we had to make some moves."
Trading Gonzalez was the biggest decision the Rangers had to make, but failing to sign Zeile and Sele, the free agents they wanted to retain, hurt the most.
"Sele kept turning me down on $28 million," Melvin said, referring to his four-year offer to the pitcher who subsequently signed with Seattle for two years and $15 million. "I wasn't aggressive on Zeile early on. I didn't go to a third year until the last minute."
As a result of the absent players, Melvin said: "We have not been nearly as good as a team. We took some risks and ended up relying on a lot of ifs. In the past we had been a solid veteran team. We knew what players were going to do for us. This year we went a lot based on potential. It didn't happen. Then we had injuries."
Melvin, in comparing these developments, said: "Last year we won 95 games, had the best year in franchise history and lost 10 to 12 million dollars. This year we have a chance to have the worst record in a long time, and they tell me we can break even."
 
Milestones Are in Reach
Can Darin Erstad break George Sisler's major league record for hits? Can Todd Helton become the first player to hit .400 since Ted Williams in 1941? Can Carlos Delgado become the first Triple Crown winner since Carl Yastrzemski in 1967?
Seldom has there been a season in which three such sterling offensive achievements were within reach in the final four weeks.
Erstad: The Anaheim hit man has 205 hits. With 27 games remaining, he would basically have to average 1.926 hits a game to tie Sisler's record of 257 in 1920, 1.963 to break it. Given the difficulty of registering such averages, Erstad would settle for two hits a game.
Helton: He is hitting .391 after a hitless game yesterday. If, in the Rockies' final 27 games, he averaged 3.62 at-bats a game, his average for his first 133 games this season, he would have to get 44 hits to finish at .40069, or .401. Forty-three hits would take him only to .399 (.39896).
Delgado: The Toronto first baseman is second in the American League in hitting at .362, tied for second in runs batted in with 124 and tied for first in home runs with 39. Nomar Garciaparra of Boston is ahead of him in average at .366, and Erstad is right behind at .361. He is four R.B.I. behind Edgar Martinez of Seattle, tied with Mike Sweeney of Kansas City and just ahead of Frank Thomas of Chicago (122). He is tied in home runs with Thomas and Troy Glaus of Anaheim.
 
One-Hit Wonders
Pedro Martinez, as usual, was so overwhelming in his start against Tampa Bay last Tuesday that his one-hit performance (John Flaherty's leadoff single in the ninth inning) overshadowed performances in other games that night. The Devil Rays were not the only team to get only one hit that night. They were, in fact, only one of three teams that got only one hit that night.
A one-out single by Barry Bonds in the first inning was the only hit San Francisco managed against Pittsburgh (Kris Benson eight innings, Josias Manzanillo one inning). James Mouton's two-run home run in the sixth inning was the lone Milwaukee hit against Los Angeles (Chan Ho Park eight, Mike Fetters one).
The last time one day's schedule produced three games in which teams got no more than one hit, according to the Elias Sports Bureau, was Sept. 24, 1988. Cleveland had one hit against Dave Stieb of Toronto, Texas one hit against Mark Langston of Seattle and Philadelphia no hits against Pascual Perez of Montreal in a rain-shortened five-inning game.
 
Making an Appointment?
Arthur Richman, the senior adviser in the Yankees' media relations department, has a special interest in the outcome of the presidential contest between George W. Bush, former managing partner of the Texas Rangers, and Al Gore.
Richman said he told Bush five years ago that he would someday be president of the United States. After asking him what he was smoking, Richman, a friend of the Bush family, said that Bush told him, "If I become president, I'm going to appoint you my good-will ambassador to the world."
Richman has his passport ready.

HEADLINE: Annual West Indian Parade Set for Alcohol-Free Revelry

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER

 BODY:
Revelers at the West Indian American Carnival Parade tomorrow will accept, although grudgingly, a ban on alcohol at their festivities, organizers say.
And the New York City Police Department, to enforce the restrictions, will increase its presence there. 
 "We are not happy, but we are going along," said Carlos Lezama, president of the West Indian American Day Carnival Association, "because we are Caribbeanites and Caribbeanites are law-abiding citizens."
The parade, along Eastern Parkway in Brooklyn, is one of the most popular ethnic celebrations in New York City, drawing roughly 2 million people each Labor Day. But preparations have been peppered with unpleasantness in recent weeks.
Early last month, the city announced a ban on alcohol sales at all outdoor festivals, including parades, restrictions that have been in effect at the St. Patrick's Day Parade in Manhattan for years. This angered West Indian American Carnival Parade organizers, who said such a ban would cause many of their sponsors to drop out.
Their anger increased when the city backed down somewhat on that ban, saying that the Feast of San Gennaro, an 11-day festival in Little Italy that starts later this month, would be allowed to sell alcohol, although with a reduced number of vendors. It is not yet clear how the city will handle restrictions on alcohol at subsequent festivals.
Parade and community leaders contended that the inconsistency was unfair and strongly hinted that race played a role in the policy decision, a charge Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani firmly denied. The ban on alcohol was largely inspired by the disorder following the National Puerto Rican Day Parade in June, when more than 50 women were sexually attacked.
"I think it is tunnel vision enforcement of what may be a good provision," said Representative Major J. Owens, a Brooklyn Democrat. "The community thinks it is being unfairly treated, but everyone is ready to cooperate. What matters is that the festival be preserved."
In addition to the alcohol ban, myriad other safety-related changes that will probably be less visible to spectators were ordered by the city. Mayor Giuliani ordered some of the changes after two 11-year-olds and an 18-year-old man were killed at the parade last year. The children were hit by a supply van that lurched out of control and pinned them against a sound truck. The man was killed hours later, when he backed away from a snake held by a spectator and was crushed by a truck after a piece of his clothing got caught in one of its wheels.
Parade organizers and city officials agreed to a number of provisions to improve safety. Floats are supposed to be modified to give drivers better visibility, and police officers will be assigned to cars and sound trucks to control spacing between the floats. Everything on wheels will require authorization.
The list goes on: wheel covers are required for trucks and floats, animals like snakes that might frighten spectators will not be permitted, and the number of vendors will be restricted to curtail overcrowding. Spectators will be asked not to dance randomly in the streets or to board floats that are in motion.
Chief of Department Joseph J. Esposito said the police detail would be "adequately increased because there are more things to do now," but declined to give details.
Community leaders said that while the ban on alcohol would not dampen the fun of the parade, which runs along Eastern Parkway from Utica Avenue to Grand Army Plaza, it did make the economics of the event trickier.
"This carnival brings in resources to the city of New York," said Una Clarke, a city councilwoman from Brooklyn. "So it needs more government support, which should subsidize part of the expense so band leaders and costume makers would be able to get the material they need and not spend September doing parties that include the sale of alcohol. And the fact is they have sponsors who also sell alcohol that want to know that there is a return on their investment in promoting it."
Ms. Clarke stopped short of criticizing City Hall. "I am an elected leader in the community and have to display accountability," she said. "I don't have to hit the mayor over his head for everything that is done."
Another point of tension that did not directly involve the city emerged when members of three steel-drum bands planning to compete for prize money during events leading up to the parade were evicted from their practice site late last month.
The landlord of the building housing a warehouse on Parkside Avenue in Brooklyn said the groups had not paid rent to store their equipment and practice there, and the bands have since taken to the streets, where they have also been sleeping, to guard their instruments.

HEADLINE: AUGUST 27-SEPTEMBER 2;
Crime Continues to Decline

BYLINE: By Warren E. Leary

 BODY:
Violent crime in the United States dropped last year to its lowest level since the government began its annual national crime survey 26 years ago. Law enforcement officials credited crime-prevention programs, anti-gun campaigns, more police on the street, tougher sentencing and a healthy economy producing jobs. The rate of violent crime declined 10.4 percent in 1999, the Justice Department said, while crimes against property dropped 8.9 percent. But there still were an estimated 28.8 million violent and property crimes committed last year. Warren E. Leary 
http://www.nytimes.com

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

SECTION: Section 14; Page 3; Column 1; The City Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1326 words

HEADLINE: CITY LORE;
Yes! It's Him! (Whaddya Mean, Never Heard of Him?)

BYLINE: By GEORGE F. CUSTEN; George F. Custen, a resident of Park Slope, is director of the film studies program at the City University Graduate Center and author of "20th Century's Fox: Darryl F. Zanuck and the Culture of Hollywood."

 BODY:
Despite their statistical rarity, the famous seem to be everywhere in New York. So residents take it for granted that from time to time, they will come face to face with someone famous.
Naturally, then, in this celebrity-conscious realm, I was not surprised when I recently sighted someone of fame under water. Swimming laps in my neighborhood gym, I saw alongside me Courtney B. Vance, star of John Guare's celebrity-themed play "Six Degrees of Separation." 
 Shortly after, from behind the wheel of my Jeep, I found myself staring into a rather mad pair of eyes, which, I soon realized, belonged to John Turturro. This performance was far more powerful than his tour de force in the film "Barton Fink." In this instance, however, the Method had not motivated Mr. Turturro. Here, the likely cause was that I had nearly run him over.
But wait. I must tell you: these celebrity sightings were not in Manhattan, the spot most people mean when they talk of New York and fame. They were in my neighborhood of Park Slope, Brooklyn. Can it be that my borough is now full of the famous, too?
Alas, no chance. My encounters with Mr. Vance and Mr. Turturro notwithstanding, the fame game in Brooklyn is far, far different than Manhattan's. Here are some of the distinctions.
 
The Lorenz Hart Principle
It is true that the artist Joseph Cornell seemed so attached to Queens that he could rarely bring himself to leave his house (let alone the borough). And it is true that Henry Miller insisted that outside Brooklyn, the rest of the country didn't "exist for me, except as idea, or history or literature." But most people, certainly most famous people, prefer Lorenz Hart's spin: whether born there or not, they would have Manhattan.
In fact, stargazing there is like fishing for trout in a stream that is constantly being restocked. Manhattanites go forth armed with confidence fueled by celebrity options closed off to Brooklynites.
 
The Second-Tier Rule
Still, many famous people at least had the good sense to be born in Brooklyn; you can trample upon their names at the Botanical Garden's Walk of Fame. And many writers present and past, from Paul Auster to Marianne Moore, have chosen to live in or near my neighborhood alone.
But even with such celebrity richness in our midst, Brooklynites are loath to compare their borough's celebrities to Manhattan's. The reason: Brooklyn's leading lights are relatively dim. While Manhattan friends of my teenage years plotted ways to foil hotel security and meet the Rolling Stones, my youthful nights were spent wondering, could the same Beverly Road building in which my Brooklyn aunt and uncle lived also shelter, as was rumored, a being the stature of Shecky Green, the prince of Borscht Belt comedy?
There are exceptions, but a Brooklyn star search is akin to being trapped in a world where many stars resemble the misfit entertainers in the Woody Allen movie "Broadway Danny Rose." Many of Brooklyn's big names are the one-hit wonders, baseball players with career batting averages under .215, people related to someone famous (like Scott Baio's cousin, whose picture gazed down on me from the wall of a Bay Ridge restaurant) and former eminences like Helen Morgan, the star of 20's musicals like "Show Boat," who arrive in Brooklyn when they are sadly down on their luck.
A radical minority go so far as to insist that Brooklyn's specialty is not celebrities at all but their mothers. Their numbers include Mrs. Murphy (Yo! Eddie's mama), Konigsberg (Woody Allen), Streisand, Schrift (Shelley Winters), Moore (Mary Tyler's mom), Marrener (Susan Hayward's mom) and Cansino (Rita Hayworth).
 
Celebrity Drift
After their birth, many celebrities indeed continue to live in Brooklyn; for a time. The trajectory of F. Murray Abraham (the Park Slope Oscar winner who got his statuette playing a jealous composer in "Amadeus") illustrates this rule: truly successful celebrities move to Manhattan. Exceptions to the celebrity-migration law -- Louis Armstrong was a longtime resident of Queens -- do exist. But they are rare.
 
The Deli Connection
Brooklyn is densely populated by a unique celebrity genus: those show-biz pod people whose names and rictus-smiling, toupee-rich, airbrushed photos adorn the walls of many establishments. No one has ever heard of them. Fewer still have ever seen them in the flesh. No one (except, perhaps, Joe Franklin) has ever witnessed one of their performances. Yet, they possess one of celebrityhood's undeniable markers: their head shots, complete with inscriptions, hang near the cash register in every diner, deli or dry cleaner in Kings County.
There is yet another breed of Brooklyn celebrity, as exemplified by my Brooklyn-born great-aunt. She enjoyed a kind of power that came to few souls in any borough. Though not great herself, she was so proximate to greatness that it was hard to distinguish pilot fish from shark. Her aura rested on a single powerful connection. It was rumored, frequently by her, that she and my grandmother Bessie enjoyed triumphant evenings playing cards in the Bronx with no less a figure than "la mamma di Schnozzola." In Brooklyn, this putative link to Mrs. Durante was, for a time, enough to make my once-removed aunt a kind of celebrity, only twice removed.
All these ruminations forced me to face the sad truth: Brooklyn attracts celebrities who are not true celebrities. Manhattan gets nights of a thousand stars; we get the flights of fading stars.
 
"What Is He Doing Here?"
Brooklyn's great virtue may be that indeed, it is a real place whose people stand in admirable relief to the poseurs and mannequins inhabiting some Manhattan neighborhoods. Yet we nevertheless all hold celebrities to a different standard. Whatever our envy-laden carpings, we expect their demeanor, financial status, place of domicile and the sites they frequent to be more glamorous than ours. So, when we see them hopping out of a Manhattan bistro, fine. But when we bump into them in Brooklyn, we feel as if they have violated some modern-day version of the infamous studio-era morals clause in their contracts. We get suspicious. Long accustomed to seeing media representations of Brooklyn in which every citizen is a Ralph Kramden or a character played by William Bendix, the rootedness of such gods in our humble beloved turf makes them seem out of place.
The significance of the Brooklyn celebrity connection was doubly brought home to me by a neighbor who, though he requested anonymity, attained his stature via a continuing role in the HBO hit series "The Sopranos." Recently, several fans spotted him not only in Brooklyn, but in line in the unemployment office. The rapture of recognition quickly turned to suspicion. What, he was asked, would a real star be doing with them, on the unemployment line?
Brooklynites should not conclude they are wanting in the fame department, however. For the greatest concentration of eminent New Yorkers is far removed from Manhattan's bright lights. They have left the city for soothing and peaceful Brooklyn venues: its many fine cemeteries.
Passing through the massive iron gates of Green-Wood Cemetery, which sprawls between Windsor Terrace and Sunset Park, you enter a world of improbable gatherings: Horace Greeley chats with Lola Montez, while Boss Tweed skulks in the background in full view of Samuel F. B. Morse and an entire entombment of piano-manufacturing Steinways.
A short distance to the west, Montgomery Clift has been sighted (again!) in Prospect Park, or rather in the Quaker Cemetery in the park's northeast section. As befitting a deity, this former resident of Manhattan now receives callers beneath a grave designed by the architect of President Kennedy's shrine at Arlington.
In this light, the title of one of Thomas Wolfe's best-known short stories, "Only the Dead Know Brooklyn," is more prescient than that Brooklyn-hater knew.

LENGTH: 1422 words

HEADLINE: A Life on Page 1

BYLINE: By Ben Macintyre; Ben Macintyre is the United States editor of The Times of London.

 BODY:

 The Prince
 Of Tennessee
 The Rise of Al Gore.
 By David Maraniss
 and Ellen Nakashima.
 323 pp. New York:
 Simon & Schuster. $23. 
 Al Gore can balance quite large objects -- tennis rackets, umbrellas, coat hangers, that sort of thing -- on the end of his nose. This unlikely acrobatic skill, perfected when he was a St. Albans schoolboy, tends to find expression when the vice president is bored or keen to defuse a situation, but it is also an apt motif for a life spent juggling rival forces, internal, familial and political. In this fine, deep-mine biography, David Maraniss, an associate editor at The Washington Post, and Ellen Nakashima, a staff reporter there, depict Gore's personality as a remarkable balancing act: parental pressure pulling against personal inclination, the rural son of Tennessee at odds with the cosmopolitan princeling of the Fairfax Hotel, the dreamy idealist and the hard-punching political pro, self-doubt struggling with self-righteousness, "competing characteristics of farsightedness and caution, selflessness and self-aggrandizement, that have defined him, for better and worse, during his political career."
Gore called his 1992 manifesto on environmentalism "Earth in the Balance"; an alternative title for "The Prince of Tennessee" might be "A Life in the Balance." The balance is not always comfortable, and the authors depict a character far more complex and conflicted than the man he would succeed in the White House. Where Maraniss's essential biography of Bill Clinton, "First in His Class," was painted in great swaths of color, this is more a work of pointillism, myriad small dots of reportage brought together to form a vivid portrait.
The shaping of the Gore biography started before his birth. "If I have a baby boy, I don't want the news buried on an inside page," Albert Gore, the father-senator, told the Washington bureau of The Tennessean. "I want it on Page 1, where it belongs."
Gore has spent his entire life on Page 1; he was raised to belong there. When he was 6 his parents were already planting media stories of his precocity, showcasing "another Gore on the way toward the political pinnacle." Perhaps unsurprisingly, given these circumstances, at every critical stage in his life Gore seems to have been aware of an unseen but omnipresent biographer, hovering behind his shoulder, taking notes. "I was a real little politician," he once said, somewhat sadly, of his own childhood. From the earliest years almost every strategic decision, in the authors' phrase, appears to have been underpinned by "thinking politically on a longer arc."
So Gore went to Vietnam, to take part in a war of which he passionately disapproved, because it would make a bad impression and damage his father's already struggling senatorial campaign if he did not. He kept his distance from the tumult of antiwar protest at Harvard, "taking into account not just his feelings at the moment, but also how his actions might affect the political futures of himself or his father." When his father made him work in the Tennessee tobacco fields, was that good farming or just good politics?
There are other, less familiar but equally telling examples of Gore's compulsive self-scrutiny. In 1971, Gore was not attacked by a bear during a camping trip in Yosemite. The Gores had failed to heed warnings and left a half-eaten candy bar in their tent when they fell asleep. Sure enough, a brown bear came into the campsite, clawed the Gore tent and then wandered off again, having signally failed to change the course of history. To anyone else, this might be an opportunity for self-deprecating reminiscence, but not to Gore, who declined to tell the story when urged to, according to a friend, because "he couldn't stand to look bad in front of a group of people." The environmentalist could not be seen to be ignorant on the subject of ursine eating habits.
Someone who senses possible political danger in a half-eaten Snickers dating back three decades is not an easy character to pin down. It is perhaps this restraint, rather than his well-publicized self-inflations and midcampaign image adjustments, that explains why voters still feel they do not know Gore. How well can you know someone so adept at self-projection and protection, whose guard never seems to come down?
Maraniss and Nakashima have come closer to the core Gore than any other biographers to date. They reveal a man of intensely competitive urges, impelled by a Calvinist fear of chaos, plagued by doubts, exceptionally competent and confident but uneasy in his own skin, indefatigable, loyal and loyalty-inspiring yet also somewhat lonely.
There is a scientific literalness in the Gore mentality as described here, an absolute faith in the power of pure information that comes close to obsession. He may not have invented the Internet, but at times Gore speaks and behaves as if the Internet had invented him. "Everything came down to facts -- more than parliamentary skill or emotion or personality or intuition or chemistry or poetry or even wealth, pre-eminent was the raw data that comprised information." There is little of that quality Keats admired, "when a man is capable of being in uncertainties, mysteries, doubts, without any irritable reaching after fact." A highly trained political animal with an expansive mind and an instinct for the jugular, he yet appears quirkless in his adult life, lacking the edges that give form to character. Although people who know him well consistently vouch for Gore's black and understated sense of humor, there are no memorable examples in this book.
Underneath this often unflattering picture, the authors have identified the contours of an earlier, more attractive portrait, now obscured by successive layers of political veneer: a romantic soul who likes to sing loudly and drive wildly, who profoundly believes there is a right way and wants to find it, a personality so charged and pent up that when he tells his uncertain wife, for the first time, that he is running for political office, he immediately hits the floor and begins doing push-ups. The very rawness of this internal drive inspires admiration, if not necessarily affection.
"Always do right," Gore's father reportedly told his only son as he lay dying. If true, these are strange last words; not a release or a farewell, nor yet an expression of love, but a quotable injunction, another order. You can almost hear the invisible biographer scribbling away. Albert Gore Sr. looms over every page of "The Prince of Tennessee," a white-haired Shakespearean patriarch demanding obedience and dedication, even in death; more insistently in death. The old man's astonishment and anger when his son's first presidential campaign was rocked by the issue of pot smoking is one of the most telling episodes in a deeply formal relationship, fraught with unspoken tension. Plainly it had never occurred to the father that his son could do something that might jeopardize the presidential plan.
For sure, there was little enough devilry in the young scion. Indeed, so heavy is the weight of paternal expectation, of destiny foretold, that at times he almost seems to lack a will of his own, his own instincts obscured by the overriding commandment to "do right." Thus we find his wife, Tipper, as Gore is debating whether to go to Vietnam, pleading with him: "What do you really think and how are you going to feel if you do this?"
"The Prince of Tennessee" achieves what Gore himself has found so difficult on the stump, by rounding him out into a full character, neither the wooden bore depicted by his enemies nor the perfect prince that his father forged and he has always tried to be. Gore's sense of balance has made him a formidable politician: stable, agile, unflappable, a master of policy and a superb debater. But it may also have suppressed some of the humanity within. The prince born to be president was so busy looking ahead to the prize -- amassing all the facts, doing right, projecting the correct image, blending belief and calculation, trimming the message to the audience and circumstance -- that his sense of self somehow got buried. The famously stiff and distant campaigner is also the one who asks insistently: "How'd I do? How'd I do?"
The impression given here is of a man who knows almost everything about almost everything except his own personality. If Al Gore wants to get to know himself better, he would be well advised to read this book.

LENGTH: 1318 words

HEADLINE: All Work and How About Some Play, Too?

BYLINE: By NICOLE ITANO

 BODY:
AT Yarde Metals, an aluminum and steel distributor based in Bristol, children and dogs sometimes go to work and employees can occasionally be found napping on the job.
None of this bothers Craig Yarde, the company's owner and founder, who runs his $115-million-a-year company from a desk in the same large room used by the sales and administrative staff in his central office. He said his company's unusual workplace policies inspire employee loyalty and increase productivity. 
 "The only turnover we have is the turnover that we force," Mr. Yarde said. Mr. Yarde, 48, is a 60's-style idealist. He believes in profit sharing, family-friendly workplaces, and, in a move that garnered a great deal of attention, coed bathrooms.
While most companies around the state will still expect their employees' dogs and children be left at home when they return to work after this Labor Day weekend, an increasing number of Connecticut employers are, like Mr. Yarde, recognizing the role of workplace environment in attracting and retaining quality employees. Many of these companies, particularly those in the technology sector, are taking unusual steps to ensure their employees stay happy, healthy and loyal.
"Companies are having to be more innovative and creative at retaining workers," said Marjorie Bynum, vice president of the Information Technology Association of America. "Salary is important, but it's not the most important thing. Quality of life is really vital as well."
In Connecticut, where unemployment rates are at nearly half the national average, competition for employees is particularly stiff. In a survey of small- and medium-sized business conducted last year by the Connecticut Business and Industry Association, more than 80 percent of respondents said they had difficulty finding qualified workers. Forty-eight percent said they had great or extreme difficulty finding qualified employees.
A number of companies, in both the Internet and traditional markets, are responding to the labor shortage by changing workplace rules to make offices more relaxed and fun. Workplace rules have relaxed and increasing numbers of companies are throwing social events during working hours, allowing casual dress and providing on-site facilities such as kitchenettes, gyms and even nap rooms.
"Employers are trying to make the workplace almost home-like because they know that workers spend so much time there," Ms. Bynum said.
According to a study by the United Nations, the number of hours the average American worked over the course of a year increased by almost 100 between 1980 and 1997.
According to a study by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, between 1976 and 1993, the number of non-agricultural workers working more than 49 hours a week increased from 13 percent of the work force to almost 20 percent. And that shift is concentrated among professionals.
In the Stamford offices of iSolve.com, an Internet company that helps businesses sell or trade their excess inventory, most Friday afternoons are devoted to an office-sponsored social event such as a cappuccino bar or pretzel and beer party.
Barbara Serf, iSolve's executive vice president of marketing, said the events are important to office morale because with the company's fast growth -- they have hired more than 65 employees since November -- the informal get-togethers are one of the only ways people in the company can meet each other.
"These social events are important so that people get to know each other's names," Ms. Serf said. "In the dot-com world everyone is trying to pay competitive salaries. What everyone really wants is to have fun and enjoy what they're doing."
At Priceline.com in Norwalk, employees are even encouraged to play at work. About a dozen basketball hoops, air hockey and foosball tables scattered throughout the company's three-floor building provide employees a distraction during breaks. The tradition dates to the company's early days when an employee donated a foosball table and it got so much use that when it broke, senior management chipped to buy more tables for the office to share.
"We do that recognizing that there are the longer hours here and that some people need to let off stream," said Brian Ek, a spokesman for the company.
Even companies in more traditional industries are relaxing their work environments. Wilton-based accounting and tax firm Deloitte and Touche, for example, provides kitchenettes and nap rooms for employees.
"It's spawned by the technology companies because intellectual capital is so important to them," said Steve Clement of the Connecticut Technology Council. "It's become more mainstream because the labor market has become more competitive."
A number of scholars, however, have expressed skepticism of new workplace policies designed to make the office more homey. In her book, "The Time Bind: When Work Becomes Home and Home Becomes Work," the Berkeley sociologist Arlie Russell Hochschild investigated an undisclosed Fortune 500 company to examine the effect of family-friendly polices.
She found that even with these policies, workers were spending more time in the office partly, she argues, because with all the stresses on life at home -- children, marriages, housework -- the new workplace is often the more enjoyable place to be.
Competition for qualified labor has led many companies to offer unusual time-saving and quality of life benefits. Twenty-two percent of the Connecticut Business and Industry Association's survey respondents said they were now offering "creative benefit packages" such as catered meals, laundry and dry cleaning services and online concierge services. Companies said many of these new benefits are designed to help employees balance their work obligations with the rest of their lives.
"In prior years, people tried to artificially separate a person's work life from their work life. In reality, when a person shows up to work, the whole person shows up," said James Wall, the managing director of human resources for Deloitte and Touche, which has 30,000 employees around the country.
One program Deloitte offers helps employees take care of sick family members. The company will help arrange for child care for sick children and even hire temporary help to cook meals or run errands for an employee trying to balance increased home obligations with work.
Mr. Wall said such programs have saved Deloitte millions of dollars by helping the company reduce its turnover rate from 29 to 17 percent in the last eight years.
The demand for services that help employees save time has even led to the development of a whole new high-tech industry: online concerige services. These companies, which generally contract with companies and charge a per-employee fee for basic services, will run errands, make travel and entertainment arrangements.
"We're always looking for benefits that will help our employees," said Peter Cross, director of human resources for Arthur Anderson's Hartford office. His office contracts with Circles, a Boston-based online concierge service. "This is one that's a little different than many. It saves time and helps people get things done that would otherwise be difficult."
Mr. Cross, who also offers his employees free dry cleaning, said his employees use Circles primarily to make travel arrangements and find tickets for events. Jennifer Marino, a spokeswoman for Circles that serves more than one million employees across the country, said the company has even helped plan one customer's wedding.
While benefits such as online concierge services and office luxuries like nap rooms and game tables are still exceptions in Connecticut workplaces, an increasing number of companies are realizing that sometimes it is the little things that keep employees happy and content.
"Those things set you apart as a company that cares," Mr. Clement said.

HEADLINE: Congress's Part in the Firestone Crisis

BYLINE: By Joan Claybrook; Joan Claybrook is president Public Citizen, the consumer advocacy group. She was administrator of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration from 1977 to 1981.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
As Congress begins hearings this week on the recall of 6.5 million Firestone tires, questions will be raised about why the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration didn't take action sooner against Firestone and the Ford Motor Company over tire blowouts and resulting rollovers of Ford Explorers.
One answer is the agency's budget, now more than 30 percent lower in real dollars than it was in 1980. A 50 percent cut during the Reagan administration still hampers the agency's capacity to regulate an ever-growing automobile industry. Congressional interference on behalf of industry in safety recall cases has also shackled the regulators, and they lack needed authority to police automakers. 
 When it is time to drop the enforcement hammer, the safety agency can strike only lightly. The maximum penalty it can impose on Firestone or Ford is $925,000 for refusal to recall products. The penalty for withholding a document is a pitiful $ l,000, no matter how long it is withheld. And there are no federal criminal penalties for these violations, regardless of how many people are killed by a company's reckless behavior. The agency sent legislation to Congress in March to increase penalties, but the proposal for a maximum of $4 million in fines is still far too low to ensure deterrence of large corporations.
The agency's standards for tires and the strength of automobile roofs are 30 years old. Existing tests for roofs are virtually useless in protecting occupants in rollovers.
Over and over, the auto industry has succeeded in stopping strong safety measures like a rollover prevention standard and my proposal for tire inflation indicators on dashboards. Ford and Firestone now argue that consumers helped cause the current problem by not properly inflating Firestone tires.
Would these standards and legislative authority have prevented this disaster? Absolutely. But the agency must also be more proactive: seeking information about defects from repair shops, fleet owners, insurance companies, and lawyers for crash victims; issuing consumer alerts about possible defects and gathering facts from the public; and using its subpoena power to prevent the auto industry from withholding information.
When regulation of automobile safety is hampered or lax, the public pays the ultimate price.

SECTION: Section A; Page 16; Column 4; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: Pressure Myanmar

To the Editor:

Washington, Aug. 31, 2000

HEADLINE: New Economy;
Whose name is it anyway? Arbitration panels favoring trademark holders in disputes over Web names.

BYLINE: By Laurie J. Flynn

 BODY:
IN a little noticed decision in July, the World Intellectual Property Organization forced an American woman, Virginia Comito, to hand over the Internet address www.tonsil.com to Sud-Chemie, a German chemicals company that had held a trademark on the word since 1952. The address was deemed "identical or confusingly similar" to a bleaching product called Tonsil.
A month later, an arbitration panel of the organization ruled that David Sallen, a Boston entrepreneur, would have to turn over the domain name corinthians.com to the Corinthians, a Brazilian soccer team. The panel decided Mr. Sallen, whose site published a handful of biblical quotations, had acted in bad faith, determining that, among other things, he had hoped to profit from selling the name to the Brazilian team. 
 In both cases, the trademark holder prevailed. In the continuing battles between the owners of trademarks and individuals with Internet domain addresses identical to them or nearly so, the trademark owners appear to be far ahead. Of 1,000 cases that have gone before four approved arbitration boards (of which the World Intellectual Property Organization is one), three quarters have been won by trademark owners.
Francis Gurry, the organization's assistant director general, points out that it would only make sense that trademark holders prevail, as only companies that are fairly sure that domain holders are acting in bad faith take their cases to arbitrators.
"The procedure is not for cases where you have some rights and I have some rights," Mr. Gurry said in an interview from his office in Geneva. "These are supposed to be black-and-white cases."
Andrew McLaughlin, president of the Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers, the international nonprofit group that administers the domain-name system, which is also known as Icann, defended the arbitration process, which started last December as a way of giving trademark holders an easy way to resolve the growing number of battles over names. He says Icann plans a formal review of the process later this year.
Mr. McLaughlin also pointed out that the statistics on domain name arbitration are skewed because many domain name holders do not even bother to defend their positions.
At the heart of Icann's domain name arbitration system is the Uniform Dispute Resolution Policy, a set of rules that provide the litmus tests for determining if a domain name holder is acting in bad faith or is out to hijack a trademarked name. Only trademark holders can take their case to one of the arbitration and mediation centers. The decision of the arbitrators is not binding; companies and individuals can still take the case to court. And in November, the Clinton administration passed the federal Anti-cybersquatting Consumer Protection Act, giving trademark holders the right to take speculators to court and to collect damages. But the arbitrators' decisions are enforced by domain-name registrars, who carry them out by transferring domain names, or canceling them.
Of the four arbitration and mediation centers approved by Icann, the World Intellectual Property Organization hears most of the cases, followed by the National Arbitration Forum in Minneapolis; Disputes.org/ eResolutions Consortium in Amherst, Mass., and Montreal; and C.P.R Institute for Dispute Resolutions in New York.
The intellectual property organization has come under scrutiny lately by critics who say it is biased in favor of trademark holders.
James Love, director of the Consumer Project on Technology, a consumer advocacy group based in Washington, says the organization's decisions de-emphasize free speech in favor of protecting commercial interests. "The ability to call attention to your information is important," Mr. Love said. "To say that big companies can do that and individuals can't is wrong."
Granted, sorting out domain name rights is no easy job. Take the case surrounding corinthians.com, which Mr. Sallen has not taken down despite the ruling. For starters, there is the fact that the Web site operated by Mr. Sallen contains little more than a few biblical quotations and a missive stating "This website is about to be pirated by a huge corporation in Brazil." (Lawyers for the Brazilian team argue the biblical quotations appeared after the complaint was filed, presumably to make it appear the domain name was being actively used when it was not.)
Mr. Sallen had earlier sent the Brazilian team an e-mail offer to sell it the address, raising a red flag for arbitrators.
And, of course, the notion that the organization's litmus test of "confusingly similar" is, well, confusing.
Take the case of Yahoo, which has just successfully argued that several dozen domain names registered by the Data Art Corporation and others, including ayhoo.com, eeeyahoo.com and yafoo.com, are too easily confused with yahoo.com.
A related question arises from the abundance of parody and protest sites, some of which attach a disparaging or crude word onto the trademarked name, as in the case of the London-based electronics chain Dixons and a parody site with a similar and suggestive name. Is anybody really likely to confuse one address with the other? According to the intellectual property organization, they could. The "adoption" of the Dixons name in the address "is inherently likely to lead some people to believe that the complainant is connected with it," the panel wrote in its ruling, which favored the electronics store and forced the parody site to give up the address.
Another case heard by the board was that of the World Wrestling Federation, which argued that a California man was trying to profit from reselling the domain name www.worldwrestlingfederation.com. The federation, which has long maintained a site at www.wwf.com, dating back to when domain names were limited to only 22 characters, took the case to the intellectual property organization, which ruled that the address holder had acted in bad faith, hoping only to profit from reselling the name, and gave the name to the federation.
Still, consumer advocates like Mr. Love argue that the rulings lack balance and create precedents that may have far-reaching effects. The domain name problem, he says, stems from the scarcity of domain names, much of which will be alleviated when Icann next year approves new domain names to supplement .com, .gov, .org and .net.
In the meantime, a rash of celebrity domain name cases should help keep the arbitrators busy. A case brought by the entertainer Madonna against a California pornographer who until last year published a site at www.madonna.com is pending. Madonna, who has her own site at Madonnafanclub.com, is widely expected to win. But the singer Sting, whose real name is Gordon Sumner, lost his battle for the address www.sting.com after arbitrators ruled that the word sting is generic and that Mr. Sumner had not trademarked it.
Of course, when it comes to registering the domain names of famous celebrities, it may take more than arbitration to solve some cases. In May, the organization ordered the operator of a parody site about Julia Roberts to hand over the domain name juliaroberts.com to the actress. But the operator, Russell Boyd, is fighting back and has sued Ms. Roberts. But he confesses on his site that what he really wants is a phone call from her.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: Tiny Tuvalu Profits From Web Name

BYLINE: By JANE BLACK

 BODY:
At the height of the Internet land rush in 1998, an unusual story stood out from the rest: the tiny nation of Tuvalu sold, for $50 million, the rights to its chunk of cyberspace. Tuvalu, a string of islands halfway between Hawaii and Australia with a population of just 10,600, had rarely made world headlines. But the multimillion-dollar sale, to an ambitious Web entrepreneur in Canada, changed all that.
The story really began when Tuvalu, along with dozens of other nations and territories, was assigned its own two-letter suffix that signifies an Internet domain. Under the assignment, Britain received .uk; France, .fr; and Tuvalu, by chance, .tv. 
 Into this picture came Jason Chapnik, a 28-year-old entrepreneur from Toronto. Mr. Chapnik says he came up with the idea of registering names within the .tv domain as early as 1994.
"We started brainstorming," Mr. Chapnik recalled in a telephone interview from his home. "If we could have dot-anything, what would we want? We made lists -- dot-info, dot-law. Once we hit on dot-tv as a concept, we knew we had it."
But getting the rights to the .tv domain from Tuvalu would not be easy. Mr. Chapnik sent written proposals and spent months researching and making contacts with the Tuvalu government. By 1997, other people had come up with the same idea. By 1998, the Tuvalu government had narrowed the prospects down to three companies. So Mr. Chapnik and his wife, Jodi, took a vacation and went to the islands to make their pitch. In the fall of 1998, after months of negotiation, Tuvalu made its decision.
"I think my wife won it for us," Mr. Chapnik said. "Family is very important to them. Coming down with my wife and not business partners spoke volumes to them."
A few months later, Mr. Chapnik secured millions in backing from a leading Internet incubator, Idealab, which provided expertise and the capital needed to pay Tuvalu and build the business.
Under the deal, Tuvalu is to receive the $50 million over the next 12 years. Already, the company has paid the country $18 million. The payments so far have increased the country's gross domestic product by 50 percent and allowed the government to put electricity on the outer islands and create scholarships for its citizens.
Mr. Chapnik had succeeded at turning his idea into a viable Internet business company, dotTV, which is now 50 percent owned by Idealab.
The company's business plan is simple. It wants to be the next Network Solutions. As the wholesaler to the registrars of .com, .net and .org, Network Solutions made millions registering Internet addresses, largely because of the aura of the popular .com domain.
DotTV believes it can have the same kind of success with its domain, which it says is made up of the most recognizable two letters on the planet.
The company, which has its own site at www.tv, registers addresses on its Web site and through third parties like Dotster and GreatDomains.com. Most prices start at $100. Words and letter combinations with higher perceived value, like call letters of a television station, are auctioned off, starting at $1,000. Three names -- free.tv, china.tv and net.tv -- have each sold for $100,000, the company said last month.
The company's most recent success involved the Academy of Television Arts and Sciences, which agreed to relocate from emmys.org and emmycast.com to emmys.tv. It also sold .tv domains to the Pax broadcast network.
"This is an industry that is exploding," said Craig Francis, dotTV's chief operating officer. "Even at $100 a pop, which is what most names go for," he added, "this has the potential to be very profitable."
Mr. Francis would not say how many names had been sold so far, only that it was in the tens of thousands.
To sell more names, dotTV is trying to make the .tv domain synonymous with "rich" media on the Web, singling out organizations that will use video, audio and interactive features on their sites.
"Right now there is this fundamental shift in the Internet from static text to rich and engaging information that is much more television-like," Mr. Francis said. "We want the .tv domain to tell people that this is what a site is doing."
But achieving .com-like status for the new domain could still prove a challenge.
Clay Shirky, a partner at Accelerator Group, a consulting firm that works with Web start-ups, says the company's plan is based on the scarcity of commercially available domain names -- a scarcity that he says is not going to last.
"It is true that most of the 'good' .com names have been taken," Mr. Shirky said. "But the crash of the Internet market has cooled people's desire to pay buckets of cash for an easy-to-remember domain name."
Adding to dotTV's hurdles, the Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers, the international group charged with administering the domain-name system, plans to release a set of new domains, which might include suffixes like .web, .store and .sex, early next year.
So far, the only clear winner is Tuvalu. With some of the money it earned in the dotTV deal, it has financed the process to join the United Nations. Tomorrow at the United Nations, the organization will have a flag-raising ceremony for Tuvalu.
Koloa Talake, chairman of the nation's public sector reform program and a member of the board of dotTV, is quick to see a connection.
"The world's recognition of Tuvalu as an independent country has been made possible by the relationship with dotTV," he said, adding that the company was helping Tuvalu "get into the 21st century."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

WorldCom in Talks to Buy Communications Concern
WorldCom is in advanced talks to acquire Intermedia Communications, a telecommunications operator in Tampa, Fla., for almost $3 billion in cash and stock, executives close to the negotiations said.
Intermedia has been an attractive takeover target because it has a 54 percent stake in Digex, which provides Web-hosting services for corporate sites. WorldCom entered negotiations with Intermedia after talks between Intermedia and Global Crossing broke down. A third suitor, Exodus Communications, offered to acquire Digex directly but was rebuffed by Intermedia. Page C2. 

Trademarks Winning Domain Fights
In the continuing battles between the owners of trademarks and individuals with Internet domain addresses identical to them or nearly so, the trademark owners appear to be way ahead. Of 1,000 cases that have gone before four approved arbitration boards, three quarters have been won by the trademark owners. New Economy. C3.
 
A Tiny Nation Profits From the Web
As the wholesaler to the registrars of .com, .net and .org, Network Solutions made millions registering Internet addresses, largely because of the popular .com domain. Now a company called dotTV believes it can have the same kind of success with its domain, .tv, which it says are the most recognizable two letters on the planet. But to get the name it had to pay $50 million to the nation that owned it: Tuvalu, a string of islands halfway between Hawaii and Australia. C2.
 
Sports Sites Revamp Sales Strategy
Sports Web sites cheer the coming of autumn as fans increasingly flock to their computers to trade gossip, scores and injury reports on football, basketball and hockey. A year ago, many of those sites also promoted new online stores. Twelve months later, these "sports content" sites are putting as much distance as they can between themselves and their e-commerce experiments. They are not eschewing e-commerce altogether. Rather, many of them are taking a new approach to selling goods online, placing the site's store in the hands of an outside company. Bob Tedeschi: E-Commerce Report. C5.
 
MP3.com Disputes Copyrights
In the copyright-violation case involving Universal Music Group and MP3.com, which created a database of compact discs to allow users to listen to music from their collections on the Internet, a federal judge is set to rule this week on whether MP3.com willfully broke the law or started the service in good faith. That ruling will help determine damages. But MP3.com's lawyers now dispute the validity of Universal's copyrights because the company designated them "works for hire," a concept that they argue has no legal basis. C7.
 
Builder Seeks Debt Relief in Japan
A large Japanese construction company, Kumagai Gumi, is expected to ask its creditors to forgive $4.25 billion in debt. The company joins a number of debt-burdened businesses, many of them construction companies, that have asked for relief from their creditors. C4.
 
Station Goes From On-Air to Online
Last Monday, a radio station in California became the first United States broadcaster to depart the FM dial and continue on the Internet without an interruption in programming. The new Web-only entity is an experiment by its parent company, Clear Channel Communications, which sold the station's two frequencies, along with 83 others, to allay Justice Department concerns about its recently completed $23.8 billion purchase of AMFM. C6.
 
Chicago Markets Call Off Talks
A proposed merger of two financial powerhouses fell through late last week as the Chicago Board Options Exchange called off talks with the Chicago Board of Trade. The combination had been proposed as a way for the two exchanges, which have been fighting over trading rights, to retain their dominant positions in the face of increasing electronic competition. C5.
 
U.S. Markets Closed Today
United States financial markets and banks are closed today in observance of Labor Day. Most financial markets in other countries are open.

Some Unexplored Options For a Missile Defense
The debate about a national missile defense system has obscured the potential candidacy of a lesser-known antimissile weapon known as the theater missile defense system, designed to protect American troops and bases in relatively small regions. Theater missile defense systems potentially could be expanded to protect larger areas and perhaps even the entire United States, analysts inside and outside the military say. A1
 
Strong Challenger in Yugoslavia
In the race for president, polls suggest that the moderate nationalist Vojislav Kostunica, the most serious opposition candidate ever to challenge Slobodan Milosevic, ought to be able to win. The election is being closely watched by the United States and NATO, which bombed Yugoslavia for 78 days last year over Kosovo and have labored since to push Mr. Milosevic out of office. A1

More Immigrants in Work Force
The percentage of immigrant workers in the nation's labor force has climbed to its highest level in seven decades. This influx -- immigrants now represent 12 percent of the nation's workers -- is having profound effects on the work force and the economy, helping hold down wages in unskilled jobs and giving many companies the employees needed to expand. Immigration analysts estimate that nearly 5 million of these workers are illegal immigrants. A1
 
What War-Ready Means
The 49th Armored Division of the Texas National Guard -- nominally under Gov. George W. Bush's command -- has the lowest ranking for wartime readiness that the Pentagon gives, according to military officials. It has been that way for the last three years. But just as the Pentagon disputes that its active-duty forces are not ready for combat, the 49th Guard division's case reveals a far more difficult question about the overall state of the American military today. It involves an arcane, sometimes subjective readiness accounting system that can be misleading and is not easily reduced to the sound bites of a presidential campaign. A15

HEADLINE: In America;
Working Harder, Longer

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT

 BODY:
There's a lot of good news to report this Labor Day. Unemployment is very low and wages are rising. The benefits of the booming economy are being widely distributed. Workers at the bottom are finally enjoying significant increases in their inflation-adjusted wages. Better yet, the U.S. is experiencing a surge in the growth of labor productivity which, as noted in a book-length report from the Economic Policy Institute, is "probably the best indicator of an economy's capacity to provide for the material needs of its population."
This good news is the result of the rapid economic growth and most especially the sustained low unemployment that really got rolling in the mid-1990's. The key issue has always been the same for working people -- jobs, jobs, jobs. 
 "Employment opportunities have expanded considerably, especially for historically disadvantaged groups, including women, blacks and Hispanics," the report said. "The long-term rise in job instability and job insecurity, which continued well into the current economic recovery, finally appeared to have abated at the end of the last decade.
"Even the share of workers in nonstandard -- often substandard -- work arrangements, such as temporary work and part-time work, has declined as opportunities for regular full-time employment have grown."
Nirvana, yes?
Well, no.
For one thing, there's the time crunch. Families with children have had to work harder and harder over the past few decades to maintain a decent standard of living, and that phenomenon continues. The number of earners per family has increased, as have the average number of weeks worked per year, and the number of hours worked per week.
That doesn't leave a lot of quality time for families to enjoy the benefits of their added income. As a woman in New Jersey recently said: "We're a working family all right. That's all we do is work."
And then there's the matter of indebtedness. The institute's report, which is titled "The State of Working America 2000-01" and is published by Cornell University Press, makes it clear that despite the rosy stock market stories of the past few years, the typical American family accumulated more debt in the 1990's than it made from the appreciation of stocks.
The authors wrote:
"The total wealth of the typical American household improved only marginally during the 1990's. The net worth of the typical household rose about $2,200 in the 1990's -- from $58,800 in 1989 to $61,000 in 1998. While this household's assets grew modestly -- stock assets were up by $5,500 and nonstock assets by $8,500 -- its debt rose as well, by $11,800. Thus, the relatively modest gains in stock and nonstock assets combined with the offsetting rise in household debt meant that the 1990's were far less generous to typical households than business-page headlines often suggest."
"Middle-income families are ahead of where they were four or five years ago to the tune of two or three or four thousand dollars, and that's not chicken feed," said Jared Bernstein, a labor economist and one of the authors of the report. "But they are more indebted, working more and more hours, and the stock market boom has largely passed them by."
The times may be terrific, but American working families are not well-prepared for significant downside economic surprises. "On some level," said Mr. Bernstein, "their future is largely dependent on staying where we are with regard to unemployment and productivity."
Meanwhile, the public profile of the poor has diminished almost to the point of invisibility. But they are still there. Despite the economic gains of the past few years, the national poverty rate in 1998 -- the latest year for which complete statistical data was available -- was 12.7 percent, just one tenth of a percentage point less than in 1989, and one full percentage point higher than in 1979.
Nearly one in five American children lives in poverty.
The tight labor market is helping, and poor families are working more. But the progress is painfully slow.
Historians will look back at Labor Day 2000 and marvel at how well America was doing. And then they will assess how wisely, during these best of times, we invested our considerable resources in the unfinished business of creating a brighter future for everyone.

HEADLINE: FOREIGN WORKERS AT HIGHEST LEVEL IN SEVEN DECADES

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE

 BODY:
As employers clamor for more foreign-born workers and as tens of thousands of Mexicans slip across the border each year, the percentage of immigrant workers in the nation's labor force has climbed to its highest level in seven decades.
New figures from the Bureau of Labor Statistics showed that the number of immigrant workers jumped to 15.7 million last year, up 17 percent from three years earlier. Immigration analysts estimate that nearly 5 million of these workers are illegal immigrants. 
 This influx -- immigrants now represent 12 percent of the nation's workers -- is having profound effects on the work force and the economy, helping hold down wages in unskilled jobs and giving many companies the employees needed to expand.
Immigrants dominate dozens of jobs, especially arduous, low-paying ones: poultry plant workers, meatpackers, gardeners, hotel maids, seamstresses, restaurant workers, building demolition workers and fruit and vegetable pickers.
"Immigrants are now a critical part of the labor force across the board," said Demetrios Papademetriou, co-director of international migration policy at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace. "We are into a new world of immigrants basically spreading throughout the economy. This is something that is going to continue and intensify."
With the unemployment rate at 4.1 percent, near its lowest point in 40 years, the debate about immigrant workers has shifted considerably from five years ago, when many politicians called for more restrictive policies.
Now, software companies, farmers, hotels and other employers desperate for workers are pressuring Congress to enact legislation that would admit hundreds of thousands of additional immigrants each year.
But some groups, most notably labor unions and engineers' associations, are fighting such an easing, fearing that it would depress wages and cost jobs for American workers. At the same time, unions have softened their once hard line toward illegal immigrants already in the country, as they seek to unionize them.
Economists and demographers see a continuing surge in immigrant workers unless there is a major economic downturn. Under existing quotas, about 800,000 immigrants enter the nation legally each year. An estimated 300,000 enter illegally.
These workers range from supermarket delivery people who have received an illegally low $3 an hour, far less than the $5.15 an hour minimum wage, to $100,000-a-year software developers from India.
As the number of immigrant workers has soared, Americans are voicing less anger and anxiety about immigration than in the mid-1990's. The reason, political analysts said, is that the expanding economy and low jobless rate have reduced economic insecurity.
Not only that, politicians who led the attack against immigrants -- with measures to cut government benefits to the children of illegal immigrants -- have seen their efforts backfire, especially in California. There, the fast-growing Hispanic and Asian populations have moved to punish anti-immigrant politicians in the voting booth.
"You have a very robust economy and full employment, and that always changes the terms of debate on immigration," said James P. Smith, an economist with the Rand Corporation who was chairman of a 1997 National Academy of Sciences study on the effects of immigration. "When there are plenty of jobs around, the finger pointing that goes on about immigration goes away."
Even so, in some places, like Farmingville, N.Y., residents have complained that dozens of immigrant day laborers who assemble in streets and parking lots each morning to be picked up by employers are an unsightly horde who litter, commit crimes and hurt property values.
At the same time, many Americans have found that the stream of immigrants has provided them with affordable gardeners, nannies, housekeepers -- even manicurists
"Americans rely very much on low-cost immigrant labor to maintain their living standards, which means everything from lawn care to inexpensive agricultural production to the construction business," Mr. Papademetriou said.
One unhappy result of the influx of immigrants has been a wave of violations of the nation's labor laws. Unscrupulous employers have refused to provide workers' compensation or pay minimum wage or time-and-a-half overtime to immigrants required to work 70 to 80 hours a week. Some female immigrants have complained that their bosses sexually harass them, and they fear that if they complain, their bosses will report them to the Immigration and Naturalization Service.
One immigrant, Silverio Otero, a grocery store worker on New York's Lower East Side, complained that for a long time he was paid $240 a week even though the store owner required him to work 72 hours a week. That came to $3.33 an hour.
"They didn't treat us very nice," said Mr. Otero, a 29-year-old native of Mexico who will receive $7,000 in back wages because of a settlement arranged by Eliot L. Spitzer, the New York State attorney general. "They took advantage of us because we were immigrants and they didn't think we would speak up."
Officials from a coalition of industries pushing Congress to grant several hundred thousand more temporary worker visas each year said they were not looking for easy-to-exploit workers, but simply for workers. Among the groups pressing for such legislation are the National Restaurant Association and the American Hotel and Motel Association.
"We want to make it easier for employers who are facing shortages to hire foreign workers," said John F. Gay, co-chairman of the industry group, the Essential Worker Immigration Coalition. "We've tried everything we could think of to bring more American workers into the labor force, but with this booming economy, it hasn't been enough. It's not a question of finding cheaper bodies. It's a question of finding bodies."
Other industries are making similar pleas. The agricultural industry wants Congress to allow in more foreigners to plant and pick produce. Computer and software companies have asked that more three-year visas be granted each year to foreigners with technology expertise. In 1998, Congress expanded that program to allow in 115,000 workers, up from 65,000, and now the high-technology industry wants that quota lifted to more than 200,000.
Many labor groups, including the United Farm Workers and the A.F.L.-C.I.O., are fighting these proposals. The unions argue that workers brought in under such programs drive down wages and essentially are easy-to-exploit captives restricted to working for one company.
The Clinton administration, mindful of Silicon Valley's political contributions and organized labor's political muscle, has signaled that it favors increasing the number of high-technology visas, but not those for unskilled workers.
"In high technology, we are now trying to meet a real spot shortage," Labor Secretary Alexis M. Herman said. "But when you talk about jobs in the hotel industry and other areas, there's still a lot of untapped employment potential in the nation, and I believe that we can meet those demands with Americans."
This debate is influenced heavily by the way immigration creates different winners and losers.
American businesses, ranging from motels and lettuce farms to corporate giants like Intel and Apple, benefit from the influx of immigrants. But the National Academy of Sciences study found that immigrants, especially illegal, unskilled workers from Mexico and the rest of Latin America, have pushed down wages for American-born workers with less than a high school education by 5 percent.
That study found that immigration increased the nation's economy by $10 billion -- a tiny amount in a country with a gross domestic product of nearly $10 trillion.
"The real impact of immigration is not to increase the size of the pie, but to redistribute the pie," said George J. Borjas, a Harvard University professor of public policy. "If you happen to have the type of job that competes with immigrants, you're often hurt, but if you're a company or an upper-middle-class person who hires immigrants, then you benefit."
In recent months, one of the biggest changes has been the softening stance of labor unions toward illegal immigrants. The A.F.L.-C.I.O. has called for repealing the law that bars employers from hiring illegal immigrants -- a law organized labor lobbied successfully for in 1986.
While still favoring strict limits on the number of immigrants entering the country, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. has reversed itself by calling for the granting of legal status to hundreds of thousands of illegal immigrants. Giving them legal status, union officials said, would make it harder for employers to exploit them and hold down their wages.
"There was a recognition of how immigrants are being discriminated against and of the indignities they suffer," John J. Sweeney, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., said. "We saw that the present immigration policies weren't working and that it was time to call for a fairer policy that treats these people in a more humane way."
As part of this shift, many unions that once sought to keep immigrants out of their fields now are eager to organize those workers.

SECTION: Section A; Page 16; Column 1; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: The Gateway City

 BODY:
New York City has long held a special place in American life as a metropolis that perpetually renews itself with waves of foreign immigration. That has never been truer than today, when the city is brimming with newly arrived residents. At the end of a decade in which one million newcomers swept into the city, 40 percent of New Yorkers are now foreign-born, the highest level since 1910. The city is enriched by the immigrants, but it also faces major challenges in helping to integrate them fully into the life and economy of the city.
The earlier generations of immigrants who passed through Ellis Island were largely from Europe. The fastest-growing groups these days are from South Asia, the Dominican Republic, Mexico and the nations born of the breakup of the Soviet Union. In Queens alone 167 nationalities and 116 languages coexist. That variety is one of New York's most distinctive traits. While other cities tend to attract immigrants primarily from one or two foreign regions, New York is a magnet for the whole world. The immigrants come because of the city's reputation as a point of entry and the presence of friends and relatives. 
 If it were not for immigration, the city's population would be decreasing today. The newcomers culturally and economically revitalize abandoned neighborhoods, and their presence bolsters the economy and contributes to the tax base. But the surge has also brought a slew of challenges. Many immigrants do not speak English, and long lines of people are turned away from the too-few English classes sponsored by nonprofit organizations and community colleges. The inability to speak English keeps immigrants in very low-paying jobs. Many Mexican and Dominican immigrants, for instance, earn less than $20,000 a year.
Meanwhile, a shortage of affordably priced housing has led to overcrowding in poor areas. It is not uncommon in some Bronx neighborhoods for four or more people to live in a single room. Schools are also inadequate in these neighborhoods, with enrollments straining already sparse resources.
Because newly arrived immigrants are not eligible to vote -- and turnout is low among those who have become citizens -- many of these problems do not receive the attention they deserve from political leaders. Naturalized citizens should be encouraged to register to vote, and local politicians need to make more effort to reach out to these traditionally ignored populations. In addition, immigrants are often unaware of the programs that do exist to help them. Public housing aid and child health insurance, for example, are not widely used by immigrants who are eligible for them. Many immigrants use emergency medical care but also rely on unlicensed community clinics, in part because they are unaware of the dangers associated with such clinics.
Poverty rates among immigrant populations are high, and if current problems are allowed to grow, they could lead to a permanent underclass of immigrants. With the city's foreign-born population expected to grow even larger in the years ahead, the health of the city will depend in no small measure on how successfully it absorbs its newest residents.
