HEADLINE: Security Council Looking At Its Peacekeeping Bills

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 4

 BODY:
The five permanent Security Council members plan to use their collective influence this week and call for a revision of how peacekeeping costs are divided among member nations, a move that would -- at least on paper -- help Washington in its battle to reduce American assessments.
The review of peacekeeping bills, which has to be conducted through a committee of member nations, would be intended to help put the faltering and cash-strapped peacekeeping department on a firmer financial footing. 
 The five members -- Britain, China, France, Russia and the United States -- will meet on Thursday as part of a separate Security Council "summit within a summit" meeting of more than 150 government leaders. Both the full 15-member council and its core of permanent members will issue declarations for the day.
The permanent members' final draft calls for adjusting the payment scale for peacekeeping costs "in light of changed circumstances." The scale was established in 1973 to cover an operation in Sinai and has never been revised.
At that time, the permanent members, who hold veto power, were asked to pay a premium for peacekeeping on top of their fair share of costs based on their national economies. Other industrial nations paid just their share. Smaller or poorer nations paid as little as 10 or 20 percent of what they would usually be charged. A complex formula of special discounts claimed by many nations further skewed the system.
Based on 1973 economic figures, the United States was assessed more than 30 percent and China less than 1 percent, a gap that has rankled American officials in recent years. Russia is still assessed as if it were the Soviet Union.
China has generally acknowledged that the system is out of date and unfair, given the changes in the economic fortunes of many nations. Saudi Arabia and Singapore, for example, pay minimal amounts. But Chinese officials have refused to agree to a significant increase in their bill.
Diplomats say with the economy of Hong Kong now calculated in with that of the rest of China, Beijing will no longer be able to make a case for poverty, even taking into account its large population.
In Washington, Congress has already ruled that the United States will pay no more than 25 percent of its bill -- when it pays at all. That contributes to an ever-widening American debt, because member nations do not recognize moves like this from individual countries.
Reopening formal debate on a new payment scale will take a long time, diplomats said, because 189 countries will all have opinions to offer and limits to negotiate. But lobbying by the permanent council members will help the process.
In general, the permanent five will recommend in their statement this week that the financial base of the United Nations, both the regular budget, which is assessed separately, and peacekeeping "must accurately reflect the capabilities and responsibilities of every member state."

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE VOTERS;
Hearing About God but Wondering About Issues

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON 

DATELINE: DENVER, Sept. 3

 BODY:
All the talk of faith and religion in the presidential campaign might be expected to gain the attention of a voter like Sarah Dotson, 28, who rose early this morning to attend Mass at Holy Ghost Roman Catholic Church here.
She had noticed, all right. And that was the problem. 
 "Frankly, it makes me a little uncomfortable," said Ms. Dotson, who clutched a prayer book as church bells pealed on this Sunday morning. "I've heard enough from the candidates about how they pray. I want to hear how they're going to keep the economy going."
Voters could scarcely miss the expressions of religious faith by candidates in this presidential campaign.
Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, the Republican nominee, declared a "Jesus Day" in his state. Vice President Al Gore, the Democratic nominee, has described himself as a born-again Christian who often asks himself, "What would Jesus do?"
Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut, the Democratic vice-presidential nominee, who is an Orthodox Jew, has urged that religious faith play a stronger role in American life.
But for all the soul baring by candidates, more than three dozen voters interviewed around the country in the past few days expressed little interest in weighing the religious convictions of candidates in choosing the next president.
As Kim Cart, a 29-year-old store clerk in Vinton, La., put it, with a chuckle, "As long as he's not into Satanic rituals, I really don't care about a politician's religious beliefs."
Even those who consider themselves religious, like Dee Bobbitt, a 47-year-old waitress who teaches Sunday school and helps clean the First Assembly of God Church in suburban Houston, did not place much emphasis on the religious views of a candidate.
"I care more if they're smart," said Mrs. Bobbitt, who thinks President Clinton "has done a wonderful job," no matter that he might not agree with her views on the sinfulness of drinking, smoking, dancing and gambling, not to mention sex outside marriage. "I'd like to say that it does matter if a president is religious, but it just doesn't."
Those interviewed also tended to express a skepticism about the sincerity of the religious views of candidates.
Bob Doby, a 41-year-old truck driver from Stockton, Calif., shook his head with impatience at the religious ponderings of politicians.
"It's just a way to try to get votes, that's all," said Mr. Doby, who added that he did not believe in God. "I'm jealous of people who can go to church and find solace. I can't. Some people can, and that's cool. But it's got nothing whatsoever to do with running the country. It just doesn't have any relevance, and they ought to stop talking about it."
Shaunessy McNeely, a 21-year-old nursing student, who attended Riverside Baptist Church here, said she could not help noticing that politicians mostly like to preach to the choir and keep quiet if they think an audience is not receptive.
"Jesus Day in Texas -- how hard is that?" Ms. McNeely said laughing, adding that it was scarcely a profile in religious courage for Mr. Bush to issue such a proclamation in a state with so many evangelical Christians. "Is he going to go to San Francisco, to Manhattan, and say, 'Rah, rah, Jesus.' If he does, then I'll be impressed."
David Carey, a 48-year-old Roman Catholic who works for an insurance company here, said he appreciated that candidates were trying to "invoke a higher moral standard." But Mr. Carey said it was folly to try to assess which candidate seemed to be more religious.
"When the candidates talk about religion, I just ignore them," he said. "It says more about what the politicians think of the voters, and what they think the voters want to hear."
To be sure, a few voters said the candidates should be talking more about religion, not less.
"The morals of the country are shot, and God is the only way to bring things back," said Bruce Abel, a 53-year-old kitchen designer, who was on his way to Riverside Baptist Church here. "Belief in God has shaped this country from the founding, and God's hand needs to be in politics today."
If Mr. Clinton had been more religious, Mr. Abel said, the nation would not have been forced to endure the sex scandal that nearly drove him from office.
"But Clinton getting elected was all part of God's plan," he said. "It was part of a lesson for us."
Some voters said it was healthy for candidates to talk about religion, as long as they did not push a particular faith.
Merrill Goldberg, a 57-year-old math teacher from Shawnee Mission, Kan., said he thought it was odd that people seemed uncomfortable talking about religion but did not so much as shrug over the saturation of sex and violence in today's culture.
"With all that garbage out there, I would hope it would be permissible to talk about God, too," Mr. Goldberg, an Orthodox Jew, said. "To me, religion is equated with morality. So I don't have a problem with that. But it crosses the line when you promote a particular religion."
Among the candidates, Mr. Lieberman tended to be seen as the most sincere about his expressions of faith. "He doesn't just say it," Ms. Cart said, "he lives it."
Dick Rosenberg, a 61-year-old real estate investor here, who described himself as a nonpracticing Jew, said he also admired Mr. Lieberman. Nonetheless, Mr. Rosenberg said he wished the senator would stop talking so much about religion.
"Religion shouldn't be used as a marketing tool," he said, supporting the call by the Anti-Defamation League for Mr. Lieberman to refrain from talking about his religion. "It's a private deal, so keep it private."
Even among voters who said their religion shaped their voting, there was plenty of disagreement about the political will of God, judging from the disparate views among people who shared pews in the same church.
Donna Loper, a 61-year-old secretary who attended Holy Ghost Church, said her convictions would prevent her from voting for a candidate who supported abortion.
"It's against church teachings," Ms. Loper said; "it can't be any clearer." She said she would be voting for Mr. Bush.
Michael Carrigan, 33, who also attended Holy Ghost, said his faith also shaped his ideology.
"My religion inspires my politics," Mr. Carrigan said. "The church calls us to social action and justice, to take care of the less fortunate."
He said he would be voting for Mr. Gore.
Few voters seemed more troubled by the religious talk than John Price, a 52-year-old management consultant, who was drinking coffee at an outdoor cafe here.
Mr. Price, a former resident of Oklahoma, recalled a conservative politician in that state running on a campaign that focused on "God, guns and gays."
He critcized Mr. Bush and Mr. Gore for making statements that "smacked of the cult of Jesus," appeals that he said risked dividing the American public.
"The only way religion is going to be an issue in the campaign for me," Mr. Price said, "is if somebody tries to force it on me."
Then he checked his watch, put down his coffee, and announced he was in a hurry to leave.
He was running late for church.

PUB-DATE: September 5, 2000

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 3590 words

HEADLINE: GRIDLOCK IN THE SKIES: A special report.;
Crisis for Air Traffic System: More Passengers, More Delays

BYLINE: By By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN and MATTHEW L. WALD 

 BODY:
Today ends the second straight summer travel season of chronic flight delays and cancellations across the United States. Yet despite the expenditure of billions -- and repeated warnings over the last decade that the air traffic system was approaching gridlock -- there is still no relief in sight for frustrated fliers.
Indeed, most experts now believe that delays, which have risen nearly 50 percent the last five years, will become worse, not better. The Federal Aviation Administration, which runs the air traffic system, predicts that by 2010 the number of airline passengers will rise 59 percent, to one billion. About 70 percent of that increase is expected to occur at the country's 28 largest airports. 
 "I don't think there is anything on the drawing board right now that you can say with any credibility is the answer," said Kenneth M. Mead, inspector general of the Transportation Department, parent agency of the F.A.A.
"We wish there was a silver bullet," said Jane Garvey, the F.A.A. administrator, "but there is not."
The story of how the nation's air transportation system reached its current crisis can be traced back to one of the government's most successful economic initiatives -- airline deregulation -- and to one of its longest and most expensive bureaucratic blunders: the F.A.A.'s ill-fated attempts to develop a new air traffic control system.
It is a tale that involves so many disparate interests shouting one another down -- from grass-roots organizations to large corporations to municipalities to labor unions -- that politicians in Congress and the White House have simply let the system drift for years.
A recent review by Mr. Mead's office found that the F.A.A. and the Transportation Department do not even have the tools to determine the precise causes of most delays.
And so the airlines blame the F.A.A., charging that the hours planes sit idling on runways and the countless appointments missed by passengers because of an antiquated air traffic control system cost more than $5 billion last year alone. The F.A.A. counters that airlines knowingly schedule more takeoffs and landings at major airports than the system can handle. Both attack Congress for not appropriating enough money to fix the system, and localities for preventing the building of new runways at congested airports.
"It's gotten down to a big finger-pointing contest," said Thomas Brantley, national vice president of the Professional Airways System Specialists, the union of technicians who maintain the F.A.A.'s air traffic control equipment. "The reality is, everybody's got blame to share."
There are other factors at work, too. Eight years of economic growth has encouraged airlines to add flights, even as consumers complain about high fares. An unusual spate of thunderstorms this summer frequently left controllers with few avenues to reroute air traffic. And United Airlines, the world's largest carrier, was forced to cancel more than 20,000 flights over the summer, largely because of labor disputes, adding to the burden on passengers and other airlines.
Still, critics say that thunderstorms and the growth in passenger demand are predictable events that the system should handle without passengers' waiting half a day or more to reach their destinations. And those passengers are seething.
"It's not like we are having typhoons," said Sharon Mantel, a drug saleswoman heading to Chicago from LaGuardia Airport one morning in July. "Shouldn't technology be able to handle this? It's not like the airplane was invented yesterday."
Indeed, the answer to today's gridlock, whenever it comes, will involve new technology that lets controllers track more planes in the sky -- and, possibly, new economics that let market forces allocate the system's scarce resources.
Any changes, however, must guarantee the same high level of safety enjoyed now. For with all its flaws -- and despite a few deadly collisions on the ground -- the national air system has been remarkably successful at keeping big jets from flying into one another.
 
The Transformation
With Deregulation,
Sweeping Changes
 A generation ago, life was much simpler for airlines and air traffic controllers. Government regulators told the airlines when and where they could fly and how much they could charge. Bureaucrats made sure every city was served and that popular cities had no more service than they could handle.
The drawback was that flying was expensive, the preserve of an elite.
The deregulation of the industry in 1978 transformed air travel into mass transportation. It also hit the industry like an earthquake. Venerable carriers disappeared; low-fare upstarts rose and fell. The survivors established so-called hubs at major airports, increasing their efficiency by flying passengers in, transferring them to other planes, and flying them on to their final destinations.
Today, the airline industry carries three times as many passengers as it did in 1978 at average fares that are 40 percent lower, adjusting for inflation.
But while the industry was transformed, the air traffic control system has remained virtually unchanged. At its heart are a collection of ground-based navigation beacons and radar stations that divide the 3.5 million square miles of airspace over the continental United States into aerial highways over which most airplanes are dispatched single-file like railroad cars.
Because radar -- developed for the military in World War II -- is arguably better at spotting attack planes than tracking friendly jets, the F.A.A. has long stipulated that planes flying between cities be separated by at least 5 miles horizontally and 1,000 feet vertically. That clogs the routes taken by the 20,000 scheduled flights a day.
"A bunch of guys with slide rules, pocket protectors and tape on their glasses figured this out a long time ago," said William Blackmer, the top safety and technology expert at the National Air Traffic Controllers Association, the union for 15,000 F.A.A. controllers.
When a storm hits, controllers begin closing off highways and spacing planes farther apart, leading to long delays on the ground. Even when the weather is perfect, departures are not spread evenly throughout the day; for a hub to be successful, planes must arrive and depart in waves. Airlines also try to provide frequent service from their hubs for the convenience of business travelers, who pay the highest fares.
The irony is that inviting everybody to travel when they prefer means fewer planes arrive or depart on time. Mr. Mead, the Transportation Department's inspector general, found that airlines frequently schedule flights in numbers that would be beyond an airport's maximum capacity even in perfect weather, let alone on bad weather days, when departure and arrival rates can be cut in half.
For example, at Newark International Airport one day earlier this year, Mr. Mead found that airlines had scheduled more planes to take off than could be handled by the tower for four hours during the day. Last year, Newark had the second highest number of delays recorded by the F.A.A., after O'Hare International Airport at Chicago.
Continental Airlines, which uses Newark as a hub, said it had spread out arrivals and departures to stay below the airport's capacity throughout the day. It has also replaced smaller airplanes with larger ones, to keep takeoffs and landings flat while accommodating more passengers.
"If we scheduled fewer flights, then people couldn't travel," said Greg Brenneman, Continental's president. "It is not incumbent on the airlines to be the least common denominator here. It is incumbent on the government to have a system that allows people to travel when they want to travel."
Several government commissions have urged expanded use of secondary airports to ease the strain on the system. Southwest Airlines, the country's seventh-largest carrier, has had enormous success bypassing major airports, providing frequent service between cities like Baltimore and Providence or Dallas and Houston. That has helped Southwest achieve the best on-time performance of any major carrier. But the other airlines continue to favor the hub system.
The airlines would like to see busy airports enlarged; that is what both United and American Airlines would prefer at O'Hare, for instance, where they operate hubs. But residents near O'Hare oppose any expansion. Representative Henry J. Hyde Jr., their Republican congressman, has joined with Representative Jesse L. Jackson Jr., a Democrat from Chicago, to back construction of a new airport south of the city -- but the airlines have said they would not fly there.
Most other major airports also have difficulty expanding, either because there is no space, as is the case at Newark and LaGuardia Airport, or because of local opposition. From 1995 through 1999, only three new runways were put into service at the 28 biggest airports, according to the Transportation Department.
The introduction of smaller 50- and 70-seat jets has also increased congestion. These so-called regional jets are rapidly replacing propeller-driven planes on many commuter routes and are much preferred by passengers. But unlike prop planes, which fly at lower altitudes and can take off and land on shorter runways, regional jets act just as big jets do, adding to the competition for space on the ground and in the air.
In 1995, there were just 35 regional jets in the nation's fleet. Last year, there were 407. The Transportation Department estimates the number will grow 25 percent annually, comprising 19 percent of the total domestic fleet by 2011.
 
The New System
Plan With Promise
Triples Its Cost
 The growth in air traffic was supposed to be easily handled by a sophisticated system that the F.A.A. began developing in 1981. In the wake of that year's air traffic controllers' strike, when all 11,000 controllers were fired by President Reagan, the F.A.A. began looking for a system that would handle more traffic with fewer controllers.
What came to be known as the Advanced Automation System, was the centerpiece of a 10-year, $12 billion plan to modernize air traffic control. Though the overall system of radar and navigation beacons was unchanged, the plan promised to save billions of dollars by enabling controllers to "work smarter, not harder," the F.A.A. administrator at the time said.
It turned out to be a gigantic white elephant. In 1994, after its cost had tripled, the system's capabilities were shown to be much less than promised and it was still 10 years from completion, the F.A.A. decided to scale back the project dramatically. The money wasted, according to the General Accounting Office, amounted to $2.8 billion.
The failure was just the most dramatic example of the F.A.A.'s storied incompetence in procurement. For years, the agency has been rebuked by members of Congress and outside critics.
"The Federal Aviation Administration currently lacks the organizational, management, and financial wherewithal to keep pace with the dynamic aviation community," the National Civil Aviation Review Commission, a blue-ribbon panel set up by Congress, concluded in 1996. (The Commission also warned presciently that "rapidly growing demand combined with a reduction in capacity, as the result of continued reliance on outdated equipment, will bring our nation's aviation system to gridlock soon after the turn of the century.")
The F.A.A. has shown some improvement in the last five years. For one thing, Congress mandated a five-year term for the administrator, slowing the turnover at the top.
After the debacle with the Advanced Automation System, the F.A.A. adopted a much more modest approach to modernizing air traffic control -- a strategy Mrs. Garvey, the administrator since 1997, sums up as "build a little; test a little; deploy a little."
It replaced its old mainframe computers with newer ones and installed color radar display screens. System crashes, which in the 1990's frequently forced controllers to track jets on slips of paper, are now rare.
But many serious problems remain. The original $12 billion modernization program that was supposed to be completed in 1991 now has a budget of $40 billion through 2004 with no end in sight.
In addition, what the F.A.A. hails as modernization is the technological equivalent of a new coat of paint. The new mainframe computers that form the heart of the air traffic system are I.B.M. models built in the 1990's that have already gone out of production. The F.A.A. could not buy I.B.M.'s newest machines because they would not run Jovial, the 1960's programming language used in the system's software.
Jovial, which stands for Jules Own Version of the International Algebraic Language, was created by a programmer, Jules I. Schwartz, 40 years ago as part of a contract for the Strategic Air Command. The F.A.A. plans to switch to a more modern computer language, but the transition "is very complex and it is going to take literally years," said William Shumann, an agency spokesman.
The F.A.A. also had high hopes for a plan called the Wide Area Augmentation System, intended to use the constellation of military satellites that make up the Global Positioning System to enable planes to fly virtually independent of controllers on the ground.
It was supposed to be operating by 1998, but also proved much more complicated -- and expensive -- than the F.A.A. first thought. The system was made available on a very limited basis last week, but is not scheduled to be completed until 2002. Few believe it will make a significant contribution toward reducing delays.
"The F.A.A. parades these acquisitions before Congress like they know what they are getting, but they haven't figured out yet what they need," said Mr. Mead.
Meanwhile, a group of cargo carriers, frustrated by the F.A.A.'s failures, is developing its own air traffic system using satellites. Under this system, each airplane broadcasts its location and identity to all other airplanes. Every cockpit has a display screen, a miniature version of those in air traffic control centers, that tells pilots the flight paths and altitudes of other airplanes in the vicinity.
Because pilots and controllers have more precise information than is provided by the current radar-based system, airplanes can fly closer together in the sky and land and take off more closely on the ground. Now, for example, pilots must wait for clearance from the tower before they take off. But with the satellite system, if the crew saw that it had the necessary three-mile separation from the previous takeoff, it could decide on its own to depart.
The new system has been tested in the Midwest. United Parcel Service, which is leading its development, believes it can be useful at its hub in Louisville. But the F.A.A., which has been working with the cargo carriers, has some reservations.
"What if the second pilot leaves before he has the three miles?" asked David W. Ford, the F.A.A. official in charge of developing such systems. "Who gets credited with the operational error?"
For now, the F.A.A. is working on deploying a series of discrete systems designed to improve the efficiency of takeoffs and landings at busy airports and to allow some airplanes to fly more direct routes. But these improvements will not come close to addressing the long-term growth in air traffic.
"We know we can make some changes," said Steven J. Brown, the F.A.A.'s acting associate administrator for air traffic services. "Those will be marginal -- not unimportant, but marginal."
 
The Criticism
Should the F.A.A.
Be Scuttled?
 Such talk fuels critics who say that the only way to end the gridlock in the skies is to junk the F.A.A. -- or junk the economics on which its management of the air traffic system is based.
Under the current arrangement, air traffic control services are paid for by taxes on airline tickets, cargo and fuel. Heavy users like commercial airlines do not pay any more to use the system than private pilots; small planes get the same priority as jumbo jets.
"The problem is that the resources are not priced properly," said Richard Golaszewski, a consultant who has advised the F.A.A. and several European countries. "In fact, they are not priced at all." That means that airlines have no incentive to limit their use of air traffic control services even at the most crowded airports.
For years, economists have urged the Government to switch to a fee-based system that would force users to pay for the services they use. Raising prices at peak hours would put pressure on airlines to reduce congestion. They might also switch service to underutilized secondary airports, or replace some regional jets with less frequent service on bigger planes.
"This is the unfinished business of deregulation," Mr. Golaszewski said. "We have taken off all of the controls on what airlines can do, but we haven't done anything to balance demand and capacity."
The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which operates Newark, LaGuardia and Kennedy airports, and the operators of San Francisco International Airport are considering changes that would discourage small planes, but both airport authorities fear the F.A.A. will block them.
Many advocates go farther and say that the air traffic control system needs to be separated from the F.A.A. and handed over to a new, independent entity that would operate like a business.
Various privatization proposals have been floated in Congress over the years, but none have made any progress. A plan that the Clinton administration sent to Capitol Hill in 1994 as part of Vice President Gore's campaign to reinvent government never got out of committee, even though the House was still controlled by Democrats at the time.
"I told him I'll do all I can to kill this idea," Representative James L. Oberstar, a Democrat from Minnesota who was then head of the House Transportation Committee's aviation subcommittee, recalled in a recent interview, referring to Mr. Gore.
Mr. Oberstar, now the ranking minority member on the committee, said that privatizing the F.A.A. would not break the aviation gridlock. "Who is to say that the private sector is going to do a better job than the public sector?" he said. "The same private sector that brings you delays?"
The F.A.A., he added, is already beginning to act more like a business. Congress passed legislation a few years ago creating a 15-member advisory council to supervise the agency. A bill passed this spring directed the council to hire a chief operating officer to run the air traffic control system.
Congress also increased the F.A.A.'s budget by $10 billion over the next three years to $40 billion over the next three years. And it required that funds collected from ticket taxes be spent only on aviation-related projects, such as expanding airports, rather than being used to finance other government programs.
" What we want to do is to give these things a chance and see if they won't make a difference," said Phil Boyer, president of the Aircraft Owners and Pilots Association, a longtime oppoinent of privatization whose 360,000 members make up more than half the licensed pilots in the country.
But critics say that the F.A.A. has been given too many chances already. Mr. Mead, the inspector general, said that Congress has been asking the F.A.A. since 1993 to assign a cost to each of the services its provides, as a prerequisite to charging user fees. Congress finally ordered that study in 1996; the F.A.A. now says it will be completed at the end of 2002.
Given the recent public outcry about flight delays, interest in privatization is on the rise again. Six years ago, when the Clinton administration floated its proposal, the concept was relatively new. Today, several countries, including Germany, Canada and New Zealand, have successfully contracted out air traffic services.
Nav Canada, the only private company in the world to run a national air traffic control system, has proven the most intriguing to policy makers in Washington. Before the nonprofit corporation was set up in 1996, the Canadian air traffic control system suffered many of the same problems that plague the F.A.A.: Its equipment was antiquated, and a proposed replacement was behind schedule and far over budget.
Since then, Nav Canada has managed to reduce air traffic delays, cut costs and revamp its technology. A cost-accounting system enables the company to charge users by the flight. Managers who worked under both systems say the new arrangement has enhanced safety, precisely because regulation and operations have been assigned to two different organizations. Airlines in the United States would like to be able to pay Nav Canada to control some domestic flights, but for now there is no mechanism for Nav Canada to accept such payments.
Some staff members on Capitol Hill have drafted a privatization proposal modeled on Nav Canada and are looking for a senator to sponsor it. Many analysts say the alternatives -- inching along with current plans or returning to tighter government regulation of air travel -- are unthinkable.
"My guess is that if we have one more summer as bad as this one, or even one worse than this one, finally it will force the issue," said John R. Meyer, a retired economics professor at Harvard who is in favor of introducing user fees. "That is the silver lining in every cloud."

CURRENT SYSTEM -- In the existing air traffic control system, based on ground-based radar, most pilots depend on controllers to guide them, single file and carefully spaced, along a limited number of clogged air corridors.
 
MINIMUM SPACING: -- 5 MILES HORIZONTALLY, 1,000 FT. VERTICALLY
 
ADDING IN SPACE -- In practice, controllers spread planes out more than the minimums allowed for an extra margin of safety. And at times of congestion, they add even more space to keep the number of planes manageable. During storms, some routes may close, with planes spaced out along remaining corridors.

SECTION: Section A; Page 10; Column 3; Foreign Desk 

LENGTH: 2078 words

HEADLINE: As Diplomacy Loses Luster, Stars Flee State Dept.

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4

 BODY:
At 32, Mona Sutphen, smart, driven and possessed of that quality so elusive in Washington, an easy personality, was known as one of the best and the brightest in the West Wing of the White House.
As executive assistant to the national security adviser, Samuel R. Berger, she was trusted to work on the most sensitive foreign policy matters. She sat through the tough crises, including whether to bomb Iraq and how to rescue an American pilot downed in enemy Yugoslav territory. Had she wanted, Ms. Sutphen, who was on loan from the State Department, could have gone to the heights of the United States Foreign Service: political counselor at an embassy, assistant secretary of state or an ambassador. Perhaps even the top job one day. 
 But those peaks did not look so great to Ms. Sutphen.
Instead of returning to the State Department and a future of writing cables that she felt nobody important read, she took her passion for foreign affairs to an Internet company. She is a prime example of what policy experts say is a crippling problem at the State Department: talented diplomats are leaving for careers that they believe have more power and prestige in the new global economy. And college graduates who used to rush to take the Foreign Service exam no longer bother.
The State Department, the institution responsible for American diplomacy around the world, is finding it hard to adjust to an era in which financial markets pack more punch than a Washington-Moscow summit meeting. It is losing recruits to investment banks, dot-com companies and the Treasury and Commerce Departments, which have magnified their foreign policy roles. Some are turning to idealistic private organizations that work in risky environments abroad, a far cry from the days of the cold war, when the State Department was the only place to be.
When Ms. Sutphen prepared to leave the State Department this spring, the Foreign Service made her decision easier because, while it took great pride in her as a woman of African-American heritage, it offered her nothing that she found challenging.
"In the end there was nothing on the horizon that I really wanted," she said. After the hothouse of the National Security Council at the White House, and having served in Bosnia and Thailand, the "idea of being the third political officer on the Israeli desk is very difficult." Instead, she chose to join the Manhattan office of Currenex, a Silicon Valley Internet company that specializes in business-to-business foreign currency trading at a salary of more than $100,000 -- more than twice her government pay -- plus stock options.
The loss of prestige and power at the State Department has not gone unnoticed around Washington or inside the department itself. What to do about it has consumed study groups and consultants and caused hand-wringing among the top echelon of State Department officials.
In fact, the department was so worried about the problem that two years ago it commissioned a study from a consulting firm, McKinsey & Company. The results delivered to the department, with recommendations to be carried out this year, were not flattering.
Young diplomats told the consultants that they were frustrated by slow promotions of the bureaucracy compared with promotions based on merit in the private sector. They questioned the relevance of their work. "The best for what work?" parried one respondent.
They were dismissive of what they described as demoralized management. They complained that the department was unresponsive to the needs of two-career couples, especially when sending diplomats abroad.
The study, titled "The War for Talent" -- tellingly renamed "The War Against Talent" in the department's corridors -- quoted one diplomat as saying, "You've joined the supposedly elite Foreign Service and you have terrible managers -- people who've been promoted to get them out of other people's hair."
Outside the department, the United States Commission on National Security/21st Century, set up by the federal government to study the nation's needs for its national security architecture, has taken a particular interest in the State Department's failings. The commission's executive director, Gen. Charles G. Boyd, said he had been taken aback by the department's difficulty in "retaining and recruiting quality people."
At elite graduate schools specializing in international relations, deans say that the Foreign Service has slipped down the totem pole as a career choice.
Instead, smart graduates who want to join government are heading for the Departments of the Treasury or Commerce, said Mark L. von Hagen, director of the Harriman Institute at Columbia University. Others gravitate toward nongovernmental organizations and to the World Bank. "It reflects the generally diminished role of the State Department in foreign policy," Mr. von Hagen said.
The new director general of the Foreign Service at the State Department, Marc Grossman, in essence the department's chief personnel officer, acknowledged the problem when he appeared before the Commission on National Security recently.
The dropout rate for one of the five groups of diplomats who entered the State Department in 1992 or 1993 was 32 percent, he said. For another group in that period, the dropout rate was 23 percent, although it was only 12 percent for two other groups. From 1994 to 1997, the dropout rate has hovered around 20 percent.
Officials at the State Department's personnel department said they do not have statistics to compare this dropout rate with previous decades. Nor, they said, had the department done analysis to determine whether those who had left in the 1990's were considered the most talented.
One of the most senior officials at the State Department, Under Secretary of States Thomas R. Pickering, who has served for nearly 40 years and has been ambassador to eight countries, said he did not believe that the dropout rates differed "so wildly" from the past, particularly in the era of the Vietnam war when many dissenters quit.
But General Boyd said that anecdotal evidence suggested that good young diplomats had quit in the 1990's and that the dropout rate was higher than in the past. And for all those who are leaving, there are believed to be many who are more than qualified but are not considering the Foreign Service. Last year, said the under secretary for management, Bonnie R. Cohen, there was a "significant" drop in the number of candidates who, after passing the written and oral exams of the Foreign Service and the security checks, accepted an offer to join the department. "That means young people are looking elsewhere for other jobs," said Ms. Cohen, who is in charge of budgetary and personnel matters for the department.
Money -- in particular the large financial packages from merchant banks that also offer stimulating work in the global economy -- is proving an important, though not overriding, reason for officials to leave. The average starting salary for a new Foreign Service officer is $32,500, Ms. Cohen said. This is less than some unionized customer service agents make at the Verizon telephone company..
Peter E. Bass, 37 -- who after a meteoric career left the State Department this summer to join Goldman Sachs as the chief of staff for the bank's president and chief operating officer, John L. Thornton -- is one of half a dozen officials who have been enticed away in the last several years by Goldman Sachs.
"I hope to gain a knowledge of the financial world, the global economy and capital markets, which are the key for global prosperity," Mr. Bass said, explaining his decision to leave. He had been deputy assistant secretary of state for energy and sanctions, involved in policy toward Iran and Libya.
But the Wall Street scale salary was also a lure. "When the difference in money is arithmetic, it's bearable; when it's geometric, it becomes harder and harder," Mr. Bass said.
One reason that Mr. Grossman is appreciated as the new face of personnel, though, is that he acknowledges that money is not the only reason for losing good people. He knows, he said, that in order to attract and keep talent, the department must evolve.
"The department has to change from being one that went and observed to one that sees itself in a more active world," Mr. Grossman said. "I can't give more people more money but I can give jobs that are seen as more active and less passive."
But it may be a hard argument to win. Many of the fields that Mr. Grossman talks about being new to the State Department -- international trafficking in people, the environment, empowering poor women -- are often handled by other American agencies operating abroad.
The Drug Enforcement Administration and the Federal Bureau of Investigation, for example, now operate at a number of American embassies. Rather than being proud of this expansion, American diplomats view these agencies as competitors for whom, they say, embassies perform the role of "concierge." At the American Embassy in London, for example, fewer than 20 percent of the officials belong to the State Department.
There are other hurdles: most notably, the archaic way the State Department hires people and treats them once they get inside. It can take up to two years before a candidate, who has taken the written exam (general knowledge, focusing on international affairs) and the oral exam (problem-solving) and passed the security clearance is invited to join the Foreign Service.
Diplomats who have recently left the State Department argue that the substance of the work must also change if good people are going to stay.
"You've got a culture where you are told to make notes and send them forward," said Spence Spencer, 38, who quit this summer after 12 years and three tours abroad. "A lot of it is staffing to make sure your boss looks good."
Mr. Spencer, who celebrated his departure over several glasses of wine at a recent lunch, left on a high note. He reached a cherished goal: equipping 30 court buildings in Kosovo with computers, fax machines, photo copiers, typewriters, generators and metal detectors.
An official in the department's Human Rights Bureau, Mr. Spencer said there was much more in the field of human rights that he would like to do at the State Department but felt he would be unable to achieve.
"There is such disdain for the community of nongovernment organizations at the State Department," said Mr. Spencer, whose passion is elections, police, justice and the other "soft" issues that crop up in regions of conflict.
"At State, you can't talk to these organizations with ease," he said. "So you are left talking to each other." Mr. Spencer is joining Public Strategies Inc., a company based in Austin, Tex. He will specialize in public affairs for European companies exporting to the United States and plans to do pro bono work for international nongovernmental organizations.
Another diplomat, Cynthia R. Bunton, 46, who dreamed of joining the State Department from age 12, speaks four languages and has served in a number of posts abroad. Now that she is back in Washington, the department is unable to find a way to use her new expertise in intellectual property rights, an increasingly vital issue for American business.
As the consul in Naples, Italy, for political and commercial affairs, she became an expert in property rights and for the past year has been on loan to the Recording Industry Association of America in Washington.
Ms. Bunton said she realized the importance of economics in diplomacy several years ago and decided to concentrate on music piracy. "The question is: do I go backward and become a political officer again -- which I have been all my life -- or go out into private industry?" she said. She still feels loyalty to the State Department, but she is leaning, she said, toward leaving.
One of those on the United States Commission on National Security, Leslie H. Gelb, said that in order to keep people like Ms. Sutphen, Mr. Bass, Mr. Spencer and Ms. Bunton, the State Department must make fundamental changes to regain the prestige of the past.
"The State Department will be able to attract anyone it wants when once again the building becomes the center of making foreign policy and foreign policy strategy," said Mr. Gelb, who is the president of the Council on Foreign Relations.
"Good people want to work at places that are at the center of things."

HEADLINE: Inmates Battling West's Fires Help States and Themselves

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL 

DATELINE: YELLOW PINE, Idaho, Sept. 1

 BODY:
Back in Utah, they are inmates at Bluffdale State Prison. But out here in the fire zone, they strut proudly in black T-shirts proclaiming themselves members of the Flame 'N' Go Hotshots.
"Being in this program makes all the difference," Bart Clark, 33, a six-time felon who has spent 11 of the last 15 years in prison, said this morning before shouldering his backpack on a hill acrid with smoke. 
 "Now I can tell my 4-year-old son that his dad isn't in prison, he's out fighting fires."
Almost every day since mid-May, Mr. Clark -- convicted most recently of kidnapping -- and the rest of his 20-man crew have been outside the wire, battling blazes across the West. The Utah program began in 1985, and as inmate-firefighters this year, the crew is far from alone.
In this devastating fire season, one in six of the crew members fighting fires by hand is a convict, drawn from state prisons in an enterprise that most everyone involved seems to see as benefiting all concerned.
"Sometimes there are special considerations, on account of their being inmates," said Mike Melton, a Forest Service official in command of the firefighting effort about 20 miles from this tiny town, deep in the mountains of central Idaho. "But frankly, we're glad to have any help we can get."
Other federal officials say the inmates have been invaluable, providing a much needed, well-trained and well-supervised reinforcement to resources that have worn thin.
At wages that average $1 an hour, the use of inmates is a bargain, one that might ease the taxpayers' burden in a year in which federal firefighting costs will exceed $1 billion.
And in conversations here in Idaho and in their Utah prison home, these inmates also described themselves as blessed, seeing fire as a vehicle that has brought not only a taste of freedom but an opportunity to redress old wrongs.
"Most of my life, I took things from other people, and now it's time to give something back," Tommy Phong, 33, said, puffing a cigarette in the early morning chill as he and the crew prepared to head out. After more than 13 years in prison, Mr. Phong, who was convicted of armed robbery, is scheduled to be paroled early next year, and he said he hoped his three summers fighting fires would prepare him for life outside of prison.
"All that time you're in prison, what's on your mind is to get out on the street," Mr. Phong said. "And from my first years as a firefighter, I've seen what it is like."
As the inmates loaded their gear, they were only one hub in a swirl of activity at the fire camp, home to forest rangers, college students, paramedics and skiers apparently unfazed by having prisoners in their midst.
"With some of the inmate crews, we get an extra security briefing, and the women are supposed to walk around in pairs," said John Cataldo, 28, a ranger in Alaska's Denali National Park who is on temporary fire duty in Idaho. "But everyone treats the Flame 'N' Goes like a regular hotshot crew."
The Utah team is the only crew of inmates to hold a federal designation as "hotshots," slang for top-ranking Type I status. They wear the T-shirts, not the orange prison jumpsuits assigned to inmates from California and some other states and -- under state policy -- are accompanied by unarmed escorts from Utah's Department of Corrections, not the gun-carrying guards common to some other inmate camps.
With wages that can reach $5.55 an hour, the Utah crew is better paid than other inmate teams, though the rate is just a fraction of civilian wages. A civilian firefighter with the same elite status would make about $15 an hour plus overtime.
But in all the heady rush, the prisoners have also been given a sobering reminder that firefighting is not without risk. Two fellow inmate-firefighters were killed last week in Utah in a lightning strike, raising questions about just how much value might be attached to an inmate's life.
The State of Utah has paid only for the inmates' funerals, and state officials say they cannot be confident that the two prisoners will become eligible for federal death benefits of nearly $150,000 that is routinely paid to firefighters slain in action.
"When we signed up, we had to sign a waiver that released the state from any liability," Michael Kinikini, 33, a member of that team and a convicted robber, said at the Utah prison this week. "But the bottom line is that we're out there protecting public land, and if we die, the compensation should be the same as for everyone else."
Of the two men killed, Michael Bishop, 27, had spent seven years in prison for attempted murder, while Roger Braithwaite, 26, had spent three years behind bars after a conviction for vehicular homicide. Both were within 36 months of their scheduled parole dates, a prerequisite for consideration in the Utah crew, and both had been moved to minimum-security quarters, another requirement.
"I wasn't too proud of him when he first went in to prison," Dan Bishop of Riverton, Utah, said of his late son. "But I became very, very proud."
By official count, some 25,000 firefighters are now involved in battling dozens of blazes across the West.
That count includes ground crews, air squads, fire engine personnel, and an army of supervisors and support personnel, said Neil Hitchcock, a federal fire manager who coordinates the use of firefighting resources.
About 13,000 people belong to crews assigned to the fire lines, Mr. Hitchcock said. Of these, more than 2,000 are inmates, according to estimates provided by regional fire centers, with most operating in California, home to the nation's largest inmate-firefighter program.
With an overall force of 60, divided among three 20-person crews, the Utah prison-firefighting program is one of the smallest in the West.
In addition to California's, which is spread across 38 conservation camps, another large program exists in Nevada and numbers about 900 inmates. Wyoming, Idaho, and, most recently, Texas are among the states that have established smaller operations.
In no state are the inmates compelled to serve as firefighters, state officials said.
The Utah program stands out in part because its inmate-firefighters are routinely permitted to travel outside the state, so that its teams have been in the lead this summer in battling some of the nation's largest fires.
But still, federal officials say that the contributions by other programs have also been felt widely, because the widespread use of inmates on fires in California, for example, has freed civilian crews to focus on blazes in Idaho and Montana, the states that have been hardest hit this summer.
In every state, the inmates are led by state forestry officials who guide them in firefighting techniques and relay directions from fire commanders. And though the rules imposed on inmates vary from state to state, a common denominator is a ban on participation by sex offenders or suspected escape risks. There have been no reported escape attempts or other incidents of misconduct involving inmates in the firefighting this year.
"They don't want anybody with any rabbit in them," said another inmate, Bryan Kawa, 32, of South Ogden, Utah, who was convicted on a weapons charge. Mr. Kawa, like other prisoners, is housed in a minimum-security dormitory, 30 men to a room, when he is not on the fire lines.
Among the advocates of prison-firefighting programs are those who argue that they make good economic sense.
In California, where the state prison population now stands at 162,000, it costs $21,000 a year to house a prisoner behind walls but just $13,000 a year at one of the conservation camps, said Mack Reynolds, a corrections official who supervises that state's program.
In California and some other states, the incentives offered for prisoner participation include early release, with a one-day credit in time served typically offered for every day that an inmate works on the fire line. In Utah, however, sentences are fixed, which state officials say is a reason that they provide more pay.
Some prisoner-rights advocates, led by the American Civil Liberties Union, have campaigned for broad changes in the law that would require that inmates be paid at least minimum wage and be made subject to other labor-protection laws.
In an interview, Carol Gnade, the group's executive director in Utah, said she had mixed feelings about the program.
"On the one hand, we encourage prisons to get more involved in giving opportunity to prisoners," Ms. Gnade said. "But at the same time, they should extend that to the same kinds of protections that other people receive."
The Utah inmates and their escorts described compensation as just one reward. "We get up on top of mountains where no one else has ever been," said Mr. Kawa, who is scheduled to be released in January after 11 years in prison.
"It's a zoo in there, and it's ugly," Ben Van Zandt, 35, a corrections officer, said of Bluffdale prison, home to 5,000 inmates. "A lot of these guys have spent many years in that zoo. And what this program does is to help them move from the zoo to the outside world."

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
A Russian Dinosaur

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

 BODY:
The sinking of the Russian submarine Kursk was a tragic but incredibly illuminating example of the transition the world, and Russia, are now going through from the cold-war system to the globalization system. Unfortunately, there's always some guy down the line who hasn't gotten the word yet. In this case it was Russia's president, Vladimir Putin.
Yo, Putin, this ain't your father's Soviet Union anymore. 
 In an interview on Russian TV following the Kursk tragedy, Mr. Putin defended his government and laid out his priorities: "I will be with the army. I will be with the fleet. I will be with the people." As Time magazine's Paul Quinn-Judge noted in a commentary from Moscow, Mr. Putin still believes that "the needs of the state always come first; individual concerns come a distant second."
Not in this era. What happens when a country like Russia plugs into globalization -- into global free markets, telecommunications, media and the Internet -- is that individuals become empowered, even super-empowered. That is, their ability to gather information themselves, earn a living and assert their will directly -- as individuals -- greatly increases thanks to globalization and the falling of walls everywhere. Moreover, when everyone starts to know how everyone else in the world is living, which also happens in globalization, individuals start to demand the same things. And they get angry when their leaders don't deliver.
The Kursk incident showed just how much the Russian people are starting to get this, and how little Mr. Putin does. Why did Mr. Putin and his generals resist asking for foreign help until it was too late? Because they feared it would sully the honor of Mother Russia's army and puncture Russia's pretense to still being a superpower. But the families of the Russian sailors, who knew foreign help was available, told them: "I don't want to hear about Mother Russia, or Father Russia. I want Yuri, Boris and Oleg off the ocean floor."
The message those parents sent to Russia's leaders was that "until further notice, you better have a good reason to risk a Russian soldier's life," remarked the Israeli political theorist Yaron Ezrahi, whose book, "Rubber Bullets," documents how Israel went through a similar transformation. "They sent a message that while national honor still matters, individual life and individual aspirations now matter too. They are now viable competitors with national honor -- and may matter even more. So it's not only Americans who don't want to die for abstractions anymore. It's also Russians."
Indeed, the Russian newspaper Izvestia ran a front-page picture of the crew of the Kursk, under a remarkable headline: "The Price of National Pride -- Human Lives." Such a headline, with such an equation, would have been unthinkable in the cold war, but it is utterly normal in globalization.
Sure, Mr. Putin can still send Russian soldiers to die in Chechnya, because many Russians still perceive that as a war of no choice against a real internal threat. But with the collapse of the cold-war system, they do not perceive an external threat. Indeed, most Russians would like to emulate America today, not bury it. And vice versa. Americans also prayed for the Kursk to be saved. Because without the cold-war psychological framework, the Kursk disaster was not seen as an enemy loss. It was seen as a human loss.
Does this mean that Russia will now have to fold its army and navy? Of course not. Russian nationalism and national security interests haven't gone away. But they now have a viable competitor in shaping Russian decision-making: the aspiration of individual Russians for personal security and personal fulfillment -- which today's globalization system encourages, by giving more Russians the information, connections, power and incentives to act on their own for their own betterment.
So everything is still possible with Russia. It's still possible that an autocratic Russian leader will try to restore Russian military power and provoke a war with the U.S. Yes, that is still possible. But in today's era of globalization it is much less sustainable. Because Russians will not automatically put up with pain and sacrifice anymore just to preserve some national symbols. Not in this world. That was the Kursk's crew's last message -- a message Russian leaders ignore at their peril. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: Online Deliveries Lighten Burden for the Disabled;
Empowerment, Not Just Convenience, For an Unexpected Class of Consumer

BYLINE: By JAYSON BLAIR 

 BODY:
Mary West stumbled across YourGrocer.com, an online grocery store, one afternoon a few years ago and quickly became a fan of its fresh blueberry muffins and fast deliveries.
Ordering her groceries by computer made Ms. West like any other shopper, and for this she was grateful. Now, Ms. West, who is blind, does not stand out the way she once did in D'Agostino's or Gristede's. 
 "I was looking for a place to do a lot of my shopping," said Ms. West, 35, "because I am visually impaired and I can't read labels and things on the grocery shelves." In the past, she had to rely on the help of store clerks and friends to shop for groceries and perform other tasks.
Before she had access to online delivery services, shopping had become so difficult that she had given up, ordering her favorite, although much less healthful, takeout instead.
"It really helps me out because I have a bad back, bad knees, diabetes and I can't really go the supermarket anymore," said Ms. West, who lives in Chelsea. "Four or five years ago I was not able to cook my own food because I did not have any, so I was ordering out, and that was not helping my health or my pocketbook."
Now she uses special voice recognition software to surf the Web for everything from dishwashing detergent to vegetables.
People like Ms. West, who have a temporary or permanent disability that makes it difficult to handle everyday chores on their own, are increasingly using online delivery services to rent movies, pick up cleaning supplies and buy groceries.
The advantages of information technology are pronounced in places like Manhattan, advocates for the disabled say, because crowded streets, the lack of access for the handicapped to cabs and subway stations, and other factors complicate their lives.
To the disabled, the growth of online delivery services has been empowering. To their advocates, it represents progress. To some owners of such businesses, it has become another piece of a shrewd business equation. Noble as it may be to help the disabled like rent a movie from Blockbuster or buy fresh vegetables on their own, to J. Maxwell Enoch, the chief executive of YourGrocer. com, it is about capitalizing on a market his company's founders did not even envision.
"Undoubtedly, the sort of people we are talking about have found a way to our service," Mr. Enoch said, "and it is very meaningful to them."
People with permanent disabilities, like Ms. West, and those who are temporarily off their feet, like women recovering after childbirth and runners with sprained knees, have created a new marketing niche for Mr. Enoch's company, which is based in Eastchester, N.Y., and serves New York City and some of its suburbs.
"In Manhattan, you are held hostage by the D'Agostinos and the Gristedes of the world," Mr. Enoch said in a recent interview. He noted that those grocery stores are often busy and cannot provide much attention to a disabled customer. Even when the handicapped are able to navigate these stores, he added, they often have difficulty getting the items back home. "A lot of the things we carry are heavy," Mr. Enoch said, and for the disabled, the benefits of delivery are magnified.
Executives of similar online delivery services said they were not necessarily trying to attract disabled customers when they started operating. Most of the businesses, based in Manhattan's Silicon Alley, focused on reaching young urban professionals, appealing to a simple desire for convenience.
"We go where the customers lead us," said Skip Trevathan, the chief operating officer at Kozmo.com, which is based in Manhattan and delivers many items, including toilet paper and movies, in cities across the country. "It obviously was in the thinking behind the business model, but only in a narrow sense of people who were homebound for a few days because of something like pregnancy or an injury."
That vision has expanded, Mr. Trevathan added. Now, the first page of Kozmo's employee training manual includes a letter from a disabled customer, Cameo C. Massey. Ms. Massey, a single mother in Seattle who suffers from Epstein-Barr syndrome and has severe nerve damage from troublesome surgeries, wrote about her difficulties doing everyday chores.
"I find myself at the mercy of my own limitations," Ms. Massey wrote. "Your service has helped make my life filled with more quality time. By being able to order books, magazines, movies, games and food from Kozmo, I find that I am able to feel more in touch and up to date with normal people."
Many disabled New Yorkers echo those sentiments. Ms. West, who teaches at the Computer Center for the Visually Impaired People at Baruch College, said that for the first time in her life, she "can handle everything like a sighted person."
Kozmo.com officials said they believed that as more disabled Americans gain access to computers, they would increasingly rely on online delivery services. A recent Harris poll conducted for the National Organization on Disability and financed by Aetna U.S. Healthcare found that adults with disabilities were twice as likely as the nondisabled to report that the Internet had significantly improved their lives. But the poll also found that only 43 percent of the disabled respondents had access to the Internet, compared with 57 percent of the nondisabled respondents.
For its part, Kozmo.com has begun a campaign with the National Cristina Foundation, a nonprofit organization that brings computer technology to the disabled, to deliver donated computers to the doorsteps of disabled Americans.
In a partnership with General Motors, Kmart and Microsoft, Heidi Van Arnem, a Birmingham, Mich., entrepreneur who has been a quadriplegic since 16, began a national campaign this year, the 10th anniversary of the passage of the Americans With Disabilities Act, to draw attention to what she calls the "disability divide."
In a speech she gave when the campaign started, Ms. Van Arnem, the chief executive of I-Can Online, which provides consultant services to commercial Web sites trying to reach the disabled, said, "Disabilities disappear with advancements in technology." But the fact that the people who benefit most are the ones most likely not to have a computer is frustrating, she said.
She added that the online companies beginning to cater to the disabled "represent a growing awareness that there is great opportunity to reach the 85 percent of people with disabilities who are not online yet, and whose lives stand to be enhanced by connecting to the Internet."
Robert Harvey, the president of I-Can Online, said in a recent interview that the disabled population is "the most underserved and underattended market in the country" because the disabled "are just not in public view. But they spend a trillion dollars a year on our economy."
Fifty-four million Americans, about 20 percent of the population, have disabilities, according to the latest Census Bureau data. There are about 5.6 million disabled people in New York City and its suburbs.
Most online delivery companies, Mr. Harvey said, began with a "throw seeds out and watch to see if anything will sprout" approach and quickly found that the disabled could become one of their most solid customer bases. Their success has caused other businesses to "think about this population and how they want to reach them," he said.
Despite the advantages that the Internet offers to the disabled, technological problems persist. For example, the National Federation of the Blind has sued America Online, claiming that AOL violates the Americans With Disabilities Act because its software is incompatible with many voice recognition programs, known as assisted technology. The suit is pending.
And advocacy groups have begun lobbying for an amendment to the Americans With Disabilities Act that would require online companies to give the handicapped access to the Internet, given the importance the medium has become in commerce and communication.
Several companies, including YourGrocer.com, UrbanFetch.com and Amazon.com, have had to deal with similar technical issues. Even I-Can Online had problems, since corrected, that made it difficult for voice recognition software to read its Web pages. The software allows users to control their computers with their voices instead of keyboards. The computer also reads text from Web pages, if they are formatted properly.
"It did not take us long to realize that we could not be the advocates for people with disabilities and not have ramps for our own people," said Mr. Harvey, the president of I-Can. "One of the elements we now put in our contracts is that the companies will work to make their sites more accessible."
Many online delivery companies have found, Mr. Harvey said, that improvements that make it easier for the disabled to use their sites can also appeal to nondisabled customers. For example, voice recognition software compatibility could be helpful to someone trying to shop on the Web while driving a car.
The challenges notwithstanding, Ms. West sees the improvements for disabled people as a monumental and empowering turning point. "It evens the playing field," she said.

INTERNATIONAL A3-12
 
Clinton New York Trip To Seek Diplomatic Gains
President Clinton's foreign policy aides said he planned a diplomatic whirlwind in New York, including what one senior official called "the last real chance" to jump-start the failed talks between Israel and the Palestinians and what might prove to be a tense session with China's president over Beijing's continued missile exports to Pakistan. A1
 
Siren Call of the New Economy
Policy experts say the State Department is losing talented diplomats who are leaving for careers that they believe have more power and prestige in the new global economy. The State Department is losing recruits to investment banks, dot-com companies and the Treasury and Commerce Departments. A1
 
Debate on China Trade Deal
The United States Senate, after months of delay, opens debate this week on President Clinton's trade pact with China, setting the stage for a final showdown between free-trade supporters and their foes. Each side expressed optimism that it would prevail. (Reuters)
 
Concorde Crash Inquiry
A metal fragment that was lying on the runway and that figures in the crash of the Air France Concorde in July apparently came from a Continental Airlines DC-10 that had taken off from the same runway minutes earlier, French investigators said. A6
 
Russian Mogul Cites Threat
Boris Berezovsky said a senior Kremlin official had ordered him to transfer his holdings in Russia's primary state-owned television channel to the state or face the prospect of going to jail. Mr. Berezovsky made the assertion in a letter to President Vladimir V. Putin. A10
 
Court Weighs Fate of Twins
England's Court of Appeal was asked to decide whether doctors could proceed with an operation that would separate conjoined twins but would sacrifice the life of one to save the other. The infants' parents object to the plan, although doctors say both children will probably die without the surgery. A5

SECTION: Section B; Page 1; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 1512 words

HEADLINE: Contest for Albany Seat Hinges on a Veteran Legislator's Relevance

SERIES: NEW YORK PRIMARY: 141st Assembly District

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS 

DATELINE: BUFFALO, Sept. 3

 BODY:
By noon, Assemblyman Arthur O. Eve had already put in a full morning of campaigning and seemed more than a bit weary. He had spent hours today shaking the hands of supporters and had just completed a caravan through the humid streets of Buffalo with a dozen cars carrying loudspeakers imploring people along the way to vote for him.
Mr. Eve, 67, a veteran of Buffalo politics, the deputy speaker of the State Assembly and the longest serving member of that legislative body, is now fully immersed in the fight of his political life. After more than three decades of a political career that began when Lyndon B. Johnson was president and Nelson A. Rockefeller was governor, Mr. Eve has had to campaign with an intensity that, by his own admission, he has never had to employ before. 
 In a three-way race in the Sept. 12 Democratic primary, Mr. Eve's major challenger is Crystal D. Peoples, 48, the majority leader of the Erie County Legislature. Ms. Peoples has defied expectations in earlier races by winning as the consummate outsider backed by a strong grass-roots group of supporters. In her campaign, Ms. Peoples acknowledges with admiration Mr. Eve's years of public service, but she insists that his methods are outdated and that he has become ineffective.
The themes being evoked against Mr. Eve in his 18th campaign reflect a trend that is dominating several of the races in the state in this year's primary season. Several black incumbents, like Mr. Eve, who came of political age during the civil rights movement are now facing vigorous challenges from insurgents who are depicting these political stalwarts as tired legislators with an antiquated approach to governing.
The technique is not only a hallmark of the campaign against Mr. Eve here along the streets of Buffalo's largely black East Side. It is also being used with great fanfare in primary races in New York City, against such longtime members of Congress as Major R. Owens and Edolphus Towns of Brooklyn and against others in Assembly races.
"In different parts of the country, there are incumbents who came to power in the early wave of majority black districts who have not faced serious competition for a long period of time," said John H. Mollenkopf, director of the Urban Research Center at the City University of New York's Graduate Center.
"And they are therefore in varying degrees of contact with their base," Mr. Mollenkopf said. "And that makes them vulnerable to challenges to somebody who decides that what was great for the civil rights era is not appropriate for today."
The evidence that Mr. Eve is taking this race seriously is abundant. He has summoned several elected officials here to campaign on his behalf, including State Comptroller H. Carl McCall, United States Representative Charles B. Rangel of Harlem, Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver and Representative Maxine Waters of California.
In addition, Mr. Eve's son Eric, who ran Vice President Al Gore's primary campaign in New York State, is now helping his father's re-election effort.
In one appearance before voters after another, Arthur Eve says that his years in office have produced landmark legislation, effective programs sponsored by the state and millions of dollars for community organizations throughout the 141st Assembly District which he represents.
He takes particular pride, for example, in his role in establishing the Educational Opportunity Program, which helps economically disadvantaged students attend the State University of New York, and in sponsoring bills that require affirmative action on state-financed projects.
"We've been able to put a lot of institutions in this community over 34 years," Mr. Eve said today, sitting in a campaign office buzzing with volunteers. "We have been instrumental in bringing in money for housing. We have developed training programs, educational programs and many other programs. I've tried to create institutions that will last long after Arthur Eve is gone from the scene."
He points out that with the reapportionment of legislative districts within a year or two, western New York is likely to lose at least one Assembly seat because of declining population. He says his seniority will ensure that this largely black corner of the region will be remembered by legislators who carve districts based in part on incumbents' length of service.
But Ms. Peoples says that none of those programs nor the pipeline of state money has made a difference on the East Side of Buffalo. She points to the once-thriving commercial district along Jefferson Avenue, where there are now as many shuttered businesses as open ones. She points out that there is but one supermarket in the entire district of 120,000 residents and that the streets are in dire need of repairs and the schools in need of upgrading.
"I give him all due respect for his length of service and the sacrifices he has made," she said. "But that doesn't automatically make him the elected official to stay in power for life. I'm also running because the social agenda of the 60's is old and should be over with. We have to focus on economic issues now."
She added that the conditions in the 141st District present the most salient argument for Mr. Eve's retirement. "If our community were booming, if everyone was doing well and if our streets and schools were in good shape, then you could make an argument for keeping him in office," she said. "But that's not what's happening here."
Ms. Peoples has emerged as a formidable candidate, in part because of her involvement with the political organization called Grassroots. The organization has made a name for itself because of its success at registering thousands of voters and placing several of its members in elected office, notably Ms. Peoples and Byron W. Brown, a member of the Buffalo Common Council who is now challenging a state senator, Alfred T. Coppola.
Ms. Peoples, a former elementary schoolteacher who has served on the County Legislature for five years, has been a relentless campaigner. She has walked the streets of the district night and day, from senior centers and public housing complexes to Gigi's, a soul food restaurant, where she greeted people over their morning grits and eggs. She wears a T-shirt bearing her name on the front and the slogan "Keeping It Real" on the back. She has raised about $40,000 for the campaign, she said, and has an army of volunteers.
Mr. Eve has put together his own battalion of campaign troops, some from outside Buffalo, and has raised about $60,000. His campaign officials have studied the races of other longtime incumbents under attack by younger challengers, like Mr. Rangel's 1996 race against Adam Clayton Powell IV.
The competitiveness of the campaign has led him not only to defend his record, but also to undertake a vigorous campaign schedule, like that of Ms. Peoples.
"She has name recognition because she is a public official," Mr. Eve said on a recent morning. "And so I have to campaign in a way that enables me to get my message out. This is the greatest challenge I have ever had."
The candidates' campaign commercials seem to be broadcast incessantly on some of Buffalo's radio stations. Campaign posters are on storefront windows, lawns and buildings throughout the district.
The prominence of those signs is symbolic of how divisive this race has been in Buffalo, particularly in the city's black neighborhoods. (The third candidate in the primary is Samuel A. Herbert.)
Some, like Mr. Brown, the Common Council member and State Senate candidate, say they appreciate the work Mr. Eve has done over the years, but find Ms. Peoples's message far more captivating. "She is articulate, charismatic, and makes a good point," said Mr. Brown, who was once an aide to Mr. Eve. "I feel it's time for a change."
Others, like Beverly A. Gray, another Common Council member, say they are disturbed to see that a man who has achieved such seniority and has been such a symbol of black political power in western New York has been forced into a highly competitive primary.
"Many of us are appalled at this," Ms. Gray said. "Arthur Eve has a history of creating great educational programs. He has dedicated himself to this community. And this primary is terrible because it has divided our community."
Mr. Eve, who left segregated Miami to work in a Chevrolet assembly plant in Buffalo before entering politics, says he wants to continue in office because "this city has been so good to me, and I want to continue giving back to this community."
The characterizations of him as an ineffective relic from another era, Mr. Eve said, "used to bother me, especially because they came from people who were helped by the very educational programs that I helped to create."
Speaking slowly, with a hint of melancholy, Mr. Eve said, "That used to bother me, but it doesn't anymore. I just tell myself that it's just politics."
